Chapter 1 - GENERAL PROVISIONS[1] 

Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
State Law reference— Cities and municipalities generally, K.S.A. 12-101 et seq.; ordinances generally, K.S.A. 12-3001 et seq.; compilation, revision and codification of city ordinances, K.S.A. 12-3014 et seq.; incorporation of subjects by reference, K.S.A. 12-3009 et seq. 
 
Sec. 1-1. - Designation and citation of Code. 
The ordinances embraced in this and the following chapters and sections shall constitute and be designated the "Code of Ordinances, Leavenworth, Kansas," and may be so cited. Such Code may also be cited as the "Leavenworth Code." 
(Code 1978, § 1-1; Code 1994, § 1-1) 
State Law reference— Revision and codification of ordinances, K.S.A. 12-3014—12-3016.  
Sec. 1-2. - Definitions and rules of construction. 
(a)  In the construction of this Code, and of all ordinances and resolutions passed by the city commission, the rules set out in this chapter shall be observed and the definitions prescribed in this chapter shall apply, unless such construction would be inconsistent with the manifest intent of the city commission. 
(b)  The provisions of this Code shall be liberally construed to affect the purposes expressed therein or implied from the expressions thereof. In case of doubt or ambiguity in the meaning of such provisions, the general shall yield to the particular. Reference for interpretation and construction shall tend to further the accomplishment of the elimination of the particular mischiefs for which the provisions were enacted. Words shall be construed according to the context and the approved usage of the language, but technical words and phrases, and such others as may have acquired a peculiar and appropriate meaning in law, shall be construed according to such meaning. 
City. The term "the city" or "this city" means the City of Leavenworth, in the County of Leavenworth and State of Kansas. 
City commission. The term "city commission" means the city commission of the City of Leavenworth, Kansas. 
City officers, departments, etc. Whenever reference is made to an officer, department, commission or other agency, such reference shall be construed as if followed by the words "of the City of Leavenworth, Kansas." 
Code. The term "Code" or "this Code" means this Code. 
County. The term "county" or "this county" means the County of Leavenworth, Kansas. 
Delegation of authority. Whenever a provision appears requiring or authorizing the head of a department or officer of the city to do some act or perform some duty, it shall be construed to authorize such department head or officer to designate, delegate and authorize subordinates to do the required act or perform the required duty unless the terms of the provision designate otherwise. 
Fee schedule. The term "fee schedule" means the official consolidated list of city rates, fees and changes on file in the office of the city clerk. 
Gender. A word importing the masculine gender only shall extend and be applied to females and to firms, partnerships, associations and corporations, as well as to males. 
Joint authority. Words purporting to give authority to three or more officers or other persons shall be construed as giving such authority to a majority of such officers or other persons, unless it is otherwise declared. 
K.A.R. The abbreviation "K.A.R." means the Kansas Administrative Regulations, as amended. 
K.S.A. The abbreviation "K.S.A." means the Kansas Statutes Annotated, as amended. 
Land; real estate; real property. The term "land" and the phrases "real estate" and "real property" mean and include lands, tenements and hereditaments, and all rights thereto and interest therein, equitable as well as legal. 
Month. The term "month" means a calendar month. 
Number. Any word importing the singular number shall include the plural and any word importing the plural number shall include the singular. 
Oath. The term "oath" means and includes an affirmation in all cases in which, by law, an affirmation may be substituted for an oath, and in such cases, the terms "swear" and "sworn" shall be equivalent to the terms "affirm" and "affirmed." 
Or, and. The term "or" may be read "and," and the term "and" may be read "or," if the sense requires it. 
Ordinance. The term "ordinance" means a legislative act of the city commission of a general and permanent nature. 
Parkings. The term "parkings" means the area between the roadway and right-of-way line. 
Person. The term "person" shall extend and be applied to corporations, firms, partnerships and bodies politic and corporate as well as to individuals. The term "person" includes unincorporated clubs, sororities, fraternities, associations and organizations of whatever name and nature. Where criminal prosecution may lie, the officers of any corporation shall jointly and severally be subject to prosecution as being included within the term "person." 
Personal property. The term "personal property" means and includes money, goods, chattels, evidences of debt and "things in action." 
Preceding; following. The terms "preceding" and "following" mean next before and next after, respectively. 
Property. The term "property" means and includes personal property and real property. 
Resolution. The term "resolution" means a legislative act of the city commission of a special or temporary character. 
Roadway. The term "roadway" means that portion of a street improved, designed or ordinarily used for vehicular traffic. 
Shall, may. The term "shall" is mandatory and the term "may" is permissive. 
Sidewalk. The term "sidewalk" means any portion of the street between the curb or the lateral line of the roadway and the adjacent property line, intended for the use of pedestrians. 
Signature or subscription. The term "signature" or "subscription" means and includes a mark when a person cannot write. 
State. The term "the state" or "this state" means the State of Kansas. 
Street or highway. The term "street" or "highway" means and includes any highway, alley, street, avenue or public place or square, bridge, viaduct, underpass, overpass, tunnel and causeway in the city, dedicated or devoted to public use. 
Tense. Words used in the past or present tense include the future as well as the past and present. 
Written or in writing. The term "written" or "in writing" means and includes any representation of words, letters or figures, whether by printing or otherwise, except in those cases where the written signature or mark of any person is required. 
Year. The term "year" means a calendar year. 
(Code 1978, §§ 1-19, 1-20, 1-24—1-49; Code 1994, § 1-2) 
State Law reference— Rules of statutory construction, K.S.A. 77-201.  
Sec. 1-3. - Catchlines of sections. 
The catchlines of the several sections of this Code printed in boldface type are intended as mere catchwords to indicate the contents of the section and, unless otherwise specifically provided, they shall not be deemed or taken to be titles of such sections, nor as any part of the section, nor, unless expressly so provided, shall they be so deemed when any of such sections, including the catchlines, are amended or reenacted. 
(Code 1978, § 1-22; Code 1994, § 1-3)  
Sec. 1-4. - History notes. 
The history notes appearing in parentheses after sections in this Code are not intended to have any legal effect but are merely intended to indicate the source of matter contained in the section. 
(Code 1978, § 1-23; Code 1994, § 1-4)  
Sec. 1-5. - Amendments or additions to Code. 
(a)  All ordinances passed subsequent to the passage of this Code which amend, repeal or in any way affect this Code may be numbered in accordance with the numbering system of this Code and printed for inclusion therein. When subsequent ordinances repeal any section, such repealed section may be excluded from this Code by the omission thereof from reprinted pages. Whenever any ordinance expresses the intent of the city commission that it be made a part of this Code and such ordinance is thereafter included in a supplement to this Code, such inclusion shall have the same force and effect as if the ordinance had been included at the time of the original adoption of this Code by the city commission. 
(b)  No section or sections of an ordinance shall be amended unless the amending ordinance contains the entire section or sections as amended and the section or sections amended shall be repealed. 
(c)  Amendments to any of the provisions of this Code shall be made by amending such provisions by specific reference to the section number of this Code in the following language: "That section _____ of the Code of Ordinances, city, Kansas, is hereby amended to read as follows:…." The section, as amended, shall then be set out in full. 
(d)  If a new section not then existing in this Code is to be added, the following language shall be used: "That the Code of Ordinances, Leavenworth, Kansas, is hereby amended by adding a section, to be numbered _____, which such section reads as follows:…." The new section shall then be set out in full. 
(Code 1978, § 1-4; Code 1994, § 1-5) 
State Law reference— Amendments to looseleaf codes, K.S.A. 12-3015; amendment of ordinance, K.S.A. 12-3004.  
Sec. 1-6. - Supplementation of Code. 
(a)  By contract or by city personnel, supplements to this Code shall be prepared and printed whenever authorized or directed by the city commission. A supplement to this Code shall include all substantive permanent and general parts of ordinances passed by the city commission or adopted by initiative and referendum during the period covered by the supplement and all changes made thereby in this Code. The pages of a supplement shall be so numbered that they will fit properly into this Code and will, where necessary, replace pages which have become obsolete or partially obsolete, and the new pages shall be so prepared that, when they have been inserted, this Code will be current through the date of the adoption of the latest ordinance included in the supplement. 
(b)  In preparing a supplement to this Code, all portions of this Code which have been repealed shall be excluded from this Code by the omission thereof from reprinted pages. 
(c)  When preparing a supplement to this Code, the codifier (meaning the person authorized to prepare the supplement) may make formal, nonsubstantive changes in ordinances and parts of ordinances included in the supplement, insofar as it is necessary to do so to embody them into a unified code. For example, the codifier may: 
(1)  Organize the ordinance material into appropriate subdivisions; 
(2)  Provide appropriate catchlines, headings and titles for sections and other subdivisions of this Code printed in the supplement, and make changes in such catchlines, headings and titles; 
(3)  Assign appropriate numbers to sections and other subdivisions to be inserted in this Code and, where necessary to accommodate new material, change existing section or other subdivision numbers; 
(4)  Change the words "this ordinance" or words of the same meaning to "this chapter," "this article," "this division," etc., as the case may be, or to "sections _____ to _____" (inserting section numbers to indicate the sections of this Code which embody the substantive sections of the ordinance incorporated into this Code); and 
(5)  Make other nonsubstantive changes necessary to preserve the original meaning of ordinance sections inserted into this Code; but, in no case, shall the codifier make any change in the meaning or effect of ordinance material included in the supplement or already embodied in this Code. 
(Code 1978, § 1-5; Code 1994, § 1-6)  
Sec. 1-7. - Severability of parts of Code. 
It is hereby declared to be the intention of the city commission that the sections, paragraphs, sentences, clauses and phrases of this Code are severable and, if any phrase, clause, sentence, paragraph or section of this Code shall be held invalid or unconstitutional by the valid judgment or decree of any court of competent jurisdiction, such holding shall not affect any of the remaining phrases, clauses, sentences, paragraphs and sections of this Code, since the same would have been enacted by the city commission without the incorporation in this Code of any such invalid or unconstitutional phrase, clause, sentence, paragraph or section. 
(Code 1978, § 1-7; Code 1994, § 1-7)  
Sec. 1-8. - Miscellaneous ordinances not affected by Code. 
Nothing in this Code or the ordinance adopting this Code shall be deemed to affect the validity of any of the following: 
(1)  Any charter ordinance; 
(2)  Any ordinance pertaining to the acquisition of property or interests in property by gift, purchase, devise, bequest, appropriation or condemnation; 
(3)  Any ordinance opening, dedicating, widening, vacating or narrowing streets, avenues, alleys and boulevards; 
(4)  Any ordinance establishing and changing grades of streets, avenues, alleys and boulevards; 
(5)  Any ordinance naming or changing the names of streets, avenues and boulevards; 
(6)  Any ordinance authorizing or directing public improvements to be made; 
(7)  Any ordinance creating districts for public improvements of whatsoever kind or nature; 
(8)  Any ordinance levying general taxes; 
(9)  Any ordinance levying special assessments or taxes; 
(10)  Any ordinance granting any rights, privileges, easements or franchises therein mentioned to any person; 
(11)  Any ordinance authorizing the issuance of bonds and other instruments of indebtedness by the city; 
(12)  Any ordinance authorizing contracts; 
(13)  Any ordinance establishing the limits of the city or pertaining to annexation or exclusion of territory; 
(14)  Any ordinance relating to compensation of officials, officers and employees of the city; 
(15)  Any zoning ordinance; 
provided that the enumeration of exceptions set out in this section shall not be held or deemed to be exclusive, it being the purpose and intention to exempt from repeal any and all ordinances not of a general nature and general ordinances specifically excepted by this section. 
(Code 1978, § 1-2; Code 1994, § 1-8)  
Sec. 1-9. - Code does not affect prior offenses, rights, etc. 
Nothing in this Code or the ordinance adopting this Code shall affect any offense or act committed or done, or any penalty or forfeiture incurred, or any contract or right established or accruing, before the effective date of this Code. 
(Code 1978, § 1-3; Code 1994, § 1-9)  
Sec. 1-10. - General penalty for violation of Code; continuing violations. 
Whenever in this Code or in any ordinance of the city an act is prohibited or is made or declared to be unlawful or an offense or a misdemeanor, or whenever in such Code or ordinance the doing of any act is required or the failure to do any act is declared to be unlawful, and no specific penalty is provided therefor, the violation of any such provision of this Code or any such ordinance shall be punished by a fine not exceeding $500.00 or by imprisonment for a period not exceeding six months, or by both such fine and imprisonment, as may be just for any one offense, recoverable with costs of suit, together with judgment of imprisonment until the fine and costs are paid or satisfied. Each day any violation of this Code or of any ordinance shall continue shall constitute a separate offense. 
(Code 1978, § 1-6; Code 1994, § 1-10) 
State Law reference— Penalty provisions for incorporating ordinances, K.S.A. 12-3011; jurisdiction of municipal courts, K.S.A. 12-4104.  
Sec. 1-11. - Applicability of state law relative to misdemeanors. 
The provisions of the laws of the state relating to misdemeanors, with reference to defense and construction of terms, insofar as such provisions relate to and are applicable, shall apply to this Code. 
(Code 1978, § 1-21; Code 1994, § 1-11) 
State Law reference— Kansas Criminal Code, K.S.A. 21-5101 et seq.  
Chapter 2 - ADMINISTRATION  
ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 
 
Secs. 2-1—2-18. - Reserved.  
ARTICLE II. - CITY COMMISSION[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
State Law reference— Authority for commission-manager plan, K.S.A. 12-184b(3), 12-1039. 
 
DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 
 
Sec. 2-19. - Composition; election; term of office. 
(a)  Form of government. The city continues to operate under the commission-manager form of government, pursuant to K.S.A. 12-184b and pursuant to all existing ordinances and charter ordinances relating to its form of government. The city commission shall consist of five commissioners, who are residents and qualified electors of the city, to be elected to terms set forth herein. 
(b)  Elections of commissioners. General elections shall be held on the Tuesday following the first Monday in November of each odd-numbered year. All elections for the city shall be nonpartisan. 
(c)  Terms of office. The terms of each commissioner position with terms that would have expired in January 2020 shall expire the first Tuesday in December 2019 when the commissioners elected in general election take office. The terms of each commission position with terms that would have expired in January 2022 shall expire the first Tuesday in December 2021 when the commissioners elected in the November 2021 general election take office. At each regular city election, there shall be elected two commissioners for a four-year term, and one commissioner for a two-year term. The candidates receiving the largest and second largest number of votes shall be elected for four-year terms, and the candidate receiving the third largest number of votes shall be elected for a two-year term commencing the first Tuesday in December following certification of the election. 
(d)  Candidacy for city commission. In accordance with K.S.A. 25-205, and amendments thereto, any person may become a candidate for city office elected at large by having had filed on their behalf, a nomination petition or a declaration of candidacy, accompanied by any fee required by law not later than 12:00 noon, on June 1, prior to such primary election, or if such date falls on Saturday, Sunday or a holiday, then before 12:00 noon on the next following day that is not a Saturday, Sunday or holiday. If filing by nomination petition, such petition must be signed by 50 qualified electors of the city or not less than one percent of the ballots cast and counted at the last general city election, whichever is less. 
(e)  City manager. The city commission shall appoint a city manager to be responsible for the administration and affairs of the city. The city manager shall serve at the pleasure of the city commission. The city manager shall see that all laws and ordinances are enforced. The city manager shall appoint and remove all heads of departments and all subordinate officers and employees of the city. All appointments shall be made upon merit and fitness alone. 
(Ord. No. 8104 , § 1, 6-25-2019) 
State Law reference— Form of government continued, K.S.A. 12-184a.  
Sec. 2-20. - Powers generally. 
All powers exercised by cities of the first class, or which shall be conferred upon such cities, shall be exercised by the city commission, insofar as they do not conflict with the provisions of the statues relating to the commissioner-manager form of government. 
(Code 1994, § 2-27; Ord. No. 7812, 11-24-2009)  
Sec. 2-21. - No title distinctions between commissioners; compensation. 
Regulations relating to the commissioners of the city shall include the following: 
(1)  No distinction shall be made in the title or duties among the commissioners, except as the board shall organize itself for business. 
(2)  The commissioners shall be entitled to receive and be reimbursed for any reasonable expenses incurred as a result of trips or efforts made on behalf of the city. 
(3)  Each commissioner shall receive a $50.00 per month technology allowance to be used on technology costs of their choosing, to include, but not limited to, the cost of internet and phone. 
(4)  Each commissioner shall receive a salary of $6,000.00 per year, payable in monthly installments, provided that the commissioner chosen as chairperson annually, who shall have the title of mayor, shall, be paid $7,200.00 during the year of office, payable in monthly installments. 
(Code 1994, § 2-28; Ord. No. 7812, 11-24-2009; Ord. No. 8065, § 1, 12-12-2017) 
State Law reference— Authority of city commission to establish powers and duties of city commission and city manager, K.S.A. 12-184b.  
Sec. 2-22. - Mayor and mayor pro tem. 
The city commission shall choose its chairperson annually, and the chairperson shall have the title of mayor during the year of office, to the end that the city shall have an official head on formal occasions. The city commission shall also choose a vice-chairperson annually, and the vice-chairperson shall have the title of mayor pro tem during the year of office, to the end that the city shall have an official head on all formal occasions in the absence of the duly elected mayor. 
(Code 1994, § 2-29; Ord. No. 7812, 11-24-2009)  
Sec. 2-23. - Determination of offices and fixing of salaries. 
The city commission shall provide for such offices as shall be necessary to carry out the provisions of the state statutes relating to the commission-manager plan of government and determine salaries for such offices. 
(Code 1994, § 2-32; Ord. No. 7812, 11-24-2009)  
Sec. 2-24. - Members not to interfere with conduct of departments. 
No members of the city commission shall directly interfere with the conduct of any department, except at the express direction of the city commission. 
(Code 1994, § 2-33; Ord. No. 7812, 11-24-2009)  
Secs. 2-25—2-51. - Reserved.  
DIVISION 2. - PROCEDURE 
 
Sec. 2-52. - Meetings. 
(a)  Regular meetings. The regular meetings of the city commission shall ordinarily be held in the commission chambers of the city hall building on the second and fourth Tuesdays of each month at 7:00 p.m. 
(b)  Special meetings. Special meetings will be held only for a special purpose. Special meetings may be called by the mayor or the city manager, specifying the object and purpose of such meeting, which request shall be read at a meeting and entered into the minutes. 
(c)  Work sessions and study sessions. No agenda is required for a work or study session and no binding action may be taken during the work or study session. 
(d)  Adjournment. Regular or special meetings of the city commission may be adjourned for the completion of its business at such subsequent time and place as the city commission shall determine in its motion to adjourn. 
(e)  Cancellation or modification. The city commission may cancel or modify any ordinarily established meetings by motion and approval by a majority of a quorum at any regularly scheduled or special meeting. Notwithstanding the foregoing, the mayor (and, in the absence of the mayor, the mayor pro tem), after consulting with the city manager, shall be authorized to cancel a meeting and make a temporary change in a meeting date when such actions are reasonably necessary due to reasons of health, safety, or welfare, or the known inability to obtain a quorum. Appropriate notice of such cancellation or change in meeting date shall be provided to the public and commission members. 
(f)  Public comment. If public comment is allowed during the meeting, the citizen desiring to comment on matters of a general nature, not specific to an agenda item, shall provide his name and address for the purpose of putting both in the minutes of the meeting. Any public comment taken on specific agenda items shall require the citizen to state his name and address for the minutes. The mayor may limit the time of each citizen based upon the number of people wishing to speak and the amount of time available for the public comment portion of the meeting. 
(Code 1994, § 2-30(a); Ord. No. 7812, 11-24-2009)  
Sec. 2-53. - Agenda. 
(a)  Distribution. Prior to each regular and special meeting, the city will distribute an agenda to each city commission member and it will be made available to the public at that time. 
(b)  Setting agenda. The city manager shall be in charge of setting the agenda. 
(c)  Agenda items. The mayor or city staff member may have an item placed on the agenda. An item shall be added to the agenda by a city commission member provided they have a consensus of the city commission. Members of the public may not place an item on the agenda, but may have a city commission member sponsor such an item. 
(d)  Additions to agenda. Items may be added to or removed from the agenda at a regular meeting by motion approved by a majority of those city commission members present and voting. No items may be added to the agenda of a special meeting. 
(e)  Order of business. At the hour appointed for the meeting, the mayor shall call the meeting to order. Upon having a quorum present, the city commission shall proceed to business, which shall be conducted in the order set by the city commission. 
(f)  Consent agenda. By majority vote of the city commission, any item may be removed from the consent agenda and considered separately. 
(g)  Order of business, suspended or amended. By a majority vote of the city commission, the order of business may be amended to add or delete sections as appropriate or may be suspended in its entirety to consider other matters. Executive sessions may be held at any time in the order of business. 
(Code 1994, § 2-30(b); Ord. No. 7812, 11-24-2009)  
Sec. 2-54. - Motions. 
(a)  Second. All motions require a second before such motion may be considered. 
(b)  Debate. All motions are debatable unless otherwise noted in the section governing that motion. 
(c)  Motions. Only one main motion may be pending on the floor at any one time. It must be withdrawn or advanced to a vote before another motion is introduced. 
(d)  Substitute motion. Substitute motions are prohibited. Motions must be withdrawn or advanced before another motion is introduced. 
(e)  Motion to amend. A motion to amend is in order when the proposal is to change, add, or delete words from the main motion. If the motion is to amend a document before voting on its adoption, it is advisable to reduce the change to writing, but it is not required if all members of the city commission understand the amendment. A vote on an amendment is not a final vote on the underlying motion. To pass the underlying motion requires a vote. 
(f)  Motion to pass an ordinance. All ordinances of the city shall be considered at a public meeting of the city commission except as otherwise herein provided or when state law provides a different procedure for an ordinance for a specific purpose. Upon second consideration the mayor shall call the roll of yeas and nays which shall be entered in the minutes by the city clerk. No ordinance shall contain more than one subject, which shall be clearly expressed in its title, and no section of an ordinance shall be amended unless the amending ordinance contains the entire section as amended and the section amended shall be repealed. Consideration of ordinances cannot be passed on the date of introduction with exception of emergencies. The city commission shall determine and declare an emergency by a majority vote. 
(g)  Motion to refer. If the city commission deems it appropriate, it may refer an ordinance, resolution, contract, or other matter back to staff, committee, board, or other appropriate location for further review and consideration. Such motion may or may not contain a time certain for the item to be returned to the city commission. 
(h)  Motion to reconsider; prohibited. Motions to reconsider are prohibited. Any city commission member may make a new motion on a matter previously considered by the city. 
(i)  Motion to call the previous question. This motion is not debatable and, if passed by a majority of the city commission, calls for an immediate vote on the motion. This motion requires a vote. 
(j)  Motion to go into executive session. Upon formal motion made, seconded and carried, the city commission may recess, but not adjourn, open meetings for closed or executive meetings. Such motion shall be in compliance with K.S.A. 75-4319(a). Any motion to recess for a closed or executive meeting shall include a statement describing the subjects to be discussed during the closed or executive meeting, the justification for closing the meeting, and the time and place at which the open meeting shall resume. The complete motion shall be recorded in the minutes of the meeting and shall be maintained as a part of the permanent records of the city. Discussion during the closed or executive meeting shall be limited to those subjects stated in the motion. 
(k)  Motion to adjourn to a later date and time. If the city commission is unable to complete its agenda during the time allotted for the meeting, the meeting may be adjourned to a time and date certain to continue the regular or special meeting. The motion shall state the time, place, and date for the meeting to reconvene. If the motion is adopted, the meeting is adjourned to the specified time, place, and date. 
(l)  Motion to adjourn. At the conclusion of the agenda, a motion to adjourn is in order and requires a majority vote. 
(Code 1994, §§ 2-30(c), 2-34; Ord. No. 7812, 11-24-2009; Ord. No. 8018, § 1, 11-8-2016)  
Sec. 2-55. - Voting. 
(a)  Form and vote. All votes shall be by voice vote or in the alternative the mayor may request that a vote be by "show of hands." No vote shall be by secret ballot. 
(b)  Division. The mayor or any member may request a formal division of vote. At the discretion of the mayor, division may be by either a poll of each member of a show of hands. 
(c)  Duty to vote. Members of the city commission have a duty to vote unless such member declares a conflict of interest or other conflict that appears to make voting on an issue improper. Any member who declares a conflict of interest must state, for the purpose of its inclusion in the minutes, the reason for the conflict of interest and step down from the dais. This action does not result in a vote being recorded for the member declaring a conflict of interest. 
(d)  Votes; non-ordinance matters. Unless otherwise specifically required by law, the adoption or rejection of resolutions and other motions shall be by a majority of those present. Any member who abstains from voting for any reason other than set in subsection (c) of this section shall be counted as having voted against the motion. 
(e)  Recording. Upon final passage of a matter, the vote shall be recorded in the minutes. 
(f)  Recording; ordinary ordinance; commission city. The adoption of an ordinary ordinance requires affirmative votes of the commission. 
(g)  Recording; charter ordinance; commission city. The adoption of a charter ordinance requires affirmative votes of the commission. [e.g., This is a two-thirds vote, four members of a five member commission.] 
(h)  Recording; commission city. The mayor has a vote on all matters. The mayor does not have a second vote to break a tie. Appointments in commission cities are by motion, second, and a vote. 
(Code 1994, § 2-30(d); Ord. No. 7812, 11-24-2009)  
Sec. 2-56. - Procedural issues not covered to be decided by majority vote. 
For those matters not covered by this division or other rules promulgated hereunder, the procedure shall be as decided by a majority vote of the city commission. 
(Code 1994, § 2-30(e); Ord. No. 7812, 11-24-2009)  
Sec. 2-57. - Amendments. 
These rules may be amended after adoption by a subsequent ordinance amending specific rules as identified in the ordinance. Such ordinance amends the adopting ordinance. The rules may not be suspended by the city commission during any meeting. 
(Code 1994, § 2-30(e); Ord. No. 7812, 11-24-2009)  
Sec. 2-58. - Printing, publication of legal notices and advertisements; affidavit of publication. 
(a)  The official city newspaper and of any other newspaper, that shall print or publish for the city any legal notice or advertisement that is required by law or ordinance to be printed or published for a specified time, to file in the office of the city clerk an affidavit of the printer, foreman or principal clerk of such paper, or other person knowing the same, stating the number of times that such notice or advertisement has been printed in such newspaper, giving the dates thereof and attaching to such affidavit a copy of the notice or advertisement. It shall be the duty of the city clerk to file such affidavit and safely keep such affidavit among the records in the city clerk's office. Such affidavit shall be prima facie evidence of the publication and printing of such notice or advertisement in the manner and for the times stated in such affidavit. 
(b)  No person shall receive pay for the publishing or printing of any legal notice or advertisement, nor shall any bill for the printing or publishing of such legal notice or advertisement be audited or allowed, until the affidavit provided for in this section has been filed in the city clerk's office. 
(c)  Any person who shall, by direction or order of the city commission, print or publish any notice, order, citation, summons, ordinance, resolution, advertisement or other proceedings of the city commission required by law to be printed or published in any newspaper shall receive full compensation therefor, not to exceed the amount of compensation fixed by state law for such publications. 
(Code 1978, §§ 2-262, 2-263; Code 1994, § 2-4) 
State Law reference— Publication of ordinances, K.S.A. 12-3007; rates for newspaper notices, K.S.A. 28-137, 75-1018.  
Secs. 2-59—2-89. - Reserved.  
ARTICLE III. - OFFICERS AND EMPLOYEES  
DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 
 
Sec. 2-90. - Organizational structure of city; annual review. 
(a)  The affairs of the city shall be administered by the officers and employees of the designated administrative divisions as may be annually established by the city manager. The city commission shall annually review the administrative organization of the city concurrent with its adoption of the city budget and approve or disapprove such organizational structure. 
(b)  The city commission shall annually review the administrative organization of the city concurrent with the adoption of the city budget as prepared by the city manager. Upon approval of the budget, the city manager shall provide to all departments of the city an outline of the approved administrative organization of the city. 
(Code 1978, §§ 2-52, 2-55; Code 1994, § 2-1)  
Sec. 2-91. - Personnel policies and procedures. 
All personnel policies and procedures will be governed by the "City of Leavenworth Personnel Manual" on file in the office of the city clerk and the city human resources office. 
(Code 1994, § 82-1; Ord. No. 8089, § 1, 10-23-2018)  
Sec. 2-92. - Appointments. 
(a)  All officers and employees shall be appointed by the city manager, except as otherwise provided by state law or other city ordinances. All appointments shall be based solely on merit and fitness. Appointed officers shall include, but shall not be limited to, the city clerk, city attorney, city treasurer, municipal judge, police chief and city engineer. 
(b)  The city manager is authorized to act as, and to perform the duties of, any office for which such manager is qualified; and may appoint one person to perform the duties of more than one office or employee, provided that the duties of such office are not incompatible and such combined duties are not prohibited by law or other ordinances. 
(Code 1994, § 2-56; Code 1978, § 2-53) 
State Law reference— Authority of city manager to appoint and remove subordinate officers and employees, K.S.A. 12-1040.  
Sec. 2-93. - Classified service. 
The classified service of the city shall include all positions in the city service except for the following: 
(1)  Elected officials; 
(2)  The city manager, city attorney, municipal judge and public defender; 
(3)  Persons serving the city as independent contractors; 
(4)  Persons retained by the city as consultants; 
(5)  Temporary employees; or 
(6)  Part-time boards and commissions. 
(Code 1994, § 2-57; Code 1978, § 2-54; Ord. No. 8062, § 1, 10-24-2017)  
Sec. 2-94. - Officers' oath. 
All officers of the city, whether elected or appointed, either under the laws of the state or ordinances of the city, shall, before entering upon the duties of their respective offices, take and subscribe an oath or affirmation as follows: 
"I do solemnly swear (or affirm, as the case may be) that I will support the Constitution of the United States and the Constitution of the State of Kansas and faithfully discharge the duties of ___________(here enter name of office). So help me God." 
(Code 1978, § 2-63; Code 1994, § 2-58) 
State Law reference— Form of oath, K.S.A. 54-106; when oath of municipal employees is required, K.S.A. 75-4308.  
Sec. 2-95. - Appeal of adverse administrative rulings. 
Except to the extent a right of appeal is otherwise set forth in this Code (in which case any appeal shall be undertaken in accordance with the procedures set forth therein), any administrative ruling, order or decision made by any officer or employee of the city, including, but not limited to, denial or revocation of permits and licenses, which adversely affect any person, may be appealed by such person to the city commission in writing within ten days following the adverse ruling, order or decision. A hearing shall be scheduled by the city commission within ten days following the written appeal. The decision of the city commission on such appeal shall be final and conclusive. 
(Code 1978, § 2-1; Code 1994, § 2-2)  
Sec. 2-96. - Bonds. 
(a)  When required; amount. The city manager and such officers as the city commission may require shall each, before entering upon the duties of their respective offices, give a good and sufficient surety company bond to the city, approved by the city commission, in the amount specified in this section or as shall be required by the city commission, conditioned upon the officer's faithful performance and faithful discharge of the officer's respective duties. The bond for each commissioner shall be $10,000.00. The bond for the city treasurer shall be $50,000.00. The bond for the city manager shall be $50,000.00. The bond for all other employees of the city will be covered by a faithful performance blanket position bond in the amount of $5,000.00. 
(b)  To be executed by surety company. All bonds provided for in this division shall be signed and executed by some responsible surety company lawfully doing business in the state; no bond signed and executed by any individual as surety will be accepted or approved. 
(c)  Approval. All bonds provided for in this division shall be submitted to and approved by the city attorney, and such bonds shall also be approved by the city commission. The mayor shall endorse the approval of all official bonds by the board. The bonds of the mayor and commissioners shall be approved by the judge of the county district court and shall also be approved by the city attorney and city commission. 
(d)  Cost to be borne by city. On all bonds of officers, employees and appointees of the city for the faithful discharge of their duties, which are or may be required either by the laws of the state or the ordinances of the city, the premium or cost of such bonds shall be borne by the city. 
(Code 1978, §§ 2-64—2-68; Code 1994, § 2-90) 
State Law reference— Official corporate surety bonds, K.S.A. 78-111; treasurer's bond, K.S.A. 13-526a.  
Secs. 2-97—2-120. - Reserved.  
DIVISION 2. - CITY MANAGER[2] 

Footnotes: 
--- (2) --- 
State Law reference— City manager plan, K.S.A. 12-1039. 
 
Sec. 2-121. - Appointment; term. 
The administration of the city's business shall be in the hands of the city manager, who shall be appointed by the city commission and shall hold office at the pleasure of the city commission. 
(Code 1978, § 2-37; Code 1994, § 2-71) 
State Law reference— Appointment of city manager, K.S.A. 12-1040.  
Sec. 2-122. - Qualifications. 
The city manager shall be chosen solely on the basis of administrative ability. 
(Code 1978, § 2-38; Code 1994, § 2-72)  
Sec. 2-123. - Duties and functions. 
(a)  The city manager shall be responsible for the administration of all the affairs of the city; shall see that all laws and ordinances are enforced; and shall appoint and remove all heads of departments and all subordinate officers and employees of the city. 
(b)  The city manager shall be responsible for the discipline of all appointive officers, and may, without notice, cause the affairs of any department or the conduct of any officer or employee to be examined; shall prepare and submit the annual budget to the city commission and keep the city commission fully advised as to the financial conditions and needs of the city; shall make recommendations to the city commission on all matters concerning the welfare of the city, and shall have a seat, but no vote, in all of the public meetings of the city commission. 
(Code 1978, § 2-39; Code 1994, § 2-73) 
State Law reference— Powers of city manager, K.S.A. 12-1040.  
Sec. 2-124. - Preparation of wage and employee classification schedule; payrolls. 
The city manager shall prepare a wage schedule and employee classification which shall be presented to the city commission. The city manager shall, at the time of preparing the annual budget, incorporate the established wage schedule into the budget so as to provide compensation for the employees of each department for the budget year. The city manager shall, every other week or once each month, cause to be prepared payrolls in accordance with the current budget and the established wage schedule. 
(Code 1978, § 2-40; Code 1994, §§ 2-26, 2-74; Ord. No. 7812, 11-24-2009; Ord. No. 7987, § 1, 12-8-2015; Ord. No. 7992, § 1, 5-10-2016)  
Secs. 2-125—2-148. - Reserved.  
ARTICLE IV. - BOARDS, COMMISSIONS, COMMITTEES AND SIMILAR BODIES  
DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 
 
Sec. 2-149. - Policy for declaring vacancy on advisory boards; appointment of successor. 
(a)  Upon any member of an advisory board subject to appointment by the city commission failing to attend three regular meetings within any one calendar year, the chairperson of the board shall notify the mayor by delivering to the city clerk in writing the title of the board, the name of the individual, and the dates of the meetings missed. The city clerk shall cause the matter to be placed on the agenda for consideration of the city commission at the next regular meeting following the seven-day notice period as hereinafter provided. 
(b)  The city clerk shall, upon receipt of the written notice from the chairperson of the board under this section, notify the individual of the date and time of the meeting at which such matter shall be considered by the city commission. 
(c)  At the time of consideration of a vacancy under this section, the mayor, by and with the consent of the city commission, may declare a vacancy existing and proceed to appoint a successor for the remaining term of the vacant position. By majority vote, the city commission may continue the consideration of the vacancy or the appointment of a successor. 
(Code 1978, § 2-80; Code 1994, § 2-111)  
Sec. 2-150. - Cable television advisory committee. 
The city commission shall act as the cable television advisory committee. The mission of the cable television advisory committee shall be to act in accordance with the guidelines outlined in the city governmental access channel capacity guidelines for utilization. Action required of the cable television advisory committee shall be conducted by the city commission during the regular city commission meetings. 
(Code 1994, §§ 2-178—2-180; Ord. No. 7865, § 1, 2-8-2011)  
Secs. 2-151—2-168. - Reserved.  
DIVISION 2. - AIRPORT ADVISORY BOARD 
 
Sec. 2-169. - Board's purpose. 
The city has created an airport advisory board to make reports and recommendations to the city commission relating to the efficient and effective operation of the airfield as follows: 
(1)  To make recommendations to the city commission regarding airport facility maintenance. 
(2)  To make recommendations regarding airport operations. 
(3)  To make recommendations regarding capital improvement need, including, but not limited to, facilities such as the apron, fuel, facilities, hangers, office space and maintenance facilities. 
(4)  To make recommendations pertaining to signage. 
(5)  To review the current fixed-base operator contract and services being provided and make recommendations pertaining to the current and future contracts. 
(6)  To explore the possibility of Federal Aviation Administration funding assistance for airport improvement. 
(Code 1994, § 2-141; Ord. No. 7635, § 1, 12-21-2004)  
Sec. 2-170. - Composition; appointment. 
The airport advisory board shall consist of one member who shall be recommended by the installation commander at Fort Leavenworth and appointed by the mayor by and with the consent of the commissioner who shall serve as a non-voting liaison from the fort and seven members who shall be appointed by the mayor by and with the consent of the commission who shall be voting members. The city manager and public works director shall be support staff to the board. The assistant city manager shall attend all board meetings and shall keep and publish minutes of the board meetings. 
(Code 1994, § 2-142; Ord. No. 7635, § 2, 12-21-2004)  
Sec. 2-171. - Terms of service. 
In appointing the seven voting members of the airport advisory board, the mayor shall designate three to serve two-year terms and four to serve three-year terms. Terms of all subsequent appointees shall be for three years. 
(Code 1994, § 2-143; Ord. No. 7635, § 3, 12-21-2004)  
Sec. 2-172. - Compensation. 
The members of the airport advisory board shall serve without pay. 
(Code 1994, § 2-144; Ord. No. 7635, § 4, 12-21-2004)  
Sec. 2-173. - Removal of members. 
Each member of the airport advisory board shall be removable for cause by the recorded vote of a majority of the voting members of the city commission after a public hearing. Any member of the board failing to attend four successive regular meetings without cause, acceptable and approved by the remaining board members, shall be thereby automatically removed from the board and the vacancy shall be appointed by the mayor for the balance of the term. 
(Code 1994, § 2-145; Ord. No. 7635, § 5, 12-21-2004)  
Sec. 2-174. - Organization. 
The mayor shall appoint the initial chairperson of the board, who shall serve in that capacity for a period of one year. Thereafter, the committee shall annually elect one of its members to act as chairperson. The board may adopt the rule and bylaws of its meetings. 
(Code 1994, § 2-146; Ord. No. 7635, § 6, 12-21-2004)  
Sec. 2-175. - Meeting frequency. 
The board shall meet as needed at a time and place which is mutually agreeable to the members. 
(Code 1994, § 2-147; Ord. No. 7635, § 7, 12-21-2004)  
Secs. 2-176—2-203. - Reserved.  
DIVISION 3. - SISTER CITY ADVISORY BOARD 
 
Sec. 2-204. - Established; membership; terms; compensation. 
(a)  The city has created and established a board of the city to be known as the sister city advisory board (hereafter "board"), the members of which shall be appointed by the mayor with the consent of the city commission and shall consist of no more than 11 members. Four of the 11 members will be standing positions from the following organizations: Leavenworth Area Development, Convention and Visitors Bureau, Education Community, and Fort Leavenworth Community. Of the remaining seven membership slots, two shall be appointed for a term to expire December 31, 2001, two shall be appointed for a term to expire December 31, 2002, and three shall be appointed for a term to expire December 31, 2003. Thereafter, at the expiration of the term of an appointed member, the member or his successor, may be appointed for a term of three years. 
(b)  Any vacancies in the membership of the board will be filled by the appointment of a member for the unexpired term of a member whose office shall be vacant. It is not the intent of this section to limit the number of terms a member may serve. 
(c)  All members of the board shall serve without compensation. 
(Code 1994, § 2-185.11; Ord. No. 7422, § 1, 2-8-2000)  
Sec. 2-205. - Purpose; duties. 
The board shall be an advisory board to the city commission on matters relating to the city's implementation of sister city programs. The purpose and duties of the board shall be as follows: 
(1)  To seek, support, coordinate, foster and develop sister city programs both cultural and governmental in nature. Cultural considerations may include, but not be limited to, charitable, educational, literary and historical exchanges. Governmental considerations may include, but not be limited to, economic development, scientific, and ceremonial exchanges; 
(2)  To appoint such project subcommittees, as needed, to fulfill the obligations of the board, or any other such group, to facilitate the objectives of the board. A friends organization shall be established for each sister city. The chairperson of each friends organization, or his designee, shall submit a report of their activities to the sister city advisory board at each regular meeting; and 
(3)  To raise and receive moneys and accept any gift or donation to the sister city exchange program and administer the same. 
(Code 1994, § 2-185.12; Ord. No. 7442, § 1, 2-8-2000)  
Sec. 2-206. - Organization; meetings. 
At the first meeting of the board and annually thereafter, it shall organize by the designation of one of its members to act as chairperson and another to act as secretary. The board shall adopt the rules and bylaws of its meetings. The chairperson shall preside at all meetings and the secretary shall keep a record of the proceedings of this board, which record shall be available for inspection as are other municipal records. 
(Code 1994, § 2-185.13; Ord. No. 7442, § 2, 2-8-2000)  
Secs. 2-207—2-235. - Reserved.  
DIVISION 4. - YOUTH ADVISORY COMMISSION 
 
Sec. 2-236. - Youth advisory commission; established. 
The city has created a youth advisory commission consisting of 16 members, all of whom shall live in the city and be between the ages of 12 and 19 years. The members of the youth advisory commission shall be appointed by the mayor with the consent of the city commission. 
(Code 1994, § 2-185.26; Ord. No. 7526, § 1, 4-23-2002; Ord. No. 7566, § 1, 5-27-2003; Ord. No. 7685, § 1, 1-24-2006)  
Sec. 2-237. - Membership. 
The commission shall be comprised of a maximum of 16 students with at least one member from each of the following schools: Immaculata High School, Leavenworth High School, Patton Junior High School, West Middle School, Warren Middle School, Xavier School, St. Paul Lutheran School and one home-school representative. Commission members will be selected via an open application process. The application shall be submitted to the city manager's office. 
(Code 1994, § 2-185.27; Ord. No. 7526, § 2, 4-23-2002; Ord. No. 7566, § 2, 5-27-2003; Ord. No. 7685, § 2, 1-24-2006)  
Sec. 2-238. - Term of office. 
Each youth advisory commissioner will be appointed to office for a term not to exceed six years or until age limitation is achieved. 
(Code 1994, § 2-185.28; Ord. No. 7526, § 3, 4-23-2002; Ord. No. 7566, § 3, 5-27-2003; Ord. No. 7685, § 3, 1-24-2006)  
Sec. 2-239. - Purpose; duties. 
The commission shall be an advisory body to the city commission on matters involving youth. The purpose and duties of the commission shall be as follows: 
(1)  Serve as a liaison between the city commission and the youth of the community on issues affecting youth; 
(2)  Encourage the positive growth and development of youth; 
(3)  Serve as a vehicle to familiarize youth with the city government; 
(4)  Assist in minimizing community problems relating to youth; 
(5)  Give advice and assistance on matters concerning the needs of youth; 
(6)  Develop and maintain bylaws, rules and procedures for the conduct of the commission's activities; 
(7)  The city commission or city manager will assign, and prioritize as necessary, projects for discussion and reporting. The commission may generate its own discussion projects. The city commission will use the commission as a formal voice of youth on various items concerning youth in the city. 
(Code 1994, § 2-185.29; Ord. No. 7526, § 4, 4-23-2002; Ord. No. 7566, § 4, 5-27-2003; Ord. No. 7685, § 4, 1-24-2006)  
Sec. 2-240. - Meetings; organization. 
(a)  The members of the youth advisory commission shall meet at such time and place as may be fixed in the commission's bylaws, but not less than monthly. The commission shall elect one member as chairperson, one member as vice-chairperson, and one member as secretary who shall serve for one-year terms of office commencing May 1 of each year. A member shall be eligible for reelection to any of these offices as long as he remains on the commission. 
(b)  Special meetings may be called at any time by the chairperson or in the chairperson's absence, by the vice-chairperson. A simple majority of the members shall constitute a quorum. A vote of the simple majority of the quorum shall be required for any action taken by the commission. All meetings of the commission shall be open to the public. 
(Code 1994, § 2-185.30; Ord. No. 7526, § 5, 4-23-2002; Ord. No. 7566, § 5, 5-27-2003; Ord. No. 7685, § 5, 1-24-2006)  
Sec. 2-241. - Reports. 
An informal progress report shall be given to the city commission not less than two times per year. Additional reports shall be submitted as requested by either the city manager or the city commission. 
(Code 1994, § 2-185.31; Ord. No. 7526, § 6, 4-23-2002; Ord. No. 7566, § 6, 5-27-2003; Ord. No. 7685, § 6, 1-24-2006)  
Secs. 2-242—2-260. - Reserved.  
DIVISION 5. - DEER MANAGEMENT ADVISORY COMMITTEE 
 
Sec. 2-261. - Purpose. 
The city has created a deer management advisory committee to make reports and recommendations to the city commission on all matters relating to the efficient and effective operation of the deer management program as follows: 
(1)  To make recommendations to the city commission regarding changes needed to the deer management ordinance. Specifically, advise the city commission on recommended penalties to impose for various infractions of the deer management ordinance by hunters. 
(2)  To perform an analysis at the end of each archery season and make a report concerning the successes, costs and corrections needed for the following season. 
(3)  Advise the assistant city manager on preparation for each new season and provide advice and assistance during deer hunter testing, training and qualification. 
(Code 1994, § 2-185.41; Ord. No. 7636, § 1, 12-21-2004)  
Sec. 2-262. - Composition; appointment. 
The deer management advisory committee shall consist of seven city residents, who shall be appointed by the mayor, by and with the consent of the commission. The assistant city manager shall facilitate all meetings and shall keep and publish minutes of the meetings. The police chief shall appoint one representative from the police department and one representative from animal control to advise and assist the committee. 
(Code 1994, § 2-185.42; Ord. No. 7636, § 2, 12-21-2004)  
Sec. 2-263. - Terms of service. 
In appointing the seven voting members of the deer management advisory committee, the mayor shall designate three to serve two-year terms and four to serve three-year terms. Terms of all subsequent appointees shall be for three years. 
(Code 1994, § 2-185.43; Ord. No. 7636, § 3, 12-21-2004)  
Sec. 2-264. - Compensation. 
The members of the deer management advisory committee shall serve without pay. 
(Code 1994, § 2-185.44; Ord. No. 7636, § 4, 12-21-2004)  
Sec. 2-265. - Removal of members. 
Each member of the deer management advisory committee shall be removable for cause by the recorded vote of a majority of the members of the city commission after a public hearing. Any member of the committee failing to attend four successive regular meetings without cause, acceptable and approved by the remaining committee members, shall be thereby automatically removed from the committee and the vacancy shall be re-appointed by the mayor. 
(Code 1994, § 2-185.45; Ord. No. 7636, § 5, 12-21-2004)  
Sec. 2-266. - Organization. 
The mayor shall appoint the initial chairperson of the deer management advisory committee, who shall serve in this capacity for a period of one year. Thereafter, the committee shall annually elect one of its members to act as chairperson. 
(Code 1994, § 2-185.46; Ord. No. 7636, § 6, 12-21-2004)  
Sec. 2-267. - Meeting frequency. 
The deer management advisory committee shall meet as often as needed to facilitate the effective management of the deer management program, but at least quarterly at a time and place which is mutually agreeable to the members. 
(Code 1994, § 2-185.47; Ord. No. 7636, § 7, 12-21-2004)  
Secs. 2-268—2-297. - Reserved.  
DIVISION 6. - SIDEWALK ADVISORY BOARD 
 
Sec. 2-298. - Board; purpose. 
The city has created a sidewalk advisory board to make reports and recommendations to the city commission on all matters relating to the location, construction and maintenance of sidewalks throughout the city. The board shall annually provide recommendations to the city commission for a sidewalk work plan and a report on board activities. 
(Code 1994, § 2-185.48; Ord. No. 7763, § 1, 3-4-2008)  
Sec. 2-299. - Composition; appointment; meetings. 
(a)  The sidewalk advisory board should consist of seven city residents to include one member with experience as a general contractor, one member with experience as a civil engineer or architect, and one USD 453 representative. 
(b)  Members shall be appointed by the mayor, by and with the consent of the city commission. The director of public works shall facilitate all meetings and shall keep and publish minutes of the meetings. 
(Code 1994, § 2-185.49; Ord. No. 7763, § 2, 3-4-2008)  
Sec. 2-300. - Term of service. 
In appointing the seven voting members of the sidewalk advisory board, the mayor shall designate four to serve two-year terms and three to serve three-year terms. Terms of all subsequent appointees shall be for three years. 
(Code 1994, § 2-185.50; Ord. No. 7763, § 3, 3-4-2008)  
Sec. 2-301. - Compensation. 
The members of the sidewalk advisory board shall serve without pay. 
(Code 1994, § 2-185.51; Ord. No. 7763, § 4, 3-4-2008)  
Sec. 2-302. - Removal of members. 
Each member of the sidewalk advisory board shall be removable for cause by the recorded vote of a majority of the members of the city commission. Any member of the board failing to attend four successive regular meetings without cause, acceptable and approved by the remaining board members, shall be thereby automatically removed from the board and the vacancy shall be re-appointed by the mayor. 
(Code 1994, § 2-185.52; Ord. No. 7763, § 5, 3-4-2008)  
Sec. 2-303. - Organization. 
The mayor shall appoint the initial chairperson of the sidewalk advisory board, who shall serve in this capacity for a period of one year. Thereafter, the committee shall annually elect one of its members to act as chairperson. 
(Code 1994, § 2-185.53; Ord. No. 7763, § 6, 3-4-2008)  
Sec. 2-304. - Meeting frequency. 
The sidewalk advisory board shall meet as often as needed to facilitate the effective management of the sidewalk program, but at least quarterly at a time and place which is mutually agreeable to the members. 
(Code 1994, § 2-185.54; Ord. No. 7763, § 7, 3-4-2008)  
Secs. 2-305—2-326. - Reserved.  
ARTICLE V. - MUNICIPAL COURT[3] 

Footnotes: 
--- (3) --- 
State Law reference— Municipal courts generally, K.S.A. 12-4101 et seq. 
 
Sec. 2-327. - Adoption of state procedure for municipal courts. 
The city adopts by reference the provisions of the Kansas Code of Procedure for Municipal Courts (K.S.A. 12-4101 et seq.), which shall be in full force and effect in the city as if fully set forth in this article. 
(Code 1978, § 9-1; Code 1994, § 34-1)  
Sec. 2-328. - Sessions. 
Municipal court shall be held at such time and place as determined by the city commission from time to time by resolution, or such other time as the judge shall designate. 
(Code 1978, § 9-2; Code 1994, § 34-2)  
Sec. 2-329. - Municipal court administrative fees. 
(a)  The municipal court is authorized to levy municipal court administrative fees as provided by Charter Ordinance No. 52, dated June 28, 2011. Municipal court administrative fees are as provided in the schedule approved from time to time by the court and available in the office of the court clerk. 
(b)  The city prosecutor and municipal court judge shall have the discretion of whether to impose the municipal court administrative fee for cases in which the charges are dismissed. 
(Code 1994, § 34-3; Ord. No. 7888, §§ 1, 2, 11-8-2011)  
Secs. 2-330—2-346. - Reserved.  
ARTICLE VI. - FINANCE AND TAXATION  
DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 
 
Secs. 2-347—2-365. - Reserved.  
DIVISION 2. - INVESTMENT OF TEMPORARILY IDLE FUNDS[4] 

Footnotes: 
--- (4) --- 
State Law reference— Investment of public moneys, K.S.A. 12-1675. 
 
Sec. 2-366. - Authority to invest. 
(a)  The city manager, city clerk and city treasurer, acting jointly, are hereby authorized and directed to arrange for the investment of temporarily idle funds of the city in either, or all, of the following: 
(1)  Temporary notes or no-fund warrants issued by the city commission; 
(2)  Time deposit, open accounts or certificates of deposit: 
a.  In commercial banks or trust companies which have offices located in the city; 
b.  If the office of no commercial bank or trust company is located in the city, then in commercial banks or trust companies which have offices in the county; or 
c.  If such appropriate eligible commercial banks or trust companies cannot or will not make deposits available to the investing governmental unit at interest rates equal to or greater than the average yield before taxes received on 91-day United States Treasury Bills as determined by the federal reserve banks as fiscal agents of the United States, at its most recent public offering of such bills prior to the inception of such deposit contract, then in commercial banks or trust companies which have offices in the counties of the state adjacent to the county; 
(3)  In time certificates of deposit: 
a.  With state or federally chartered savings and loan associations or federally chartered savings banks which have offices located in the city; 
b.  If the office of no state or federally chartered savings and loan association or federally chartered savings bank is located in the city, then with state or federally chartered savings and loan associations or federally chartered savings banks which have offices in the county; or 
c.  If such appropriate eligible state or federally chartered savings and loan associations or federally chartered savings banks cannot or will not make such deposits available to the investing government unit at interest rates equal to or greater than the average yield before taxes received on 91-day United States Treasury Bills, as determined by the federal reserve banks as fiscal agents of the United States, at its most recent public offering of such bills prior to the inception of such deposit contract, then with state or federally chartered savings and loan associations or federally chartered savings banks which have offices in the counties of the state adjacent to the county; 
(4)  Repurchase agreements with: 
a.  Commercial banks, trust companies, state or federally chartered savings and loan associations or federally chartered savings banks which have offices located in the city for direct obligations of, or obligations that are ensured as to principal and interest by, the United States Government or any agency thereof; or 
b.  No repurchase agreements with commercial banks, trust companies, etc. in the city. 
1.  If the office of no commercial bank, trust company, state or federally chartered savings and loan association or federally chartered savings bank is located in the city; 
2.  If no commercial bank, trust company, state or federally chartered savings and loan association or federally chartered savings bank having an office located in the city is willing to enter into such an agreement with the city at an interest rate equal to or higher than a rate equal to two percentage points below the average yield before taxes received on 91-day United States Treasury Bills, as determined by the federal reserve banks as fiscal agents of the United States, at its most recent offering of such bills prior to the inception of such contract, then such repurchase agreements may be entered into with commercial banks, trust companies, state or federally chartered savings and loan associations or federally chartered savings banks which have offices in the county; or 
c.  If no bank, trust company, state or federally chartered savings and loan association or federally chartered savings bank which has its office in the county is willing to enter into such an agreement with the investing governmental unit at an interest rate equal to or higher than a rate equal to two percentage points below the average yield before taxes received on 91-day United States Treasury Bills, as determined by the federal reserve banks as fiscal agents of the United States, at its most recent offering of such bills prior to the inception of such contract, then such repurchase agreements may be entered into with commercial banks, trust companies, state or federally chartered savings and loan associations or federally chartered savings banks which have offices in the state; or 
(5)  United States Treasury Bills or notes with maturities as the city commission shall determine, but not exceeding six months. 
(b)  The investment authorized in subsection (a)(5) of this section shall be utilized only if the appropriate eligible commercial banks or trust companies which have offices located in the city or in the county if no such bank or trust company has an office which is located within the city, or the appropriate eligible state or federally chartered savings and loan associations or federally chartered savings banks which have offices located in the city or in the county if no such state or federally chartered savings and loan association or federally chartered savings bank has an office which is located within the city, cannot or will not make the investments authorized in subsection (a)(2) or (3) of this section available to the investing governmental unit at interest rates equal to or greater than the average yield before taxes received on 91-day United States Treasury Bills, as determined by the federal reserve banks as fiscal agents of the United States, at its most recent public offering of such bills prior to the inception of such deposit contract. 
(c)  In selecting a depository pursuant to subsection (a)(2) or (3) of this section, if a commercial bank, trust company, state or federally chartered savings and loan association or federally chartered savings bank has an office located in the city and such financial institution will make such deposits available to the city at interest rates equal to or greater than the average yield before taxes received on 91-day United States Treasury Bills, as determined by the federal reserve banks as fiscal agents of the United States, at its most recent public offering of such bills prior to the inception of such deposit contract, and such financial institution otherwise qualifies for such deposit, the city shall select one or more of such financial institutions for the deposit of funds pursuant to this section. If no such financial institution qualifies for such deposits, the city shall select for such deposits one or more commercial banks, trust companies, state or federally chartered savings and loan associations or federally chartered savings banks which have offices in the county which will make such deposits available to the investing governmental unit at interest rates equal to or greater than the average yield before taxes received on 91-day United States Treasury Bills, as determined by the federal reserve banks as fiscal agents of the United States, at its most recent public offering of such bills prior to the inception of such deposit contract, and which otherwise qualify for such deposits. If no such financial institution qualifies for such deposits, the city may select for such deposits one or more commercial banks, trust companies, state or federally chartered savings and loan associations or federally chartered savings banks which have offices in counties of the state adjacent to the county. 
(d)  The provisions of this section shall not apply to any funds of the city, the investment of which is expressly authorized or limited or prohibited by state law. 
(Code 1978, § 2-226; Code 1994, § 2-236)  
Sec. 2-367. - Interest, earnings. 
The interest or earnings of investments made pursuant to this division shall be used, insofar as possible, to relieve the ad valorem tax levies of the city. 
(Code 1978, § 2-227; Code 1994, § 2-237)  
Sec. 2-368. - Sale or transfer. 
If, in order to maintain sufficient moneys on demand in any fund from which investments under this division have been made, it becomes necessary to transfer or sell any securities of such funds, any two or more officers specified in section 2-366 may transfer the securities to any other fund in which there are temporarily idle moneys, or shall sell such securities, and for such purpose they shall have authority to make any necessary written directions, endorsements or assignments for and on behalf of the city. Any such transfers or sales shall be reported in writing to the city commission at its next regular meeting. 
(Code 1978, § 2-228; Code 1994, § 2-238)  
Sec. 2-369. - Custody and safekeeping. 
Securities purchased pursuant to this division is under the joint care of the city manager, city clerk and city treasurer, and shall be held in the custody of a state or national bank or trust company or shall be kept by such officers in a safety deposit box of the city in a bank or trust company. Securities in original or receipt form held in the custody of a bank or trust company shall be held in the name of the city, and their redemption, transfer or withdrawal shall be permitted only upon the written instruction of at least two city officers. Securities not held in the custody of a bank or trust company shall be personally deposited by such officers in a safety deposit box in the name of the city in a bank or trust company, access to which shall be permitted only in the personal presence and under the signature of at least two such officers. 
(Code 1978, § 2-229; Code 1994, § 2-239)  
Sec. 2-370. - Quarterly report. 
Upon request, the city manager shall cause to be prepared reports and information as requested by the city commission. 
(Code 1978, § 2-230; Code 1994, § 2-240)  
Secs. 2-371—2-398. - Reserved.  
DIVISION 3. - MUNICIPAL EQUIPMENT RESERVE FUND[5] 

Footnotes: 
--- (5) --- 
State Law reference— Municipal equipment reserve fund, K.S.A. 12-1,117. 
 
Sec. 2-399. - Established. 
In accordance with the provisions of K.S.A. 12-1,117, the city has established a municipal equipment reserve fund to finance the acquisition of equipment. 
(Code 1978, § 2-271; Code 1994, § 2-271)  
Sec. 2-400. - Equipment described. 
For the purposes of this division, equipment shall include machinery, vehicles and any other equipment or personal property, including, but not limited to, computer hardware and software, which the city is authorized to purchase for municipal purposes. 
(Code 1978, § 2-272; Code 1994, § 2-272)  
Sec. 2-401. - Purpose and intent. 
It is the policy objective of the city that such equipment reserve fund shall be used as a financing mechanism to secure the planned and orderly acquisition and replacement of equipment necessary for the efficient and effective operation of the city. It is the intent of the city commission to annually approve the budgeting of current revenues sufficient to finance the acquisition of new equipment needed in the following year and finance needed future replacements and acquisitions by setting aside a reserve account. 
(Code 1978, § 2-273; Code 1994, § 2-273)  
Sec. 2-402. - Equipment acquisition program. 
The city manager shall annually submit, at the same time the proposed annual budget is submitted, a proposed equipment acquisition program for each of the following three years. The proposed budget shall include an amount sufficient to finance proposed equipment acquisitions for the following year plus an amount to be reserved as set forth in the annually revised and extended equipment acquisition program. 
(Code 1978, § 2-274; Code 1994, § 2-274)  
Sec. 2-403. - Budget reporting requirements. 
Moneys credited to the equipment reserve fund from annually budgeted transfers shall not thereafter be subject to the provisions of K.S.A. 79-2925—79-2937, inclusive, and amendments thereto; however, in preparing the budgets of the city, the amounts credited to and the amount on hand in such equipment reserve fund and the amount expended therefrom shall be shown thereon for the information of the taxpayers of the city. 
(Code 1978, § 2-275; Code 1994, § 2-275)  
Sec. 2-404. - Investment of moneys in fund. 
Moneys in the equipment reserve fund may be invested in accordance with provisions of K.S.A. 10-131, and amendments thereto, with interest thereon credited to such fund. 
(Code 1978, § 2-276; Code 1994, § 2-276)  
Sec. 2-405. - Transfer of moneys not needed for fund purposes. 
If the city commission determines that money which has been credited to the equipment reserve fund, or any part thereof, is not needed for the purposes for which so budgeted or transferred, the city commission may transfer, by adoption of a resolution, such amount not needed to the fund from which it came, and such transfer and expenditure thereof shall be subject to the budget requirement provisions of K.S.A. 79-2925—79-2937, inclusive, and amendments thereto. 
(Code 1978, § 2-277; Code 1994, § 2-277)  
Secs. 2-406—2-423. - Reserved.  
DIVISION 4. - CAPITAL IMPROVEMENTS FUND[6] 

Footnotes: 
--- (6) --- 
State Law reference— Capital improvements fund authorized, K.S.A. 12-1,118. 
 
Sec. 2-424. - Disbursements from and reimbursements to fund; purposes. 
Disbursements may be made from the capital improvements fund for engineering and other advance public improvements plans and studies, and reimbursements may be made to the fund from bond proceeds, special assessments, or state or federal aid available for the completed project. 
(Code 1978, § 2-287; Code 1994, § 2-292)  
Sec. 2-425. - Budget requirements. 
No moneys shall be credited to the capital improvements fund except as may be budgeted annually or transferred by the annual budget from other funds. In making the budget, the amounts credited to and the amount on hand in such special fund and the amount expended therefrom shall be shown thereon for the information of the taxpayers of the city, although such funds are not subject to the provisions of K.S.A. 79-2925—79-2937, inclusive, and amendments thereto. 
(Code 1978, § 2-288; Code 1994, § 2-293)  
Sec. 2-426. - Investment of moneys in fund. 
Moneys in the capital improvements fund may be invested in accordance with the provisions of K.S.A. 10-131, and amendments thereto, with interest thereon credited to such fund. 
(Code 1978, § 2-289; Code 1994, § 2-294)  
Sec. 2-427. - Capital improvements program. 
The city manager shall annually submit, at the same time the proposed annual budget is submitted, a proposed capital improvements program for each of the following three years. The proposed program shall include an amount sufficient to finance proposed capital improvements for the following year. 
(Code 1978, § 2-290; Code 1994, § 2-295)  
Sec. 2-428. - Transfer of moneys not needed for fund purposes. 
If the city commission determines that money which has been transferred to the capital improvements fund, or any part thereof, is not needed for the purposes for which so transferred, the city commission, by adoption of a resolution, may transfer such amounts not needed to the general or other fund from which it was derived, and such transfer and expenditure thereof shall be subject to the budget requirement provisions of K.S.A. 79-2925—79-2937, inclusive, and amendments thereto. 
(Code 1978, § 2-291; Code 1994, § 2-296)  
Sec. 2-429. - Requirement regarding tax levy for use of fund. 
Any general property tax specifically levied for the use of the capital improvements fund shall be authorized by ordinance, adopted in accordance with state law. 
(Code 1978, § 2-292; Code 1994, § 2-297)  
Secs. 2-430—2-456. - Reserved.  
ARTICLE VII. - CITY CUSTODIAL PROPERTY AND ACCESS RIGHTS  
DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 
 
Sec. 2-457. - Governmental access channel. 
The "Leavenworth Governmental Access Channel Capacity Guidelines for Utilization" is adopted and incorporated as fully as if set forth at length herein and the provisions therein shall be controlling within the area of jurisdiction of the city. There shall be one copy of the guidelines marked and stamped, "Official Copy as Incorporated by Ordinance No. 7740, to which shall be attached a copy of the incorporation ordinance filed with the city clerk to be opened to inspection and available to the public at all reasonable business hours." 
(Code 1994, §§ 104-26, 104-27; Ord. No. 7421, 9-14-1999; Ord. No. 7523, 4-9-2002; Ord. No. 7740, 9-11-2007)  
Secs. 2-458—2-482. - Reserved.  
DIVISION 2. - PROPERTY IN POLICE CUSTODY 
 
Sec. 2-483. - Determination of abandoned property; authority to dispose. 
Any personal property recovered by the police department in the course of its authorized duties and activities, or property abandoned within the city and held by the police department, shall be deemed abandoned property and shall be subject to sale or other disposition if held by the city for more than 30 days and no claim to the property is made. This chapter shall not apply to abandoned vehicles nor property seized pursuant to the Kansas Standard Asset Seizure and Forfeiture Act, K.S.A. 60-4101 et seq. 
(Code 1994, § 2-400; Ord. No. 7868, 3-8-2011)  
Sec. 2-484. - Auctions; disposition of property. 
(a)  The police department is authorized to sell abandoned property by auction, except as set forth in sections 2-483 and 2-485. 
(b)  If an auction is utilized to dispose of abandoned property, an inventory listing all property to be disposed of shall be maintained on file in the police department. 
(c)  The police department also shall have the authority to donate abandoned property to another governmental entity or to a local social service agency. 
(Code 1994, § 2-401; Ord. No. 7868, 3-8-2011)  
Sec. 2-485. - Exempt property. 
The following classes of property are exempt from the provisions of section 2-484. When such property is no longer needed as evidence and is otherwise available for disposition, it shall be dealt with in the following manner:
