(9)  Refuses to permit any duly authorized police officer or city health officer to inspect the records of the operations of the licensee; 
(10)  Fails to comply with all applicable laws and regulatory provisions herein. 
(c)  Upon suspension or revocation of the massage therapist license, the massage therapist shall cease to operate in the city. 
(Code 1994, § 26-134; Ord. No. 8092, § 1, 12-11-2018)  
Sec. 12-360. - Appeal. 
Upon receipt of a written request delivered to the city clerk, an appeal of the denial, suspension or revocation of a massage therapist license shall be heard by the city manager within 30 days after the denial, suspension or revocation. The licensee may submit evidence at the hearing which is relevant and material to the specific basis for suspension or revocation. The city manager shall make a final determination as to suspension or revocation. 
(Code 1994, § 26-135; Ord. No. 8092, § 1, 12-11-2018)  
Secs. 12-361—12-378. - Reserved.  
ARTICLE VIII. - SPECIAL ENTERTAINMENT EVENTS  
DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 
 
Sec. 12-379. - Definitions. 
The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
Amusement rides. 
(1)  The term "amusement rides" means any mechanical or electrical device that carries or conveys passengers along, around or over a fixed or restricted route or course or within a defined area for the purpose of giving its passengers amusement, pleasure, thrills or excitement, including, but not be limited to: 
a.  Rides commonly known as Ferris wheels, carousels, parachute towers, bungee jumping, reverse bungee jumping, tunnels of love, roller coasters, boat rides, water slides, inflatable devices, commercial zip lines, trampoline courts and go-karts; 
b.  Equipment generally associated with winter activities, such as ski lifts, ski tows, j-bars, t-bars, chair lifts and aerial tramways; and 
c.  Equipment not originally designed to be used as an amusement ride, such as cranes or other lifting devices, when used as part of an amusement ride. 
(2)  The term "amusement rides" does not include: 
a.  Games, concessions and associated structures; 
b.  Any single passenger coin-operated ride that is manually, mechanically or electrically operated; is customarily placed in a public location, and does not normally require the supervision or services of an operator; 
c.  Nonmechanized playground equipment, including, but not limited to, swings, seesaws, stationary spring-mounted animal features, rider-propelled merry-go-rounds, climbers, slides and physical fitness devices; 
d.  Antique amusement rides; 
e.  Limited-use amusement rides; 
f.  Registered agritourism activities; 
g.  Any ride commonly known as a hayrack ride in which patrons sit in a wagon or cart that is then pulled by horses or a tractor or other motor vehicle; 
h.  Any ride commonly known as a barrel train, which has a series of handmade cars fashioned from barrels that are connected and pulled by a tractor or other motor vehicle; or 
i.  Any amusement ride owned by an individual and operated solely within a single county for strictly private use. 
Antique amusement ride means an amusement ride, as defined in this section, manufactured prior to January 1, 1930. 
Carnival means a traveling enterprise offering amusement activities, mechanical or electrical rides, booths for the conduct of games of skill or sideshows. 
Circus means a show or performance that includes, but is not limited to, feats of physical skill and daring animal acts or performances by jugglers or clowns. 
Street show means the act of performing in public places for gratuities. 
(Ord. No. 8099 , § 1(14-1), 4-23-2019)  
Sec. 12-380. - Exemption from article provisions. 
This article shall not apply to permanent amusement centers. 
(Code 1978, § 6-90; Code 1994, § 14-111)  
Secs. 12-381—12-403. - Reserved.  
DIVISION 2. - PERMITS AND OPERATIONAL STANDARDS 
 
Sec. 12-404. - Permit required; fee; provisions cumulative. 
(a)  It is unlawful for any person other than the city to operate an exhibition of any product, merchandise or service for profit anywhere within the city, or to operate any carnival, circus, street show or similar public performance or amusement enterprise providing any amusement rides, or dispensing of food and beverage within the city, without first securing a permit from the city clerk for such operation. 
(b)  Fees are in the amount provided in the city fee schedule and are not prorated, refundable or transferable. 
(c)  Any application made, fees paid, and permits obtained under the provisions of this article shall be in addition to and not in lieu of any other fees, permits, or licenses required to be paid or obtained under any other ordinances of the city. 
(Ord. No. 8099 , § 1(14-36), 4-23-2019)  
Sec. 12-405. - Procedure. 
(a)  Application form and time for filing. Application for a permit under this article shall be made to the city clerk on a form provided by the clerk. The completed application must be received by the clerk at least 60 days prior to the event. Each application shall be accompanied by the appropriate permit fee. 
(b)  Plot plan required. Each application shall also be accompanied by a plot plan specifying the location of such exhibition, carnival, circus, amusement enterprise or street show in relation to existing buildings, drive areas, location on the tract and the amount of space available for off-street parking of vehicles. 
(c)  Review by designated city officials. The city clerk will forward the application to the city manager, police chief or designee, fire chief or designee and the director of public works or designee for review and approval of the application. 
(d)  Issuance or denial. The city clerk shall issue or deny the permit within 14 days following the application. The permit may be issued with such conditions as the city deems necessary or appropriate. 
(e)  Compliance with permit conditions required. Compliance with all terms, conditions and regulations of the permit as granted by the city clerk is mandatory. Failure to comply shall immediately void the permit and shall constitute a violation of this article. 
(Ord. No. 8099 , § 1(14-37), 4-23-2019)  
Sec. 12-406. - Insurance required; notice of claims. 
(a)  A certificate of insurance shall accompany the permit application. The certificate shall comply with the following: 
(1)  Minimum limits of liability for commercial general liability insurance shall be $5,000,000.00 for each occurrence if amusement rides or other similar devices are used on the premises or $1,000,000.00 for each occurrence if amusement rides or other similar devices are not in use on the premises. 
(2)  Coverage is from an insurance carrier who is licensed to do business in this state and carries a policyholder rating of A or better. 
(3)  In the description of operations, the certificate lists the city, its officers, affiliates and assignees, as additional insureds on a primary and non-contributory basis and includes the name of the event and dates of the event. 
(b)  The permittee, upon receipt of notice of any claim in connection with the permit, shall promptly notify the city with full details thereof including an estimate of the amount of loss or liability. 
(Ord. No. 8099 , § 1(14-39), 4-23-2019)  
Sec. 12-407. - Inspection of area by city staff. 
An inspection of the location where the event is to operate will be performed by city staff upon set up and prior to the start of the event. Inspections will include, but not be limited to, inspections by the city building inspector, city fire marshal and chief of police or their designees. 
(Ord. No. 8099 , § 1(14-40), 4-23-2019)  
Sec. 12-408. - Duty of permittee to restore location; bond required; inspection. 
(a)  After the event, the permittee shall promptly clean and restore the event location to the condition that existed thereon prior to the occurrence of the event. A cash bond in the amount of $1,000.00 shall be deposited with the city clerk at the time of making the application for permit to guarantee property cleanup of the area. 
(b)  After the event, the event area will be inspected by city staff to ensure compliance with this section, and any fees associated with the cleanup of the area required by the city will be deducted from the cash bond on file. Any unused portion of the cash bond will be returned via check to the permittee within 14 days of the last day of the event. 
(Ord. No. 8099 , § 1(14-41), 4-23-2019)  
Sec. 12-409. - Posting by circuses, carnivals and amusement companies; cash bond. 
(a)  It is unlawful for the owner, agent or other representative of any circus, carnival or amusement company to glue or paste any bill, poster or other advertising matter upon any barn, shed, building, structure or window within the limits of the city, but the bill, poster or other advertising matter may be attached to such structures by tacks or other temporary means if the consent of the owners or agents of such structures is obtained by the owner, agent or other representative of the circus, carnival or amusement company. 
(b)  In addition to the license required, the owner, agent or other representative of any circus, carnival or amusement company, before posting any bill, poster or other advertising matter as provided in this section, shall give a cash bond in the sum of $1,000.00 to the city, conditioned that all such bills, posters or other advertising matter will be removed within one week after the performance so advertised. If all such bills, posters or other advertising matter are not removed within one week after the last performance so advertised, the city shall cause such bill, poster or other advertising matter to be removed and the bond shall be forfeited to the city. 
(Code 1978, § 3-19; Code 1994, § 26-214)  
Sec. 12-410. - State permit required for certain amusement rides and agritourism activity. 
It is unlawful for an owner or operator of an amusement ride, antique amusement ride, limited-use amusement ride or registered agritourism activity, as defined in K.S.A. 44-1601, to knowingly operate, or cause to be operated, any amusement ride without a valid permit issued by the state. 
(Ord. No. 8099 , § 1(14-60), 4-23-2019)  
Sec. 12-411. - Amusement rides to comply with federal, state and local regulations. 
All amusement rides shall be operated and maintained in accordance with federal, state and local regulations, including, but not limited to, K.S.A. 44-1601 et seq. 
(Ord. No. 8099 , § 1(14-60), 4-23-2019)  
Sec. 12-412. - Violations and penalties. 
Violation of this article is a Class B public offense subject to penalties as provided in section 1-10. 
(Ord. No. 8099 , § 1(14-60), 4-23-2019)  
Sec. 12-413. - Appeal. 
Upon receipt of written request delivered to the city clerk, an appeal of the denial, suspension or revocation shall be heard by the city manager within 30 days of receipt by the clerk. The permittee shall submit at the hearing evidence that is relevant and material to the specific basis for the denial, suspension or revocation. The city manager shall make final determination. 
(Ord. No. 8099 , § 1(14-38), 4-23-2019)  
Secs. 12-414—12-437. - Reserved.  
ARTICLE IX. - VEHICLES FOR HIRE  
DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 
 
Sec. 12-438. - Definitions. 
The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meaning ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning. 
Cruising means the continuous or repeated operation over the streets of a vehicle for hire in search of picking up or solicitation of prospective passengers. 
Driver license means the license issued by the city to the driver of a vehicle for hire. 
Meter means an instrument or device attached to the vehicle, which measures the distance driven and the waiting time upon which the fare is based. 
Owner's license means a license issued by the city to the owner of a vehicle for hire. 
Police chief means the police chief of the city or person designated by the police chief. 
Street means street, avenue, boulevard, thoroughfare, trafficway, alley and any other public way for vehicular travel. 
Vehicle for hire means any public passenger motor vehicle, taxicab or shuttle, which is for hire by a passenger for a fee, except that the following are not included in this definition: 
(1)  Vehicles as defined in and operating under K.S.A. 8-2701 et seq. (Transportation Network Companies.) 
(2)  Vehicle operated by the county council on aging. 
(3)  Motor buses and motor vehicles engaged exclusively in the transportation of students to and from school, commonly known as school buses. 
(4)  Vehicle operated by a person or company and used to transport persons who are the employees, patrons, guests, residents or customers of the person or company and where the provision of such transportation is incidental to the business of such person or company. 
(5)  Group riding or an arrangement between individuals whereby they pool their private transportation resources, either by using the personal automobile of one member of the group with the others contributing to the costs of operation of same, or by rotating the use of their personal automobiles with joint contributions to the cost by the other members of the group, or when any employer provides transportation for his employees, and for none other, for a charge. 
(Code 1978, § 38-16; Code 1994, § 122-26; Ord. No. 7352, § 1, 3-10-1998; Ord. No. 8106 , § 122-01, 7-9-2019)  
Sec. 12-439. - Stop and inspection authorized. 
Vehicles for hire and driver licensed under this article shall be subject to reasonable stop and inspection by the police for conformance with the requirements of this article. 
(Code 1978, 38-22; Code 1994, § 122-33; Ord. No. 7352, § 1, 3-10-1998; Ord. No. 8106 , § 122-03, 7-9-2019)  
Sec. 12-440. - Manufacturer's maximum seating capacity not to be exceeded. 
No vehicle for hire shall carry a greater number of persons, including the driver or operator, than its manufacturer rated seating capacity. 
(Code 1978, § 38-19; Code 1994, § 122-29; Ord. No. 7352, § 1, 3-10-1998; Ord. No. 8106 , § 122-04, 7-9-2019)  
Sec. 12-441. - Cruising and solicitation of passengers or business prohibited. 
(a)  When not being operated in driving to or in returning from a specific destination while employed in rendering transportation service, vehicles for hire shall be subject to call at the usual place of business maintained by the owner or operator. 
(b)  No vehicle for hire shall be operated over the streets of the city in service without a specific destination. 
(c)  No owner or driver shall solicit, employ or engage any other person to solicit patronage on the streets, sidewalks or public ways within the city. 
(d)  It is unlawful for the owner, driver or operator to park for the purpose of soliciting business or passengers for hire in any street or alley in the city, except to load or unload such vehicle for hire, and except as hereinafter provided; driver occupied cabs shall be permitted to remain legally parked in the city, for return fare. 
(Code 1978, §§ 38-21, 38-22; Code 1994, §§ 122-31, 122-32; Ord. No. 7352, § 1, 3-10-1998; Ord. No. 8106 , § 122-05, 7-9-2019)  
Sec. 12-442. - Licenses. 
(a)  Required. No person, whether acting as owner, principal, agent, employee, lessee or licensee, shall operate or permit to be operated upon the streets of the city any vehicle for hire without first having obtained an owner's license or a driver license as provided in this article. 
(b)  Annual fee. Owners and driver of vehicles for hire licensed under this article shall pay to the city clerk a yearly fee for such license, at the time of application for each calendar year or part thereof, as provided in the city fee schedule. Application fees are not prorated, refundable, or transferable except as provided in section 12-474. 
(c)  Term. Licenses issued pursuant to this article shall be valid from January 1 to December 31 of each calendar year. 
(d)  Issuance. All licenses shall be issued by the city clerk with the concurrence and approval of the police chief or their designees. 
(Code 1978, §§ 38-29, 38-47, 38-50; Code 1994, §§ 122-46, 122-66, 122-69; Ord. No. 7352, § 1, 3-10-1998; Ord. No. 8106 , § 122-02, 7-9-2019)  
Sec. 12-443. - Liability insurance; required; amount; conditions. 
(a)  It is unlawful to operate a vehicle for hire or permit the same to be operated without proof of continuing liability protection for each vehicle to be operated being on file in the office of the city clerk. The requirements for liability protection shall be as provided in this section. 
(b)  The licensee or applicant shall maintain commercial automobile liability insurance on each vehicle with liability limits of at least $60,000.00 combined single limit for injury to, or death of, one or more persons, and for damage to property, including baggage or other property of a passenger carried in or on the vehicle, resulting from any single accident, by reason of the carelessness or negligence of the driver or operator of such vehicle, with a property damage deductible, if any, not to exceed $500.00, above which all claims shall be referred to the insurance company for handling. 
(c)  The insurance policy shall be issued by an insurance carrier who offers proof that it: 
(1)  Is authorized and licensed to do business in this state and has and maintains a local office or agent in this state upon whom service of process may be had; 
(2)  Carries a Best's policy holder rating of A or better; and 
(3)  Carries at least a Class X financial rating; or 
(4)  Is a company mutually agreed upon by the city and the licensee. 
(d)  Under the policy, the insurance company shall obligate itself to handle claims and indemnify the licensee, owner, lessee, operator, and driver, as applicable, and to pay to the claimant all amounts which the insured becomes legally obligated to pay under the policy in excess of any applicable deductible. A certificate of insurance reflecting all endorsements shall be filed with the city clerk. 
(e)  The policy shall contain a provision for continuing liability thereunder to the full amount thereof, notwithstanding any recovery thereon. 
(f)  The policy shall contain a separate endorsement requiring the insurance company to notify the city clerk in writing of any change in coverage, or cancellation of the policy at least ten days prior thereto. 
(g)  The policy shall list each vehicle to be insured under the policy. 
(h)  Nothing contained in the policy or any endorsement thereof shall release the company from liability for payment of any judgment due to any violation on the part of the insured of the provisions of the policy. 
(Code 1978, §§ 38-33, 38-35; Code 1994, §§ 122-50, 122-52; Ord. No. 7352, § 1, 3-10-1998; Ord. No. 8106 , § 122-31, 7-9-2019)  
Sec. 12-444. - Appeal of license denial, suspension or revocation. 
(a)  Upon receipt of a written request delivered to the city clerk, an appeal of the denial, suspension or revocation shall be heard by the city manager within 30 days of the denial, suspension or revocation. The licensee may submit evidence at the hearing, which is relevant and material to the specific basis for suspension or revocation. The city manager shall make a final determination as to denial, suspension or revocation. 
(b)  Anyone who has been denied a vehicle for hire license or who has had a license revoked or suspended pursuant to this article may appeal the decision of such written order of the city manager to the county district court as provided in K.S.A. 8-235. 
(Ord. No. 8106 , § 122-55, 7-9-2019)  
Secs. 12-445—12-471. - Reserved.  
DIVISION 2. - OWNER'S LICENSE 
 
Sec. 12-472. - Application. 
(a)  Form and content. Application for an owner's license shall be made on a form provided by the city clerk. Such application shall contain the full name and address of the owner of the vehicles to be operated, a description of the vehicles, including year, make, model, vehicle identification number, the number of persons the vehicle is constructed to carry and state license number. 
(b)  Documentation to be attached. At the time of application, the owner shall also provide the following: 
(1)  Current registration establishing ownership of the vehicle; 
(2)  Proof of inspection by an ASE certified mechanic within the past 30 days, on a form provided to the applicant by the city clerk, containing the mechanic's signature certifying the vehicle to be in a thoroughly safe condition regarding the operability and condition of the its brakes, suspension, steering, tires, wheels, muffler and exhaust system, glazing and mirrors, windshield wipers, defrosters, door latch and release mechanisms, fuel tank and lines, seat belts, exterior and signal lights and horn. 
(3)  Proof of insurance as required by this article. 
(c)  Review and recommendation by police chief. Within two business days of receipt of a completed application and applicable fee, the city clerk shall forward such application to the police chief for review. The police chief shall return the application together with his recommendations to the city clerk within two business days. 
(Code 1978, §§ 38-30, 38-31, 38-32, 38-34; Code 1994, §§ 122-47, 122-48, 122-49, 122-51; Ord. No. 7352, § 1, 3-10-1998; Ord. No. 8106 , § 122-32, 7-9-2019)  
Sec. 12-473. - Issuance; form; display; duplicate. 
(a)  Upon approval of the application, the city clerk shall issue an owner's license for each vehicle to the applicant. The license shall be approximately three inches high and five inches wide and include the license number, amount of the license fee, the date of issuance, complete information as to the make of car as shown by the application, the vehicle license number, the name of the company carrying liability insurance on such, and the policy number. The license shall be signed by the city clerk or designee and shall be in the form as provided by the city clerk. 
(b)  When issued, such owner's license shall be carried in the vehicle at all times. Such license shall be presented for review upon demand to any law enforcement officer or passenger of such taxicab. 
(c)  In case of a loss of a vehicle for hire owner's license, the owner shall file with the city clerk a sworn statement of the facts concerning such loss, and if the city clerk is satisfied that the facts justify the issue of a replacement therefor, the city clerk shall, upon payment of a fee provided in the city fee schedule, issue a duplicate license. Such license to be plainly marked "duplicate" in red across the face, and the number of the original and duplicate to be furnished to the police chief. 
(Code 1978, § 38-36; Code 1994, § 122-53; Ord. No. 7352, § 1, 3-10-1998; Ord. No. 8106 , § 122-33, 7-9-2019)  
Sec. 12-474. - Transfer. 
(a)  If the owner of a vehicle upon which an owner's license has been issued desires to have the license transferred to another car, the owner shall make an application to the city clerk of such transfer and pay the fee provided in the city fee schedule. The application shall show the disposition of the vehicle previously licensed and all other information provided for in the original application. 
(b)  If the city clerk determines that the application is made in good faith and that the vehicle for which the license was issued shall no longer be used by the licensee in the vehicle for hire business, the city clerk shall have the authority to transfer the owner's license for the term issued for the vehicle described in the application. 
(c)  No owner's license shall be transferred or assigned by any licensee nor shall any owner's license be used by or in the vehicle for hire of any person than the one to whom issued. 
(Code 1978, § 38-38; Code 1994, § 122-55; Ord. No. 7352, § 1, 3-10-1998; Ord. No. 8106 , § 122-34, 7-9-2019)  
Sec. 12-475. - Grounds for suspension or revocation. 
The license may be suspended or revoked at any time for violations of any of the provisions of this article or of any other ordinance of the city, or of any law of the state, including the following: 
(1)  The licensee shall be responsible for the continued maintenance and repair of the mechanical systems of the vehicle. If the vehicle is found to be in dangerous condition, the license of such vehicle shall be subject to suspension of the license by the police chief or city clerk until repairs are made. 
(2)  The license of such vehicle shall be automatically suspended by the city clerk at any period of time in which insurance is not maintained as required in this article. 
(Code 1978, § 38-39; Code 1994, § 122-56; Ord. No. 7352, § 1, 3-10-1998; Ord. No. 8106 , § 122-35, 7-9-2019)  
Secs. 12-476—12-503. - Reserved.  
DIVISION 3. - DRIVER LICENSE 
 
Sec. 12-504. - Application. 
(a)  Form and content. Application for a driver license shall be made on a form provided by the city clerk. Such application shall contain the following: 
(1)  Name, address and telephone number. 
(2)  Applicant's weight, height, sex, color of hair and eyes. 
(3)  Copy of a current valid driver license issued by the state or valid for operating a vehicle in the state and the experience the applicant has had in driving a motor vehicle. 
(4)  The name of the person or business by whom the applicant is employed. 
(5)  Whether or not the applicant has previously been licensed in any state or city as a driver of a vehicle for hire, if so, when, what state or city. If such license is now or ever has been revoked or suspended and if so, the date and reason for such suspension or revocation. 
(6)  The number of times and places the applicant has been arrested or convicted for traffic violations. 
(7)  Whether or not the applicant has ever been convicted of a felony or misdemeanor, giving particulars of each such conviction. 
(b)  Motor vehicle record. Each applicant shall furnish at the time of application a motor vehicle record obtained within 14 days of the date of application. 
(c)  Driver photograph. In addition, a photograph of the applicant will be taken by the city clerk at the time the application is submitted. One copy of the photograph will be kept on file with the application and one copy will be displayed on the license. 
(Code 1978, § 38-48; Code 1994, § 122-67; Ord. No. 7352, § 1, 3-10-1998; Ord. No. 8106 , § 122-51, 7-9-2019)  
Sec. 12-505. - Examination of application by police; approval. 
The chief of police or his designee shall cause each applicant for a vehicle for hire driver license to be examined as to the applicant's criminal and driving record through appropriate law enforcement channels. The application shall be approved or disapproved based upon the information on the application, the applicant's criminal and driving history and any other reliable information at his disposal. Reasons for disapproval shall include, but may not be limited to, the following: 
(1)  Any felony conviction in the five years immediately preceding the application of a sexual or violent nature. 
(2)  Any felony theft or crime of moral turpitude conviction in the five years immediately preceding the application. 
(3)  Any misdemeanor conviction in the three years immediately preceding the application of a violent or sexual nature. 
(4)  Any misdemeanor theft or crime of moral turpitude conviction in the three years immediately preceding the application. 
(5)  Any DUI or open container conviction in the three years immediately preceding the application. 
(6)  Conviction for three moving violations within the 18 months immediately preceding the application. 
(7)  Any omission or falsification of information on the applicant form. 
(Code 1978, § 38-49; Code 1994, § 122-68; Ord. No. 7352, § 1, 3-10-1998; Ord. No. 8106 , § 122-52, 7-9-2019)  
Sec. 12-506. - Issuance; form; display; duplicate. 
(a)  Upon approval of the application, the city clerk shall issue a license to the applicant in a format prescribed by the city clerk. The license shall include the number of the license, date of issuance, the age, height, weight, sex of the applicant, color of the applicant's hair and eyes, and shall have attached thereto a photograph of the applicant. The license shall be signed by the city clerk or designee. No license shall be subject to transfer or assignment to any person other than the one to whom it was issued. 
(b)  The license shall be conspicuously displayed in such a manner that the entire license is visible from the rear seat of the vehicle. The only driver license displayed shall be the one belonging to the driver who is on duty at that time. The driver shall be responsible for keeping the license in a good condition and legible at all times. 
(c)  In case of a lost license, the owner of such lost license shall file with the city clerk a sworn statement of the facts concerning such loss. If the city clerk is satisfied that the facts justify the issue of a replacement, the city clerk shall upon payment of the fee provided in the city fee schedule issue a duplicate license. Such duplicate license shall be plainly marked "duplicate" in red across the face and the number of the original and the duplicate shall be furnished to the police chief. 
(Code 1978, § 38-51; Code 1994, § 122-70; Ord. No. 7352, § 1, 3-10-1998; Ord. No. 8106 , § 122-53, 7-9-2019)  
Sec. 12-507. - Suspension or revocation. 
(a)  A vehicle for hire driver license may be suspended or revoked at any time by the police chief for a violation of any of the provisions of this article or any other ordinance of the city or any law of the state, or for any immoral, indecent or offensive conduct. 
(b)  Any such suspension shall be noted on the license so suspended, together with a statement of the reasons therefor, and the driver shall thereupon immediately surrender the license to the police chief to be retained during the period of such suspension. 
(c)  A second suspension for the same reason as the first suspension, or a third suspension for any cause, shall automatically revoke the license. 
(d)  No driver whose license shall have been revoked shall again be licensed as a driver of a vehicle for hire except upon presentation of reasons satisfactory to the city manager. No part of any driver license fee shall be refunded upon revocation of any such license and such license shall be purchased and issued upon the conditions set out in this article. 
(Code 1978, § 38-53; Code 1994, § 122-72; Ord. No. 7352, § 1, 3-10-1998; Ord. No. 8106 , § 122-54, 7-9-2019)  
Secs. 12-508—12-538. - Reserved.  
ARTICLE X. - OTHER SPECIFIC BUSINESSES 
 
Sec. 12-539. - New goods public auctions. 
The provisions of the New Goods Public Auction Law, K.S.A. 58-1014 et seq., are incorporated by reference in this section and made a part of this article as if the same had been set out in full in this article. Persons conducting a new goods public auction shall obtain a license from the city and pay a license fee as provided in K.S.A. 58-1019 and in the city fee schedule. 
(Code 1978, §§ 30-33, 30-34; Code 1994, §§ 26-186, 26-187) 
State Law reference— New goods public auction law, K.S.A. 58-1014 et seq.; authority to incorporate by reference state statutes, K.S.A. 12-3009 et seq.  
Sec. 12-540. - Building movers. 
(a)  License required. No person shall engage in the business of building moving, or move any building through, over or along any street, avenue or alley in the city, without first obtaining a license and complying with all other provisions of this article. 
(b)  Application. The building mover license required by this article may be issued by the city clerk with the consent of the city engineer, only on written application of the party concerned, which application shall set forth the relevant work experience of the applicant, the applicant's financial status, references available from third parties, and any other pertinent information the applicant deems necessary or desirable in support of his application. The city engineer may request any further information that he deems necessary or desirable from the applicant before acting upon the application. 
(c)  Bond prerequisite to issuance. Before any license is issued under this article, the applicant shall execute and deliver to the city a good and sufficient surety company bond in the sum of $5,000.00, filed with the city clerk to be approved by the city attorney, and conditioned that the person will pay any outstanding license fees and all damages which may occur to any pavement, street or sidewalk, or to any city fire or police alarm, telegraph, telephone or electric lighting pole, wire, bridge or viaduct belonging to the city, on account of moving any building through, over or along any street, avenue or alley in the city, regardless of whether such damages are caused by the person or his agents, employees or workmen, and conditioned also that the person will save and indemnify and keep harmless the city against all liabilities, responsibility, integrity, judgments, damages, costs and expenses which may in any way accrue against the city in consequence of the granting of the license, and will, in all things, strictly comply with the conditions of such license and permits and of all ordinances of the city. 
(d)  Fee. The license fee required under this section shall be as provided in the city fee schedule. 
(e)  Revocation. Any license issued under the provisions of this section is revocable, and the city engineer may revoke or cancel such license for the failure of the licensee to comply with the terms of this article or for the conduct of the licensee's business in a manner detrimental to the best interests of the residents of the city. Such revocation or cancellation may be ordered immediately or the city engineer may prescribe additional requirements for the continuation of the license as may be, in his opinion, necessary or desirable and in the best interests of the city. 
(Code 1978, §§ 8-223—8-228; Code 1994, §§ 22-666—22-670)  
Sec. 12-541. - Garage sales. 
(a)  Defined. For purposes of this section, the term "garage sale" means any garage, basement, yard, rummage or other similar sale of three or more items that were originally purchased by the garage sale permittee for the permittee's ultimate use. 
(b)  Limitation on number and duration. One garage sale per quarter (first quarter January through March, second quarter April through June, third quarter July through September, and fourth quarter October through December) for a total of four per year. 
(c)  Permit required; exception. No person shall conduct or carry on in the city a garage sale without having first obtained a permit therefor; provided, however, that schools, churches and nonprofit organizations may carry on garage sales for the benefit of the organization when such sale is conducted on school, church or commercial property without obtaining a permit. 
(d)  Application. Application for a permit for a garage sale shall be submitted to the city clerk and such application shall contain a statement that all items to be offered for sale were purchased for use by the applicant. A fee in the amount provided in the city fee schedule shall be submitted with the application. 
(e)  Signs. Signs advertising a garage sale shall not exceed two signs of two square feet each and shall be displayed only on the permitted property during the day of such sale. 
(Code 1978, §§ 30-16—30-21; Code 1994, §§ 98-26—90-28, 98-41—98-43; Ord. No. 7086, § 1, 2-25-1992; Ord. No. 7938, § 1, 11-26-2013)  
Sec. 12-542. - Pawnbrokers; state law adopted. 
The provisions of K.S.A. ch. 16, art. 7 (K.S.A. 16-701 et seq.), except those provisions applicable to a county, are adopted by reference to provide for the regulation of pawnbrokers in the city. 
(Code 1978, § 26-1; Code 1994, § 90-65) 
State Law reference— Pawnbrokers and precious metal dealers, K.S.A. 16-706 et seq.  
Sec. 12-543. - Refuse collectors. 
(a)  License required; application and issuance. Any person desiring to collect or transport for hire garbage, trash or refuse in the city shall obtain a license therefor. Application for a license shall be made to the city clerk and shall set forth the name of the applicant, together with the address of the applicant, title number, make and type of vehicle to be operated for the transportation of garbage, trash or refuse, and the method of disposal of garbage, trash or refuse. Upon receipt of proper and complete application, a certificate of inspection as required in this section and a permit fee in the amount provided in the city fee schedule, the city clerk shall issue the license. 
(b)  Application denial and license revocation. The city may deny license issuance or renewal under this section for the failure of the applicant or licensee to maintain a collection vehicle or complete inspections as required by this article. In addition, the city shall have the right to deny or revoke a license under this article if the applicant or licensee fails to provide adequate, sightly and sanitary disposal of garbage, refuse and trash collected, whether within or without the city limits or if the applicant or licensee permits trash to be scattered or blown or to fall from the truck onto the public streets or alleys of the city. 
(c)  Collection vehicles required; securing vehicle loads; sanitary condition to be maintained. All persons engaged in collecting refuse in the city shall, for such purpose, provide themselves with vehicles with bodies sufficiently tight to prevent the contents escaping therefrom, and such vehicles shall be loaded and conveyed so that none of the contents shall fall upon the ground, run out or spill therefrom. All vehicles used to transport garbage shall be maintained in a sanitary condition by frequent washing and disinfecting to the satisfaction of the city's solid waste foreman or duly authorized representative. 
(d)  Vehicle inspections required. Licensees under this section will ensure that vehicles are thoroughly and carefully inspected and examined by an ASE certified mechanic and certified by the mechanic's signature, on the form provided by the city, and to be in a thoroughly safe condition regarding the operability and condition of the vehicle. All vehicles licensed shall be inspected at the time of original or renewal licensing. 
(e)  Vehicle maintenance standards. Continued maintenance and repair of the mechanical systems of the vehicle shall be the responsibility of the vehicle owner and any vehicle found to be in a dangerous condition shall be subject to suspension of the license until repairs are made. A state department of transportation inspection form may be provided in lieu of the ASE inspection and a current form must be kept on file during the license period of the vehicle. 
(Code 1978, §§ 15-3, 15-4, 15-32—15-34; Code 1994, §§ 98-4, 98-5, 98-56—98-59; Ord. No. 7986, § 1, 12-8-2015) 
State Law reference— Authority to regulate and license garbage and trash collectors, K.S.A. 12-2110.  
Sec. 12-544. - Tree trimmers. 
(a)  Defined. As used in this section, the term "tree trimmer" means any person engaged in the business of cutting down or trimming trees. 
(b)  License required. No person shall engage in the business of tree trimming or tree cutting within the corporate limits of the city without first having obtained a license therefor from the city clerk. 
(c)  Liability insurance required. Before a tree trimmer's license shall be issued, the applicant for such license shall file with the city clerk a certificate of liability insurance issued by a company authorized to do business in the state providing $1,000,000.00 per occurrence for bodily injury or property and $2,000,000.00 aggregate coverage. The description of operations section shall include the following: "tree trimmer" and "City of Leavenworth, its assigned, officers and affiliates are additional insured on a primary and non-contributory basis." The policy shall further include a provision that notice of change or cancellation shall be given to the city. 
(d)  Revocation upon lapse of insurance. A license issued under this section shall be automatically revoked upon receipt of notice of cancellation of the required insurance policy. 
(e)  Term. Each license issued under this article shall be valid from March 1 to February 28 of each year, unless it is revoked. 
(f)  Fee. The license fee for each commercial tree trimmer or tree surgeon shall be as prescribed in the city fee schedule. Fees under this section are not prorated and not refundable. 
(Code 1978, §§ 37-23—37-26; Code 1994, §§ 118-36—118-39)  
Sec. 12-545. - Tent shows and meetings. 
(a)  Location near residences restricted. No facilities requiring a permit under this article shall be located nearer than 300 feet to any occupied residential structure. 
(b)  Measures to be taken to prevent certain nuisances. The permittee under this article shall show that adequate measures will be taken to prevent odor, dust, noise, light, parking and traffic from becoming objectionable to uses on other properties, and an access drive shall be so located as to minimize traffic hazards. 
(c)  Permit required; duration. Use of tents for commercial purposes or temporary religious services shall require a permit from the city under the terms of this article. Each permit issued under this article shall be valid for a period of not more than seven days and shall not be granted for more than three such periods for the same location within any 90-day period. 
(d)  Fee. Each applicant for a permit under this article shall pay a permit fee in the amount set out in the city fee schedule for each permit. 
(Code 1978, §§ 34-1, 34-2, 34-16—34-18; Code 1994, §§ 106-1, 106-2, 106-36—106-38; Ord. No. 7986, § 1, 12-8-2015)  
Chapter 14 - ELECTIONS[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
State Law reference— Elections, K.S.A. 25-101 et seq.; city elections, K.S.A. 25-2101 et seq. 
 
ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 
 
Sec. 14-1. - County election officer to conduct. 
The county election officer shall conduct all elections in the city. 
(Code 1978, § 10-1; Code 1994, § 38-1) 
State Law reference— Similar provisions, K.S.A. 25-2110.  
Sec. 14-2. - Time of opening and closing polls. 
The hours of voting in all general elections, primary elections, city elections and special elections in the city shall be from 7:00 a.m. until 7:00 p.m. 
(Code 1978, § 10-2; Code 1994, § 38-2) 
State Law reference— Similar provisions, K.S.A. 25-2111.  
Sec. 14-3. - Intoxicating beverages at polls prohibited. 
It is unlawful for any person to have any whisky, beer or other intoxicating liquors in such person's possession or under such person's control at any voting or polling place at any general or special election held in the city at any time between the opening and closing of the polls. It is unlawful for any person to have or keep in such person's possession or under such person's control at any place in the city any intoxicating liquor for the purpose of giving such intoxicating liquor away or treating any qualified voter or any person working at the election. 
(Code 1978, § 10-3; Code 1994, § 38-3)  
Sec. 14-4. - Electioneering at polling places. 
Electioneering at polling places is knowingly electioneering on election day within any polling place or within a radius of 250 feet from the entrance thereof. As used in this section, the term "electioneering" means an attempt to persuade or influence, by any means, eligible voters to vote for or against a particular candidate, party or question submitted. Electioneering at polling places is a Class C misdemeanor. 
(Code 1978, § 10-4; Code 1994, § 38-4) 
State Law reference— Similar provisions, K.S.A. 25-2430.  
Sec. 14-5. - Intimidation of voters. 
For purposes of this section, the term "intimidation of voters" means intimidating, threatening, coercing or attempting to intimidate, threaten or coerce any person for the purpose of interfering with the right of such person to vote or to vote as he may choose, or of causing such person to vote for, or not to vote for, any candidate for any office or question submitted at any election. The term "intimidation of voters" also includes mailing, publishing, broadcasting, telephoning or transmitting by any means false information intended to keep one or more voters from casting a ballot or applying for or returning an advance voting ballot. Intimidation of voters is a Class A misdemeanor. 
(Code 1978, § 10-4.1; Code 1994, § 38-5) 
State Law reference— Similar provisions, K.S.A. 25-2415.  
Sec. 14-6. - Disorderly election conduct. 
Disorderly election conduct is prohibited and constitutes a Class B misdemeanor. As used in this section, the term "disorderly election conduct" means willfully: 
(1)  Disturbing the peace in or about any voting place on election day. 
(2)  Leaving or attempting to leave a voting place in possession of any ballot, except as is specifically permitted by law. 
(3)  Approaching or remaining closer than three feet to any voting booth, voting machine or table being used by an election board except as admitted for the purpose of voting or by authority of the supervising judge. 
(4)  Interrupting, hindering or obstructing any person approaching any voting place for the purpose of voting. 
(5)  Engaging, within 250 feet from the entrance of a polling place during the hours the polls are open on election day, in solicitation of contributions or conduct of advisory elections other than those specifically authorized by law, including the exercise of home rule power, to be conducted by a county election officer. 
(Code 1978, § 10-5; Code 1994, § 38-6) 
State Law reference— Similar provisions, K.S.A. 25-2413.  
Sec. 14-7. - Police officers to preserve order. 
The mayor is directed to furnish a sufficient number of police officers during the time that any general or special election is being carried on to preserve order at and in the vicinity of all of the polling places in the city, to keep all pavements and sidewalks free and clear of all obstructions, and to arrest all offenders committing any breach of the provisions of this chapter or the laws of the state or causing any disturbance of the peace at or near the polling places in the city. 
(Code 1978, § 10-6; Code 1994, § 38-7)  
Secs. 14-8—14-32. - Reserved.

Chapter 16 - EMERGENCY MANAGEMENT AND SERVICES[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) ---

ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 
 
Secs. 16-1—16-18. - Reserved.  
ARTICLE II. - LOCAL EMERGENCY AND DISASTER AGENCY 
 
Sec. 16-19. - Disaster assistance to other jurisdictions. 
(a)  In the event of a disaster when there is a request for assistance, if the city can provide assistance without unduly jeopardizing the protection of its own community, that this section authorizes the city manager or his designee, to provide such assistance as may be required under authority granted in K.S.A. 48-904 et seq., with all the privileges and immunities provided therein. 
(b)  Nothing in this section is intended to conflict with or circumvent any existing interlocal agreement, any automatic aid, intergovernmental or mutual aid agreement, or any authority to enter into those in the future. 
(c)  It is the intent of this section to provide assistance in any form of service, including, but not limited to, police, fire, EMS, public works, administrative and clerical during times of disaster, as defined in K.S.A. 48-904, with all the privileges and immunities described therein. 
(Code 1994, § 42-1; Ord. No. 7210, §§ 1—3, 4-11-1995) 
State Law reference— Interjurisdictional agencies, K.S.A. 48-929.  
Secs. 16-20—16-41. - Reserved.  
ARTICLE III. - ALARM SYSTEMS 
 
Sec. 16-42. - Definitions. 
The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
Alarm means any assembly of equipment, mechanical or electrical, arranged to signal the occurrence of an illegal entry or other activity requiring urgent attention and to which the police or fire department is expected to respond. This does not include vehicle alarms. 
Alarm company means the business by any individual, partnership, corporation or other entity of selling, leasing, maintaining, servicing, repairing, altering, replacing, moving or installing any alarm system or causing to be sold, leased, maintained, serviced, repaired, altered, replaced, moved or installed any alarm system in or on any building, structure or facility. 
Alarm user means the person, firm, partnership, association, corporation, company or organization of any kind in control of premises wherein an alarm system is maintained. 
Automatic dialing device means a device which is interconnected to a telephone line and is programmed to transmit by a need for emergency response. 
Burglary alarm system means an alarm system signaling an entry or attempted entry into the area protected by the system. 
Central alarm system means any facility, central station, modified central station or answering service operated by any person, business, firm, corporation or other commercial entity engaged in the occupation of selling, renting, leasing, installing, maintaining, operating or repairing an alarm system, which facility is manned at all times by operators employed to receive, record and validate alarm signals transmitted to such facility and to relay information about such signals to the police department by a direct telephone line. 
Direct telephone lines means a telephone line directly to the police department. 
False alarm means an alarm signal eliciting a response by the police or fire department where an emergency situation does not in fact exist, but does not include an alarm caused by violent conditions of nature or other extraordinary circumstances not reasonably subject to control by the alarm operator or alarm user. 
Fire alarm system means an alarm signaling a fire, smoke, toxic fumes or intensive heat within an area protected by the system. 
Holdup alarm system means an alarm signaling a holdup or attempted holdup is in progress wherein an alarm system is maintained. 
Interconnect means to connect an alarm system including an automatic dialing device to a telephone line, either directly or through a mechanical device that utilizes a telephone, for the purpose of using the telephone to transmit a message upon the activation of the alarm system. 
Local alarm system means any location wherein an alarm system is maintained to activate a local alarm on the premises, such as a bell, siren or horn. 
Permit year means July 1 through June 30. 
Primary trunk line means a telephone line serving the police or fire department or any central alarm station that is designated to receive emergency calls. 
Responsible party means the applicant for an alarm permit and is the person to be held responsible for any fees, or charges levied. This will generally be the alarm user, as defined previously, or the property owner in case of vacant property. 
Robbery alarm system means an alarm system signaling a robbery or attempted robbery. 
(Code 1994, § 42-36; Ord. No. 7239, § 1, 11-28-1995; Ord. No. 7731, § 1, 6-26-2007)  
Sec. 16-43. - Purpose. 
The purpose of this article is to establish conditions and requirements for the installation and use of emergency alarm systems in the city. 
(Code 1994, § 42-37; Ord. No. 7239, § 1, 11-28-1995)  
Sec. 16-44. - Interpretation. 
This article, which is administered by the city through its agents and representatives, shall be liberally construed to affect the purpose of this article and to achieve uniform interpretation and application of the respective ordinances. 
(Code 1994, § 42-38; Ord. No. 7239, § 1, 11-28-1995)  
Sec. 16-45. - Violations and penalties. 
All violations of this article shall be an unclassified offense with a fine not exceeding $500.00. The violations include, but are not limited to, failure to obtain and renew the required alarm user permit by residents, failure of an alarm company doing business in the city to obtain a license from the city clerk as required herein includes renewal and liability insurance and violations of false alarms and permit revocation set forth in section 16-50. 
(Code 1994, § 42-41; Ord. No. 8057, § 1, 9-12-2017)  
Sec. 16-46. - Monitoring; autodial numbers; supervisory controls. 
(a)  Alarms from public institutions, federally insured financial institution buildings, and industrial, commercial and private buildings equipped with alarms will be monitored by the police department. The monitoring of any alarm system by the police department must be approved by the police chief. 
(b)  No automatic dialing devices may be programmed to dial any primary trunk line serving the police or fire department. A dedicated trunk line will be provided by the police department for this purpose. 
(c)  Supervisory controls must use a central alarm station, answering service or local alarm systems and will not be monitored by the police department. Supervisory controls are monitors on such things as sprinklers, thermostats and water controls. 
(Code 1994, § 42-39(1); Ord. No. 7239, § 1, 11-28-1995; Ord. No. 7731, § 1, 6-26-2007; Ord. No. 7986, § 1, 12-8-2015; Ord. No. 8057, § 1, 9-12-2017)  
Sec. 16-47. - Alarm system company to providing training to alarm user. 
Each alarm company selling, leasing or furnishing to any alarm user an alarm system which is installed on premises located within the city limits shall furnish the alarm user with instructions and training for its personnel that provides information to enable the alarm user to operate the alarm system properly and to locate and obtain service for the alarm system at any time, and will make them aware of this article by providing them with a printed copy of the ordinance from which this article is derived at the time of sale. 
(Code 1994, § 42-39(3); Ord. No. 7239, § 1, 11-28-1995; Ord. No. 7731, § 1, 6-26-2007; Ord. No. 7986, § 1, 12-8-2015; Ord. No. 8057, § 1, 9-12-2017)  
Sec. 16-48. - Alarm user permits. 
(a)  Required; application. All persons in the city using an emergency alarm system shall obtain from the city an alarm user's permit pursuant to this article. Application for the alarm user's permit will be filed with the city clerk's office each year. 
(b)  Term. Each permit shall be for a one-year period beginning July 1 of each year. Any new alarm user obtaining a permit in the last quarter of the permit year will be allowed to obtain a following year permit at the same time. 
(c)  Original issue and renewal fees. All alarm users shall pay an alarm user's permit fee for each premises to the city clerk's office prior to installation of an alarm system or within the next business day after installation and upon each annual renewal of the permit. No permit shall be renewed if an outstanding balance of alarm response fees exists. 
(d)  Late charges. A late charge will be charged to users who fail to pay applicable permit fees within 30 days of activating a new alarm system and to users who fail to renew the user's permit by June 30 of each year. 
(e)  False alarm fee amount when permit is not timely renewed. If a permit is not renewed, the fee for any false alarm responses shall be the same as "permit revoked" in the city fee schedule. 
(f)  Amount of fees and other charges. The amount of all fees and late charges under this article shall be in the amount provided in the city fee schedule. 
(Code 1994, §§ 42-39(2); Ord. No. 7239, § 1, 11-28-1995; Ord. No. 7731, § 1, 6-26-2007; Ord. No. 7986, § 1, 12-8-2015; Ord. No. 8057, § 1, 9-12-2017)  
Sec. 16-49. - Alarm company business license. 
(a)  Required; renewal date. An alarm company doing business in the city shall obtain a license from the city clerk. Licenses issued under this section have a renewal date of July 1 of each year. 
(b)  Application. Each application for license shall include the address and phone number of the parent company, the local address and phone number of the representative of the parent company, the state sales tax number, a brief description of the nature of the company's business and a current list of the names of at least two responsible persons to contact in an event of an emergency regarding the systems the company is responsible for. 
(c)  Late charges. A late charge will be assessed to alarm companies who fail to obtain a license before beginning business operations in the city or who fail to renew the license by June 30 each year. No alarm company license shall be renewed if a balance of outstanding fees exists at the time of application. 
(d)  Liability insurance required. Before a license shall be issued under this section, the applicant for such license shall file with the city clerk a certificate of liability insurance issued by a company authorized to do business in the state providing $1,000,000.00 per occurrence for bodily injury or property and $2,000,000.00 aggregate coverage. In the description of operations section, it shall include the following: "Alarm Company" and "City of Leavenworth, its assigned, officers and affiliates are additional insured on a primary and non-contributory basis." The policy shall further include a provision that notice of change or cancellation shall be given to the city. 
(e)  Clerk to be notified of new alarm installations. Each alarm company shall notify the city clerk's office of all new alarm installations within 60 days of such installation. Each late notification will result in a late reporting fee as provided in the city fee schedule, per late notification. 
(f)  Maintenance of monitoring equipment. Each alarm company shall keep its alarm monitoring equipment in satisfactory condition at all times. 
(g)  Amount of fees and other charges. The amount of all fees and late charges under this article shall be in the amount provided in the city fee schedule. 
(Code 1994, § 42-39(3); Ord. No. 7239, § 1, 11-28-1995; Ord. No. 7731, § 1, 6-26-2007; Ord. No. 7986, § 1, 12-8-2015; Ord. No. 8057, § 1, 9-12-2017)  
Sec. 16-50. - False alarm procedure; response charges; revocation and reinstatement of permit. 
(a)  If the police department records six false alarms within the preceding 12-month period for any alarm system. The chief shall notify the responsible party by certified mail of such fact and direct that the user submit a report to the chief within five working days of receipt of the notice describing actions taken or to be taken to discover and eliminate the cause of the false alarms. If the alarm user submits a report as directed, the chief shall determine if the action taken or to be taken will substantially reduce the likelihood of false alarms, and, if so, he shall notify the alarm user in writing that his permit will not be revoked at that time; however, for each additional false alarm the user will be charged a fee as provided in the city fee schedule. 
(b)  If no report is submitted, or if the chief determines that the action taken or to be taken will not substantially reduce the likelihood of false alarms, the permit user fails to pay the false alarm fees, or if in the chief's judgment the alarm user demonstrates no intention to cooperate in reducing false alarms, the chief shall give notice by certified mail or in person to the user and alarm company that the alarm permit shall be revoked without further notice if the user does not file, within ten days, a written request for a hearing. The revocation for this location shall stand until removed by the police chief regardless of a change in ownership or tenant. 
(c)  If the police department records 12 false alarms in the preceding 12-month period, the permit shall be revoked and a fee for revoked false alarm response as provided in the city fee schedule shall be charged for all subsequent false alarm responses. If the alarm user provides sufficient proof that the problems have been corrected, the police chief may reinstate the permit with a fee required to be paid by the alarm user and the fees for false alarms will return to the lowest level as provided in the city fee schedule. 
(d)  If a hearing is requested as permitted in this section, written notice of the time and place of the hearing shall be served on the alarm user by the chief by certified mail or in person. The hearing date shall not be more than 15 nor less than five days after the filing of the request for the hearing. 
(e)  The hearing shall be before a hearings officer designated by the city manager. The police chief and the alarm user shall have the right to present written and oral evidence, subject to the right of cross examination. If the hearings officer determines that more than 12 false alarms have occurred and that the user has not taken action which substantially reduces the likelihood of false alarms, he shall issue written findings to that effect and uphold the chief's action for permit revocation. If the hearing officer determines the user has taken action that will reduce the likelihood of false alarms, the user will retain the alarm user's permit and the hearing officer may reduce the number of false alarms charged against the user. 
(f)  When the police department or fire department has responded to any alarm sound, signal or message emitted or transmitted from or by an alarm system or proprietor alarm, the permit for which has been suspended or revoked, or for which there was not previously issued a permit in accordance with this article, or for which six or more false alarms have occurred in the last 12-month period, the police chief shall promptly transmit a report of appropriate fees to the city clerk, together with an appropriate report relating the facts and circumstances concerning the incident to which the report of fees relates. The city clerk shall cause billing for the total fees as reported by the chief to be mailed or otherwise transmitted to all of the following or as many as are shown to be involved in connection with the particular incident and with the alarm system thereby involved: 
(1)  The responsible party as listed on the alarm permit; 
(2)  The owner or landlord of the property where the alarm system is operated, if such property is vacant; and 
(3)  Any other person shown to have activated the false alarm (if such was the case) intentionally, carelessly, or by negligent act or omission. Upon billings being mailed or transmitted, each person so billed shall become indebted and liable, severally and jointly, for payment to the city of the entire amount due, and additionally for such further legal costs as may be incurred by the city, including a reasonable attorney's fee to be set by the court, in the event the total amount billed is not paid and it becomes necessary for the city to resort to legal action in order to collect. 
(g)  If any billing under this section is not paid within 60 days, an action may be brought for collection of any amounts due. Permits shall not be renewed if unpaid response or permit filing fees exist. 
(Code 1994, § 42-40; Ord. No. 7239, § 1, 11-28-1995; Ord. No. 8057, § 1, 9-12-2017)  
Chapter 18 - ENVIRONMENT  
ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 
 
Sec. 18-1. - Land filling prohibited in business district; exception; special permits. 
(a)  Prohibited in central business district; exception. Deposits on the earth of rock, stone, gravel, sand, earth, building or construction materials, or any other fill material, within the central business district as indicated upon the zoning district map of the city are prohibited, except for excavations for which a building permit has been issued, or deposits on the earth of any building or construction materials to be used in a structure for which a building permit has been issued. 
(b)  Special permits. The city commission may, in its discretion, grant a special permit to otherwise deposit fill within the central business district, by resolution, with such conditions as deemed necessary. A permit issued under this section shall be valid for a specified period of time, subject to inspection by the building inspector as may be required by the city commission to ensure that all work is in accordance with the terms of the special permit. 
(Code 1978, §§ 11-31, 11-32; Code 1994, §§ 46-201, 46-202)  
Secs. 18-2—18-20. - Reserved.  
ARTICLE II. - OIL AND GAS WELLS[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
State Law reference— Oil and gas, K.S.A. 55-101 et seq.; oil and gas wells, K.S.A. 55-150 et seq. 
 
DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 
 
Sec. 18-21. - Fencing and screening of pumping units. 
Pumping units of an oil or gas well shall be surrounded or enclosed with a six-foot chain fence, on top of which, there shall be a protruding extension of three barbed wires at a 45-degree angle to the outside. Within 30 days of completion of the installation of the pumping unit and its required fence, a hedgerow or other means of screening the pumping unit from public view shall be established by the pump owner. 
(Code 1978, § 24.5-4; Code 1994, § 46-234)  
Sec. 18-22. - Power requirements for pumping operation. 
All pumping units at an oil or gas well must be electrically driven. The power belt must be shielded. Use of fuel-powered motors or generators for pumping operations is prohibited. 
(Code 1978, § 24.5-5; Code 1994, § 46-235)  
Sec. 18-23. - Laying, maintaining and operating pipeline; franchise requirements. 
It is unlawful for any person to lay or maintain any pipe or pipelines for the transportation of oil or any other substance in or across the streets, alleys or other public places of the city without having first obtained a franchise ordinance granting permission so to do. All such pipelines shall thereafter be laid, maintained and operated in accordance with the terms of the franchise. 
(Code 1978, § 24.5-6; Code 1994, § 46-236)  
Sec. 18-24. - Construction, operation in accordance with state regulations. 
Any oil or gas well drilled within the city shall be constructed in accordance with applicable regulations of the state corporation commission and the department of health and environment. Any person, before commencing drilling operations, shall notify the appropriate representatives of the commission and department as to the date when drilling operations will commence. 
(Code 1978, § 24.5-7; Code 1994, § 46-237)  
Sec. 18-25. - Utility lines. 
It shall be the responsibility of persons drilling an oil or gas well or installing crude oil transmission lines to determine the locations of utility lines including cable television and telephone lines and any existing pipelines. Such transmission lines shall be installed no closer than two feet from utility lines. 
(Code 1978, § 24.5-8; Code 1994, § 46-238)  
Sec. 18-26. - Locations for drilling. 
Minimum drilling site must be ten acres. Access to the site must be from arterial or collector streets or county roads as classified in the current comprehensive plan. No drilling, pumping, on-site storage or saltwater storage within 330 feet of the lease or property line shall be permitted. Further, no drilling, pumping, on-site storage or saltwater storage within 1,000 feet of a habitable residential dwelling shall be permitted unless written permission is obtained from the property owner. 
(Code 1978, § 24.5-9; Code 1994, § 46-239)  
Sec. 18-27. - Fencing of drilling rig. 
The entire drilling rig for any oil or gas well, together with its equipment, shall be enclosed by a fence not less than six feet in height when not attended. 
(Code 1978, § 24.5-10; Code 1994, § 46-240)  
Sec. 18-28. - Compliance with statutes and applicable rules and regulations. 
Any oil and gas well that is drilled, completed or produced subject to this article shall be drilled, completed, produced and operated in compliance with this article and all applicable state and federal laws and administrative regulations. 
(Code 1978, § 24.5-2; Code 1994, § 46-232)  
Sec. 18-29. - Protection during drilling operations. 
An artificial liner shall be placed in all pits receiving oil, saltwater, waste, waste products or refuse accumulated during drilling operations. Adequate measures shall be taken to protect persons and property from blowing oil during drilling operations. 
(Code 1978, § 24.5-11; Code 1994, § 46-241)  
Sec. 18-30. - Disposal of saltwater and waste. 
At no time shall fluids of any kind or type be run into, stored or collected in earthen pits, and during the period of drilling, completion, operation, repair or maintenance of any oil or gas well the applicant, permittee or contractor shall provide watertight tanks or vessels to contain drilling mud, water, petroleum and all types of liquid or solid waste, such wastes to be regularly removed from the premises and disposed of in accordance with law, and shall not permit the same to spill upon the ground or surface. 
(Code 1978, § 24.5-12; Code 1994, § 46-242)  
Sec. 18-31. - Pumping and storage operations. 
(a)  A six-inch reinforced concrete curb shall be erected around the pumping unit of each oil or gas well and the area within this curb shall be filled with material of a highly absorbent quality such as fill sand. 
(b)  Storage tanks, whether single or battery, will be protected by an earthen dike (revetment) whose enclosed area and height shall produce a volume equal to 1½ times the volume of the capacity of the storage tanks. In the event of a spillage or rupture of the tanks, under no circumstance will the oil be allowed to soak into the ground. The operator shall be responsible for the recovery of the oil. 
(Code 1978, § 24.5-13; Code 1994, § 46-243)  
Sec. 18-32. - Additional requirements; right of entry. 
(a)  All oil or gas lines shall be installed underground. At the time of the granting of any permit or license, the city commission may make such additional requirements by resolution or as conditions to a special use permit as it may deem necessary for the protection and safety of persons and property in the territory likely to be affected by the drilling of the well. 
(b)  The building inspector and other officers, agents and employees of the city shall have the right at all times to go upon the applicant's premises for the purpose of inspecting any oil or gas well and determining compliance with or violation of the terms of this article. 
(Code 1978, § 24.5-14; Code 1994, § 46-244)  
Sec. 18-33. - Penalty for violation of article. 
Any person violating any provision of this article shall be fined not less than $5.00 nor more than $500.00 for each offense, and a separate offense shall be deemed committed on each day during or on which a violation occurs or continues. 
(Code 1978, § 24.5-16; Code 1994, § 46-246)  
Secs. 18-34—18-54. - Reserved.  
DIVISION 2. - DRILLING PERMIT[2] 

Footnotes: 
--- (2) --- 
State Law reference— State well drilling applications, etc., K.S.A. 55-151. 
 
Sec. 18-55. - Drilling prohibited without permit; fees. 
(a)  It is unlawful for any person to commence operation for the drilling, completion or production of a gas or oil well within the corporate limits of the city without first having lawfully obtained from the city a permit therefor pursuant to this division. 
(b)  The applicant shall file with the city clerk an application in writing on a form provided and prescribed by the city attorney and shall, at the time of filing, deposit with the city clerk a fee as provided in the city fee schedule for each well drilling site, which shall be credited to the general operating fund. 
(c)  Permits shall not be assigned a time period without written approval from the city and payment of a transfer fee as provided in the city fee schedule. The fee for reworking a previously drilled site shall be the same as an original site. Production wells shall pay an annual renewal fee as provided in the city fee schedule and at the same time file insurance certificate renewals as required by this division. 
(Code 1978, § 24.5-1; Code 1994, § 46-231; Ord. No. 7086, § 1, 2-25-1992)  
Sec. 18-56. - Conditions precedent to issuance of drilling permit. 
(a)  Applicability. Each of the requirements set forth in this section shall be a condition precedent to the issuance of a drilling permit under this division. 
(b)  Surety bond. The applicant shall file a corporate surety bond approved by the city clerk, executed by a bonding or surety company authorized to do business in the state, in the amount of $25,000.00, payable to the city, conditioned upon the full and faithful compliance with all of the terms and provisions of this division and the conditions of the permit authorized, and saving the city and holding it free and harmless of and from all judgments for damages sustained by the city in the event that any claim for damage or injury is maintained against the city as a result of the activities of the applicant, or his agents, servants, employees or persons in privity with applicant in the drilling, completion or plugging of an oil and gas well and restoration of the site. 
(c)  Irrevocable letter of credit. As an alternative to the surety bond described in subsection (b) of this section, an applicant may submit an irrevocable letter of credit issued by a bank authorized to do business in the state with the same conditions as set forth for a corporate surety bond, and further conditioned as follows: 
(1)  The irrevocable letter of credit shall be issued for a one-year-period, automatically renewable unless the bank gives the city 60 days' notice of intent to not renew; 
(2)  Failure of the drilling permit holder to renew the letter of credit shall cause the termination of the drilling permit which will require the permit holder to cease drilling immediately, complete plugging of the oil or gas well and restore the site within 30 days. 
(3)  Upon failure to complete these required activities within 30 days from the date of the notice of intent to not renew, the city may make demand on the financial institution for payment of the estimated amount of the cost of performing closing and cleanup procedures. Should the costs be less than the estimate, the excess amount shall be returned to the financial institution. 
(d)  Indemnity insurance. The applicant shall file a policy of indemnity insurance or a certificate of such policy: 
(1)  Issued by an insurance company authorized to do business in the state naming the city as a coinsured 
(2)  Insuring and providing indemnity for judgments and defense of actions for injuries, loss or damage for which the applicant, applicant's agents, servants and employees or persons in privity with applicant may be liable as the result of the drilling, completion, operation or maintenance of any oil and gas well or any structure, apparatus, machinery or facilities appurtenant thereto or used in connection therewith. 
(3)  In an amount not less than $2,000,000.00 aggregate for injury and property damage per occurrence. 
(4)  Accompanied by a certificate of the insurer that such insurance is in full force and shall not be cancelled without 30 days' written notice thereof to the city clerk. 
(5)  Which insurance shall be maintained continuously in effect during the entire period during which the applicant and permittee shall be conducting drilling, completion, maintenance or production operations with respect to any oil and gas well drilled under the terms of this division and restoration of the premises. 
(e)  Valid lease agreement. The applicant shall furnish satisfactory evidence that the applicant possesses a valid lease agreement of the surface and minerals in, upon and under the real estate described in the application and upon which the oil and gas well proposed in the application is to be drilled. 
(f)  Method of disposing of waste products. The application shall state and describe the applicant's plans for the handling and disposal of all drilling fluids, basic sediment, oil field brines, liquid petroleum, water, other deleterious substances and wastes that may be produced in connection with the drilling, completion, operation and maintenance of the proposed well, which plan shall be reasonable, adequate, practical and in accordance with the highest degree of care of the industry as well as the specific terms and conditions of this division. 
(g)  Detailed map or plat of property. The applicant shall provide a map or plat of the applicant's property and the precise and definite location thereon of the well to be drilled pursuant to the application, showing the ownership boundaries of all land adjoining the applicant's property and the proposed drill site together with evidence of the names of such owners and their addresses, showing the location of all habitable structures within 1,000 feet of the lease boundaries; the location of all streets, alleys, public areas, utility easements and structures adjoining the applicant's property and the proposed drill site; and the proposed location of transmission lines from the proposed drill site to the point on the applicant's property where it is proposed or expected to be stored. 
(h)  Pledge for specified cleanup upon abandonment. A written undertaking of the applicant that if a well is either nonproductive or abandoned that within 15 days after the determination thereof or abandonment thereof, all tools, equipment and machinery used in connection with the drilling, completion, production or maintenance of such well shall be removed; that the premises will be fully restored to its original condition as soon as practicable, and in no case more than 15 days after such determination; and that such well will be plugged in accordance with the rules and regulations of the state corporation commission. 
(i)  Pledge for restoration of area surrounding immediate well site. A written undertaking of the applicant that if such well is productive and completed, only the tools, machinery, structures and equipment necessary for the normal daily operation thereof shall be maintained at the well site and that the premises surrounding the immediate well site shall be restored to their original condition as nearly as practicable and in no case more than 15 days after the completion of the well. 
(Code 1978, § 24.5-3; Code 1994, § 46-233; Ord. No. 6996, § 1, 11-14-1989)  
Sec. 18-57. - Revocation of permit. 
The violation of or breach of any of the terms or conditions of this article, or the ceasing to exist of any of the conditions precedent listed in this article, or the breach of any of the terms or conditions of any permit issued pursuant to this article, shall be grounds for the revocation of any permit issued under this article. Such revocation shall take place only upon hearing by the city commission, of which hearing the permittee shall be given at least ten days' written notice by mail or personal delivery. Mailing of such notice to the last-known mailing address of a permittee shall satisfy the requirements of notice made in this section. 
(Code 1978, § 24.5-15; Code 1994, § 46-245)  
Secs. 18-58—18-87. - Reserved.  
ARTICLE III. - LAND DISTURBANCE PERMITS 
 
Sec. 18-88. - Definitions. 
The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning:
