When a food or drinking establishment is in violation of this article, including any rules adopted by reference herein, the city health officer is authorized to suspend, or revoke the permit of the food or drinking establishment. Each owner or operator of a food or drinking establishment shall pay an annual health permit fee as provided in the city fee schedule. The annual permit fee shall be payable to the city clerk before the permit is issued. The health permit shall be renewed and the permit fee paid prior to January 1 each year. Proof of a valid food safety license issued by the state department of agriculture must be provided to the city clerk. The city health permit application shall be made upon a form prescribed by the city and submitted and filed with the city clerk. Such form shall include the following: 
(1)  Name and permanent address and contact information of the applicant and the business. If the applicant is not an individual, the names and permanent address of the officers of the corporation or the members of the partnership, firm association or other entity, as the case may be; 
(2)  Valid state sales tax ID number; and 
(3)  Signature of applicant, individually or by its members and officers, and any agents or employees of the applicant who will be involved in the applied-for health permit certifying that all of the information provided in the application is true and correct. 
(Code 1994, § 54-133; Ord. No. 8058, § 1, 9-26-2017)  
Sec. 22-26. - Food service school; food handler permit. 
(a)  Each employee or person engaged in the handling or preparation of food or beverage shall attend online food handler training from the city's online food handler training provider. Attendance of similar training courses held in other cities may be accepted if equal requirements and completion is evidenced by official documents. Upon evidence of training by other means approved by the city health officer or city clerk, a food handler permit shall be issued by the office of the city clerk. Upon request to and approval from the city health officer, such school may be offered and conducted by the city health officer from time to time for special circumstances. 
(b)  All persons attending online food handler training from the city's online food handler training provider shall pay the fee for such training directly to the online provider. All persons attending a requested and approved school conducted by the city health officer shall pay a fee to the city clerk in the amount as provided in the city fee schedule prior to attendance. All persons issued a duplicate permit or a permit upon evidence of training by another means approved by the health officer or city clerk shall pay a fee to the city clerk in the amount as provided in the city fee schedule. 
(Code 1994, § 54-134; Ord. No. 8058, § 1, 9-26-2017; Ord. No. 8091, § 1, 12-11-2018)  
Sec. 22-27. - Regulations adopted; enforcement. 
There is incorporated by reference, for the purpose of adopting regulations, provisions, conditions, terms, and specifications, for the regulation of food safety in food establishments and temporary food establishments within the city; the issuing, suspension, and revocation of licenses and temporary permits; the collection of fees; the making of inspections; the enforcement of this article and the fixing of penalties for violations thereof, the 2012 Kansas Food Code, as adopted and published by the secretary of the state department of health and environment on July 1, 2012, which in turn was based upon the United States Public Health Services (PHS) 2009 Model Food Code. One copy of the 2012 Kansas Food Code shall be marked "Official Copy as Adopted by Ordinance No. 8058," to which shall be attached a copy of the ordinance from which this article is derived and filed with the city clerk to be open to inspection and available to the public at all reasonable hours. The enforcement official for the purpose of enforcing and interpreting the 2012 Kansas Food Code, shall be the city manager or his designee. 
(Code 1994, § 54-135; Ord. No. 8058, § 1, 9-26-2017)  
Sec. 22-28. - Penalties. 
Any person convicted of violating any provisions of this article, for which another penalty is not specifically provided, is guilty of a public offense and punishable by a fine of not more than $500.00 or imprisonment not to exceed six months, or by both such fine and imprisonment. Each person is guilty of a separate offense for each and every day during any portion of which any violation of any provision of such division is committed, continued or permitted by any such person and shall be punished accordingly. 
(Code 1994, § 54-136; Ord. No. 8058, § 1, 9-26-2017)  
Sec. 22-29. - Denial, revocation and appeal. 
(a)  If a license or permit is not issued, the city clerk or designee shall indicate in writing the reasons for denial and inform the applicant of the applicant's right to an appeal of the denial in accordance with the provision of this article. 
(b)  A license or permit may be revoked if the applicant fails to provide true and correct information on the application, the applicant fails to continuously maintain insurance in accordance with requirements of this chapter, or upon a violation by the applicant or any involved agents or employees of any provision of this Code or any federal, state, or local law, rule, or regulation applicable or related to the license or permit issued under this article. Notice of such revocation shall be mailed by the city clerk or designee to the applicant's address as shown on the registration application form, or to the applicant's last-known address, indicating in writing the reasons for revocation and informing the applicant of the applicant's right to an appeal of the revocation in the same manner as a denied application; however, any appeal of a license or permit revocation shall not suspend the revocation during the pendency of the appeal. 
(c)  Upon the city's denial of an application for revocation of a license or permit under this article, the applicant shall have the right to appeal such action within 14 days of the denial or revocation being mailed to the applicant's address as shown on the registration application form, or to the applicant's last-known address. Such an appeal must be in the form of a written request, filed with the city clerk, setting the grounds for the appeal. Upon receipt of such a written request, the city clerk shall schedule the appeal hearing to take place during the next ten calendar days, before the city manager. Notice of the appeal hearing shall be given to the appellant in the same manner as provided for in the mailing of the notice of license or permit denial or revocation. The decision of the city manager on the appeal shall be final and binding on all parties. 
(Code 1994, § 54-137; Ord. No. 8058, § 1, 9-26-2017)  
Secs. 22-30—22-46. - Reserved.  
DIVISION 2. - FOOD AND DRINKING ESTABLISHMENTS 
 
Sec. 22-47. - Definitions. 
The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this division, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
Food and drinking establishment means restaurant, grocery store, convenience store, bakery, delicatessen, bar, cafe, coffee house, bed and breakfast, hotels, lodging establishments, concession stand, drinking establishment, food processors, food wholesalers, food warehouses, food re-packers and food manufacturers and any similar non-temporary business or organization preparing or offering for sale food or beverage outside of its manufactured packaging. 
(Code 1994, § 54-147; Ord. No. 8058, § 1, 9-26-2017)  
Sec. 22-48. - Registration required. 
It is unlawful for any owner or operator of a food or drinking establishment to operate within the corporate limits of the city without first obtaining the required licenses/permits in accordance with this section. 
(1)  Health permit. Food and drinking establishments shall make application and pay a fee to the city clerk in the amount as set out in the city fee schedule. 
(2)  Food handler permit. Each employee or person engaged in the handling or preparation of food or beverage shall obtain a food handler permit. 
(Code 1994, § 54-148; Ord. No. 8058, § 1, 9-26-2017)  
Secs. 22-49—22-69. - Reserved.  
DIVISION 3. - TEMPORARY FOOD SERVICE 
 
Sec. 22-70. - Definitions. 
The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this division, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
City-approved event means any event open to the public within the city, held on any city property, park, street, alley or right-of-way; any event such as a community celebration, parade, run, walk, festival or similar event approved by the city by filing a special event application with the city clerk, paying applicable fees, and approved by city staff or the city commission of the city. 
Event coordinator/promoter means any person or entity responsible for and submitting a special event application with the city. 
Temporary food service operations means any food establishment or vendor who does not possess a permanent location in the city or has not obtained an annual license or permit in accordance with division 2 of this article or any mobile food vendor who does not possess an annual license or permit in accordance with division 4 of this article. 
(Code 1994, § 54-155; Ord. No. 8058, § 1, 9-26-2017)  
Sec. 22-71. - Registration required. 
All temporary food service operations in the city that do not serve prepackaged foods, such as chips and candy bars, from an approved source need a temporary food service permit. Temporary food service application shall be reviewed by the city health officer for approval. The city health officer will take into consideration the food or drink prepared or served, how the food or drink items are prepared, temperature management procedures and enclosure from which the food or drink will be served from. 
(1)  The event coordinator/promoter of a special event shall be responsible for submitting, the completed temporary food service application and fees to the city when food vendors are participating in a single event. 
a.  Coordinator/promoter shall submit completed applications at least two weeks before an event to be reviewed and approved by the city health officer. No fee is to be paid to the city until the vendor has been approved by the city health officer. 
b.  Coordinator/promoter shall pay the temporary food service application fee, for applications approved by the city health officer, as set out in the city fee schedule no later than 24-hours before an event. For weekend scheduled events, payment is expected by 12:00 noon the Friday before the event. 
c.  Temporary food service permits shall be issued per special event and shall be valid for a period of no more than three consecutive days. 
d.  Proof of a valid food safety license issued by the state department of agriculture or any other state is required. In the event the temporary food vendor does not possess a valid food safety license, the city health officer shall provide an inspection for a fee set out in the city fee schedule. 
(2)  Temporary food service vendors shall be inspected by the city health officer during the event. The temporary food service vendor shall be available for inspection at the time specified upon approval of the application. 
(Code 1994, § 54-156; Ord. No. 8058, § 1, 9-26-2017)  
Sec. 22-72. - Registration application. 
(a)  All applications for a temporary food service application shall be made upon a form prescribed by the city and submitted and filed with the city clerk. 
(b)  License or permit is non-transferable and nonrefundable. Such form shall include the following: 
(1)  Name of the applicant and the business or vendor name and contact information. If the applicant is not an individual, the names and permanent address of the officers of the corporation or the members of the partnership, firm association or other entity, as the case may be; 
(2)  Event information to include name of event, location of the event, event coordinator, scheduled dates and times of the event; 
(3)  Valid state sales tax ID number; 
(4)  Information regarding any type of license held; 
(5)  Information regarding the items to be served; and 
(6)  Signature of applicant, individually or by its members and officers, and any agents or employees of the applicant who will be involved in the applied-for temporary food service license certifying that all of the information provided in the application is true and correct. 
(Code 1994, § 54-157; Ord. No. 8058, § 1, 9-26-2017)  
Sec. 22-73. - Exclusions. 
(a)  Application fee shall be waived for nonprofit 501(c)(3) organization with proof of registration as such. 
(b)  Application fee shall be waived for mobile food vendors holding a current city mobile food vending license. 
(c)  Application fee shall be waived for ice cream vendors holding a current city ice cream vendors license. 
(d)  Application fee shall be waived for food service establishments holding a current city health permit. 
(Code 1994, § 54-158; Ord. No. 8058, § 1, 9-26-2017)  
Secs. 22-74—22-104. - Reserved.  
DIVISION 4. - MOBILE FOOD VENDING 
 
Sec. 22-105. - Definitions. 
The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this division, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
City-approved event means any event approved or sponsored by the city, any event such as a community celebration, parade, run, walk, or festival approved by the city by filing a special event application with the city clerk, paying applicable fees, and approved by city staff or the city commission of the city. 
Mobile food unit or unit means any self-contained vehicle, trailer, cart or other type of conveyance from which food or beverage is offered for sale, but does not include ice cream trucks/ice cream vendors. (See division 5 of this article.) 
Mobile food vending means to conduct, hold, carry on, pursue or operate a business of vending, peddling, hawking or selling any food or beverage from a mobile food unit or push cart. 
Mobile food vendor or vendor means any person, corporation, association, or other entity, however organized, that offers food or beverage for sale from a mobile food unit. 
Mobile packaged food delivery truck means an enclosed vehicle licensed to operate on public roads in which a person travels from place to place to deliver packaged food that has been previously ordered. 
Public property means and includes all city streets, alleys, rights-of-way, parking lots, and parking spaces, city parks or recreational areas. 
Push cart means a non-self-propelled vehicle used from which food or beverage is offered for sale, but does not include ice cream trucks. (See division 5 of this article.) 
(Code 1994, § 54-165; Ord. No. 8058, § 1, 9-26-2017)  
Sec. 22-106. - Registration required. 
It is unlawful for any person to conduct mobile food vending within the corporate limits of the city without first obtaining required license or permits in accordance with this article. 
(1)  Mobile food vending license. All vendors shall make application with the city clerk. All applications shall be accompanied by a nonrefundable registration fee. The amount of the fee shall be set out in the city fee schedule. 
(2)  Health permit. All vendors shall make application and pay a fee to the city clerk in the amount as set out in the city fee schedule. 
(3)  Food handler permit. Each employee or person engaged in the handling or preparation of food or beverage shall obtain a food handler permit. 
(Code 1994, § 54-166; Ord. No. 8058, § 1, 9-26-2017)  
Sec. 22-107. - Registration application. 
(a)  All applications for new or renewal license for mobile food vending shall be made upon a form prescribed by the city and submitted and filed with the city clerk. All mobile food vending licenses are for a period of March 1—February 28. License fees are not prorated. All applications shall be reviewed and approved by the city health officer prior to issuance of the license. 
(b)  License or permit is non-transferable. Such form shall include the following: 
(1)  Name and permanent address of the applicant and the business, showing proof of identification, if the applicant is not an individual, the names and permanent address of the officers of the corporation or the members of the partnership, firm association or other entity, as the case may be; 
(2)  The name of the owner and the type, make and registration number and description of the vehicle to be used; 
(3)  Valid state sales tax ID number; 
(4)  A statement as to whether or not the applicant has ever had a mobile food vending registration or other similar license or permit revoked or suspended by the city or any other city. Such a revocation or suspension may result in the city's refusal to process the application; 
(5)  A statement that the applicant understands and agrees that registration will not be used or represented in any way as an endorsement of the applicant by the city or by any department, officer, or elected or appointed official of the city; 
(6)  Proof of a valid driver license for operation of the class of vehicle identified in the application for the applicant and any agent or employees of the applicant who will be involved in driving the identified vehicle; 
(7)  Proof that the applicant has secured commercial general liability insurance for the mobile vending operation to be maintain for the entire length of the registration, written by an insurance carrier licensed to do business in the state, with minimum limits of $1,000,000.00 combined, single limit for bodily and property damage, each occurrence and $2,000,000.00 in the general aggregate. In the description of operations section shall include the following: "Mobile Food Vending" and "City of Leavenworth, its assigned, officers and affiliates are additional insured on a primary and non-contributory basis. Evidence of compliance with these insurance requirements shall be in the form of a certificate of insurance that shall be submitted with the application. Such insurance certificate shall not be cancelled without prior written notice to the city; and 
(8)  Signature of applicant, individually or by its members and officers, and any agents or employees of the applicant who will be involved in the applied-for mobile food vending certifying that all of the information provided in the application is true and correct. 
(Code 1994, § 54-167; Ord. No. 8058, § 1, 9-26-2017)  
Sec. 22-108. - Operating conditions. 
All mobile food vending registration certificates shall be subject to compliance with the following conditions: 
(1)  Location. 
a.  Mobile food vendors may not be located on property where the unit or a line of customers would: 
1.  Hinder the flow of traffic on any street; 
2.  Hinder the flow of bicycles within any bike lane or route; 
3.  Hinder the flow of pedestrians along any sidewalks; 
4.  Block or reduce to less than five feet in width any accessible route to persons with disabilities; 
5.  Block, hinder, or obstruct the vehicular flow within any parking lot; or 
6.  Block or obstruct access to any driveway or access point to any property. 
A police officer may order the vehicle moved by the operator to comply with these provisions or have the vehicle towed at owner's expense to alleviate the problem. 
b.  No more than three mobile food units may locate on any zoning lot at any given time except as part of a city-approved event; 
c.  Mobile food vendors shall not operate within 100 feet of a permanent brick and mortar restaurant during posted hours of operations, without written permission from the restaurant owner; 
d.  Mobile food vendors shall not operate within residential zoning districts, unless at an approved block party event with an authorized temporary street closure, or other private event and parked on a private driveway; 
e.  Mobile food vendors shall not operate in a public right-of-way along parade routes on the day of the parade; 
f.  Mobile food vendors shall not locate on any public property or park without first obtaining permission from the city. Requests shall be filed with the city clerk for consideration and may be granted by the city manager; and 
g.  Every unit shall be stationary while vending. 
(2)  Written permission of property owner. All mobile food vendors operating on private property shall acquire and maintain the written permission of the property owner for the use of and location of the unit on the property. Written permission of the property owner shall be kept in the unit and produced upon request by the police chief or designee or other public officer changed by the city manager with enforcement of this article. 
(3)  Prohibited sales. Mobile food vendors are prohibited at all times from selling or offering for sale alcoholic beverages, cereal malt beverages, or tobacco products. 
(4)  Lights. No flashing lights or attention attracting devices are permitted on or in association with the use of the mobile food unit. No direct light from a mobile food unit may be shined on adjacent property or cause glare or distraction for vehicles, bicycles, or pedestrians. 
(5)  Sound devices. Amplified music or chimes from a mobile food unit is not allowed. 
(6)  Signs. No sign on a mobile food unit may be illuminated. A maximum of one detached A-frame/sandwich board sign may be permitted as per section 8.10 of Appendix A, Development Regulations. A-frame/sandwich board sign must be located within 15 feet of the associated unit and may not interfere with vehicle access, pedestrian movement, or handicap-accessible routes to and around the unit. 
(7)  Trash and site cleanup. All mobile food vendors shall ensure that a trash receptacle shall be provided with each mobile food unit. Such receptacle must be attached to the unit or located within 15 feet of the unit and cannot interfere with vehicle access, pedestrian movement or handicap-accessible routes to and around the unit. Immediately upon the cessation of vending, the mobile food vendor shall remove and properly dispose of all trash and litter accumulated at the vending site. 
(8)  License and permits. All mobile food vendors shall acquire and maintain all required licenses and permits applicable to the use and operation of mobile food units from all applicable jurisdictions. Evidence of such license or permits shall be kept in the unit and produced upon request by the police chief or designee, city food health officer or other public official charged by the city manager with enforcement of this chapter. 
(Code 1994, § 54-168; Ord. No. 8058, § 1, 9-26-2017)  
Sec. 22-109. - Exclusions. 
The provisions of this section (mobile food vending) shall not apply to the following: 
(1)  Vendors selling as part of a city-approved event; 
(2)  Vendors selling at the Leavenworth Farmers Market; 
(3)  Ice cream vendors licensed under division 5 of this article; 
(4)  Vendors selling on public or private school property with the permission of any such school; 
(5)  The sale of farm or garden products or fruit grown by the seller or his employer; 
(6)  Individuals providing catering services to a private event and not open for the sale of food or beverage to the general public; 
(7)  Mobile packaged food delivery trucks; or 
(8)  Neighborhood refreshment stands and other similar products. 
(Code 1994, § 54-169; Ord. No. 8058, § 1, 9-26-2017)  
Secs. 22-110—22-131. - Reserved.  
DIVISION 5. - ICE CREAM VENDORS 
 
Sec. 22-132. - Definitions. 
The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this division, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
Ice cream vending means the act of traveling by any type of vehicle from house to house, or place to place, selling or offering for sale any prepackaged ice cream, ice cream novelties, or frozen treats intended for immediate consumption within the corporate limits of the city. 
Ice cream vendor means any person, firm, partnership or corporation who travels by any type of vehicle from house to house, or place to place, selling or offering for sale any prepackaged ice cream, ice cream novelties, or frozen treats intended for immediate consumption within the corporate limits of the city; provided, however, that no person, firm, partnership or corporation shall be considered an ice cream vendor when orders are taken for ice cream food products to be delivered to the ultimate consumer on a prearranged day subsequent to the date of sale. 
Ice cream vendor unit or vehicle means every device in, upon or by which any person or property is or may be transported or drawn upon a street or highway for the purpose of vending ice cream, ice cream novelties or frozen treats intended for immediate consumption. 
(Code 1994, § 54-176; Ord. No. 8058, § 1, 9-26-2017)  
Sec. 22-133. - Registration required. 
It is unlawful for any person to conduct ice cream vending within the corporate limits of the city without first obtaining required license or permits in accordance with this article. 
(1)  Ice cream vendor license or permit. All vendors shall make application with the city clerk. All applications shall be accompanied by a nonrefundable registration fee. The amount of the fee shall be as provided in the city fee schedule. 
(2)  Health permit. All vendors shall make application and pay a fee to the city clerk in the amount as set out in the city fee schedule. 
(3)  Food handler permit. Each employee or person engaged in the handling or preparation of food or beverage shall obtain a food handler permit. 
(Code 1994, § 54-177; Ord. No. 8058, § 1, 9-26-2017)  
Sec. 22-134. - Registration application. 
(a)  All applications for new or renewal license or permits as an ice cream vendor shall be made upon a form prescribed by the city and submitted and filed with the city clerk. All ice cream vendor license or permits are for a period of March 1—February 28. License or permit fees are not prorated or refundable. All application shall be reviewed and approved by the city health officer and police chief prior to issuance of the license. 
(b)  License or permit is non-transferable. Such form shall include the following: 
(1)  Name and permanent address of the applicant and the business, showing proof of identification. If the applicant is not an individual, the names and permanent address of the officers of the corporation or the members of the partnership, firm association or other entity, as the case may be; 
(2)  The name of the owner and the type, make and registration number and description of the vehicle to be used; 
(3)  Valid state sales tax ID number; 
(4)  A statement as to whether or not the applicant has ever had an ice cream vending registration or other similar license or permit revoked or suspended by the city or any other city. Such a revocation or suspension may result in the city's refusal to process the application; 
(5)  A statement that the applicant understands and agrees that registration will not be used or represented in any way as an endorsement of the applicant by the city or by any department, officer, or elected or appointed official of the city; 
(6)  Proof of a valid driver license for operation of the class of vehicle identified in the application for the applicant and any agent or employees of the applicant who will be involved in driving the identified vehicle; 
(7)  Proof that the applicant has secured commercial general liability insurance for the mobile vending operation to be maintain for the entire length of the registration, written by an insurance carrier licensed to do business in the state, with minimum limits of $1,000,000.00 combined, single limit for bodily and property damage, each occurrence and $2,000,000.00 in the general aggregate. In the description of operations section shall include the following: "Ice Cream Vendor" and "City of Leavenworth, its assigned, officers and affiliates are additional insured on a primary and non-contributory basis. Evidence of compliance with these insurance requirements shall be in the form of a certificate of insurance that shall be submitted with the application. Such insurance certificate shall not be cancelled without prior written notice to the city; and 
(8)  Signature of applicant, individually or by its members and officers, and any agents or employees of the applicant who will be involved in the applied-for ice cream vendor license or permit certifying that all of the information provided in the application is true and correct. 
(c)  No license shall be issued under this division to any person who: 
(1)  Is required to register pursuant to the Kansas Offender Registration Act, K.S.A. 22-4901 et seq., or pursuant to an offender registration act of any state; 
(2)  Has been convicted of a felony; 
(3)  Has been convicted in the past five years of a misdemeanor or ordinance violation involving force, violence, deceit, or fraud; or 
(3)  Has been convicted in the past three year of any law prohibiting leaving the scene of an accident; driving under the influence of alcohol or drugs; reckless driving; fleeing or eluding a police officer; driving while license is suspended or revoked; failure to report an accident; or five or more traffic violations (not including parking violations). 
(Code 1994, § 54-178; Ord. No. 8058, § 1, 9-26-2017)  
Sec. 22-135. - Operating conditions. 
It is unlawful for any ice cream vendor to: 
(1)  Vend on a street where the posted speed limit exceeds 25 miles per hour, nor exceed a speed of 15 miles an hour when seeking sales or when attempting to make a sale; 
(2)  Stop anywhere within 25 feet of an intersection when making a sale or attempting to make a sale; 
(3)  Double-park, or park in any manner contrary to any ordinance relating to parking when attempting a sale or when making a sale; 
(4)  Make a U-turn on any block; 
(5)  Drive the vehicle backwards to make or attempt any sale; 
(6)  Sell or attempt to sell to any person who is standing in the street; 
(7)  Permit any person to hang on the vehicle or permit any person to ride in or on the vehicle except a driver and a bona fide assistant authorized by the owner of the vehicle or the licensee; 
(8)  Remain standing or stopped at any place for a period of time exceeding ten minutes, or otherwise stop or park a vehicle on the public right-of-way for the purpose of making a sale so as to obstruct the free flow of traffic; 
(9)  Sell or attempt to sell along any particular route more than one time during a 24-hour period; 
(10)  Sell or attempt to sell inside any city park or recreational area unless authorized by the city as part of a city-sponsored event or as authorized by the parks and recreation director; 
(11)  Sell or attempt to sell from a vehicle which is not equipped with a prominent sign visible to both the front and rear with the wording "Caution—Children," and flashing amber (yellow) caution lights on all four corners of the vehicle visible from front, rear and both sides; 
(12)  Use a sound device of any kind whatsoever, except bell, amplified music or chimes which are not audible any distance greater than 300 feet which are turned off when the vehicle is stationary for the purpose of seeking a sale or attempting to make a sale; 
(13)  Sell or attempt to sell or use amplified music or chimes outside the hours of 10:00 a.m. to 30 minutes after sunset; 
(14)  Sell or attempt to sell while the vehicle is moving; or 
(15)  Sell or attempt to sell within 500 feet of an active school zone of a public or private school. 
(Code 1994, § 54-179; Ord. No. 8058, § 1, 9-26-2017)  
Sec. 22-136. - Exclusions. 
The provisions of this division shall not apply to vendors selling as part of a city-approved event or to vendors selling on public or private school property with the permission of any such school. 
(Code 1994, § 54-180; Ord. No. 8058, § 1, 9-26-2017)  
Sec. 22-137. - Vehicle inspection. 
The police chief or designee or other public officer charged by the city manager with enforcement of this article may at any time cause any ice cream vendor unit to be inspected to determine that the unit is suitable from the standpoint of safety for the conduct of an ice cream business and that all provisions of this division and any other city ordinances relating to safety are being complied with. 
(Code 1994, § 54-181; Ord. No. 8058, § 1, 9-26-2017)  
Secs. 22-138—22-157. - Reserved.  
ARTICLE III. - PRIVIES, CESSPOOLS AND SEPTIC TANKS 
 
Sec. 22-158. - Inspection authority. 
The public works director or his representative shall have the right to enter upon any premises and inspect the sanitary conditions therein to enforce this article. 
(Code 1978, § 16-30; Code 1994, § 54-186; Ord. No. 7548, § 1, 10-22-2002)  
Sec. 22-159. - Prohibition. 
No person shall construct, permit or maintain a privy vault or cesspool within the city limits. Septic tanks may not be constructed on any lot or premises where there is a public sanitary sewer and city water in any street, alley or highway adjoining such lots or premises. 
(Code 1978, § 16-31; Code 1994, § 54-187; Ord. No. 7548, § 1, 10-22-2002)  
Sec. 22-160. - Abandonment; filling. 
Every septic tank located on premises described in section 22-159 shall be abandoned within 90 days after a new sewer is laid and all abandoned privies, septic tanks and cesspools must be thoroughly cleaned and filled with ashes, cinders or other material not subject to decay or liable to cause a nuisance from any cause whatsoever. 
(Code 1978, § 16-32; Code 1994, § 54-188; Ord. No. 7548, § 1, 10-22-2002)  
Sec. 22-161. - Adoption of state board of health standards for construction. 
Construction of septic tanks shall comply with the standards as prescribed by the state board of health, three copies of which are on file with the city clerk. 
(Code 1978, § 16-33; Code 1994, § 54-189; Ord. No. 7548, § 1, 10-22-2002)  
Sec. 22-162. - Installations. 
Rules and regulations pertaining to the installation of septic tanks in the city shall be as follows: 
(1)  Permits. A septic tank may be constructed upon any premises containing 21,000 square feet or more within the city when a connection to a sanitary sewer is not available. A permit for such installation shall be issued by the plumbing inspector upon approval by the city public works director upon application describing the location of the premises and the proposed design of such tank and appurtenances thereto, and approval of the same, and payment of the permit fee as provided in the city fee schedule. 
(2)  Construction. All septic tanks shall be of a factory-constructed type of not less than 800-gallon capacity of a type approved by the plumbing inspector and the city public works director. Each septic tank must be connected to at least 200 feet of factory-made lateral drain tile at least four inches in diameter. The tank must be covered by a self-sealing, factory-designed top. All tanks shall be inspected and approved by the public works director before being covered. 
(3)  Approval of septic system prior to issuance of building permit. Where a public sewer is not available, approval of a septic system must be obtained from the public works director before a building permit is issued. 
(4)  Prohibited uses. The use of wells or cesspools for use as a sewage disposal system is strictly prohibited. 
(Code 1978, § 16-34; Code 1994, § 54-190; Ord. No. 7548, § 1, 10-22-2002)  
Sec. 22-163. - Disinfection. 
All septic tanks shall be disinfected when so ordered by the public works director or his authorized representative. 
(Code 1978, § 16-35; Code 1994, § 54-191; Ord. No. 7548, § 1, 10-22-2002)  
Sec. 22-164. - Temporary privies for workers. 
All contractors or other persons employing men in constructing buildings, street improvement or other similar work shall provide and care for such temporary privies as will meet the approval of the public works director. 
(Code 1978, § 16-36; Code 1994, § 54-192; Ord. No. 7548, § 1, 10-22-2002)  
Sec. 22-165. - Duty of owner to keep clean. 
It is the duty of the owner or agents of property to keep all septic tanks on property owned or managed by them clean and to properly clean them when notified by the public works director to do so; and any expense incurred in cleaning or abating any nuisance shall be paid by the person owning the premises where the septic tank has been ordered cleaned by the public works director. 
(Code 1978, § 16-37; Code 1994, § 54-193; Ord. No. 7548, § 1, 10-22-2002)  
Sec. 22-166. - Requirement for dwelling houses. 
No building shall be used as a dwelling house unless such building is provided with a sanitary sewer or septic tank. 
(Code 1978, § 16-38; Code 1994, § 54-194; Ord. No. 7548, § 1, 10-22-2002)  
Sec. 22-167. - Cleaning permit. 
It is unlawful for any person to clean a septic tank until the equipment for cleaning the septic tank has been examined and approved by the public works director. Written approval by the public works director is sufficient guarantee of proper equipment to perform the work, but the public works director may revoke the privilege of cleaning septic tanks at any time if the apparatus is not maintained in a satisfactory condition. 
(Code 1978, § 16-39; Code 1994, § 54-195; Ord. No. 7548, § 1, 10-22-2002)  
Sec. 22-168. - Specifications for containers used for removal of contents. 
All carts, receptacles, containers and implements used in the removal of the contents of any septic tank shall be strong, tight and so constructed that no part of the contents shall leak or fall therefrom, and such carts, receptacles, containers and implements shall be kept covered and protected so that flies shall not have access thereto or to contents thereof. 
(Code 1978, § 16-40; Code 1994, § 54-196; Ord. No. 7548, § 1, 10-22-2002)  
Sec. 22-169. - Cleaning of containers used for removal of contents. 
All carts, receptacles, containers and implements used in removing the contents of any septic tank shall be kept in an inoffensive and sanitary condition. Such carts, receptacles, containers and implements shall be thoroughly washed inside and outside after each use and when not in use shall be disinfected, stored and kept in some place where they shall not become offensive or create a nuisance. 
(Code 1978, § 16-41; Code 1994, § 54-197; Ord. No. 7548, § 1, 10-22-2002)  
Sec. 22-170. - Time for cleaning. 
The time of the day or year when septic tanks shall be cleaned will not be limited except in cases where a nuisance will be created by cleaning them in the day-time, and in all cases the public works director shall be the judge. In every and all cases where the public works director orders a septic tank cleaned at night, the time for cleaning will be limited to the time between 9:00 p.m. and 5:00 a.m. 
(Code 1978, § 16-42; Code 1994, § 54-198; Ord. No. 7548, § 1, 10-22-2002)  
Sec. 22-171. - Time, place and manner of cleaning. 
The time, place and manner of cleaning septic tanks and the disposal of the contents of septic tanks shall be determined by the public works director, and written permission will be given designating the time, place and manner of removal and disposal of the wastes. Disposal in every case shall be into a public sewage treatment facility. 
(Code 1978, § 16-43; Code 1994, § 54-199; Ord. No. 7548, § 1, 10-22-2002)  
Secs. 22-172—22-195. - Reserved.  
ARTICLE IV. - TEMPORARY SEWAGE LAGOONS 
 
Sec. 22-196. - Prohibition. 
No person shall construct, permit or maintain a sewage lagoon within the city limits except as provided in this article. Temporary sewage lagoons shall not be constructed on any lot or premises where there is a public sanitary sewer available to serve such premises or where the percolation test by the city public works director indicates that such premises is suitable for septic tank and lateral field sewage systems. 
(Code 1978, § 16-47; Code 1994, § 54-231; Ord. No. 7548, § 1, 10-22-2002)  
Sec. 22-197. - Inspections; authority. 
The public works director or representative shall have the right to enter upon any premises and inspect the sanitary conditions therein to enforce this article. 
(Code 1978, § 16-48; Code 1994, § 54-232; Ord. No. 7548, § 1, 10-22-2002)  
Sec. 22-198. - Adoption of state board of health standards for construction. 
Construction of temporary sewage lagoons shall comply with the standards as prescribed by the state board of health and as such standards may be amended. 
(Code 1978, § 16-49; Code 1994, § 54-233; Ord. No. 7548, § 1, 10-22-2002)  
Sec. 22-199. - Installations. 
Rules and regulations pertaining to the installation of temporary sewage lagoons in the city shall be as follows: 
(1)  Permit. A permit for such installation may be issued by the plumbing inspector upon approval by the public works director upon application describing the location of the premises, the proposed design and approval of same by the state board of health, and payment of a permit fee as provided in the city fee schedule. 
(2)  Construction. All temporary sewage lagoons constructed under authority of this article shall be totally retentive. All temporary sewage lagoons shall be inspected and approved by the director of the city public works director before being placed in service. 
(3)  Fencing. All temporary sewage lagoons shall be enclosed with a minimum fence 60 inches in height of woven or welded wire, with two-inch by four-inch maximum openings. 
(4)  Compliance with all rules and regulations. No person shall be issued a permit or undertake construction of a temporary sewage lagoon without full compliance with all rules and regulations adopted by the state department of health and environment, the laws of the state and ordinances of the city. 
(Code 1978, § 16-50; Code 1994, § 54-234; Ord. No. 7548, § 1, 10-22-2002)  
Sec. 22-200. - Duty of owner to maintain. 
The owner of the premises shall maintain the area within the fenced enclosure in accordance with the directions from the public works director. Failure to properly maintain, including filling upon abandonment, and cleaning within five days from notification from the public works director to do so shall constitute a nuisance and any expense incurred in cleaning or abating any nuisance shall be paid by the person owning the premises where the area has been ordered cleaned by the public works director. 
(Code 1978, § 16-51; Code 1994, § 54-235; Ord. No. 7548, § 1, 10-22-2002)  
Sec. 22-201. - Abandonment; filling. 
Every temporary sewage lagoon shall be abandoned within 90 days after a new sewer is available for use, and all abandoned temporary sewage lagoons must be filled in accordance with directions from the public works director. Failure to so do shall constitute a nuisance. 
(Code 1978, § 16-52; Code 1994, § 54-236; Ord. No. 7548, § 1, 10-22-2002)  
Sec. 22-202. - Service of notice to abate nuisance. 
The notice to abate a nuisance under this article shall be served as any other legal process may be served pursuant to law and shall contain an order to abate the nuisance within the time period set forth in this article, describe the location of the nuisance and a description of what constitutes such nuisance, a statement of acts necessary to abate the nuisance, and a statement that if the nuisance is not abated as directed and no request for hearing is made within the prescribed time, the city will abate such nuisance and assess the costs thereof against such person. Any costs incurred for abatement of such nuisance shall be certified to the city commission and, if not paid by the owner of such premises, shall be assessed against each lot or piece of ground chargeable therewith as a special assessment, and the city clerk shall certify the assessment to the county clerk for collection as other special assessments are collected. 
(Code 1978, § 16-53; Code 1994, § 54-237; Ord. No. 7548, § 1, 10-22-2002)  
Sec. 22-203. - Penalty for violation of article. 
Any person who shall violate any of the provisions of this article shall be punished as provided in section 1-10. Each day's violation after notice to discontinue such practice shall be deemed a separate and distinct offense and punishable as such. The penalties provided in this section shall be in addition to any action taken to abate an existing nuisance, and it is further, provided that the city may maintain an action in a court of competent jurisdiction to abate such nuisance and any person injured by the violation of any provisions of this section shall have the right of action for the abatement of such nuisance as may be by law provided. 
(Code 1978, § 16-54; Code 1994, § 54-238; Ord. No. 7548, § 1, 10-22-2002)  
Chapter 24 - LIBRARY[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
State Law reference— Libraries generally, K.S.A. 12-1215 et seq. 
 
ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 
 
Sec. 24-1. - Defined. 
As used in this chapter, the term "library" means the public library of the city. 
(Code 1978, § 19-1; Code 1994, § 62-1)  
Sec. 24-2. - Library board. 
(a)  Established; membership. The city has created a library board for the city which shall consist of seven members to be appointed in the manner and for terms provided by law. The mayor shall be ex officio a member of such board with the same powers as appointed members. 
(b)  Officers. The library board shall annually meet and organize by the election of a chairperson, a secretary and a treasurer and such other officers as they may deem necessary. 
(c)  Regular and special meetings. The library board shall fix the date and place of its regular meetings, and special meetings may be called by the chairperson or upon written request of a majority of the members in the manner provided by law. 
(d)  Duties. The library board shall be responsible for the general operation and maintenance of the city library and shall make and adopt rules and regulations for the administration thereof. 
(e)  Employment of librarian. The library board shall employ a trained librarian to operate the library. 
(Code 1978, §§ 19-17—19-23; Code 1994, §§ 62-36—62-42) 
State Law reference— Library boards generally, K.S.A. 12-1222 et seq.; powers and duties of library board, K.S.A. 12-1225.  
Secs. 24-3—24-22. - Reserved.  
ARTICLE II. - USE RESTRICTIONS[2] 

Footnotes: 
--- (2) --- 
State Law reference— Rules and regulations for use of library, K.S.A. 12-1227. 
 
Sec. 24-23. - Injuring building and property. 
Any person who shall cut, carve, mark, etch or engrave any character, figure, picture, letter or name on the building occupied by the library, or who shall willfully in any way injure or damage the building, or who shall cut, mar or injure any tree, shrub, plant, fence, wall or other public property in, on or around the ground upon which the building is situated, shall be guilty of a misdemeanor. 
(Code 1978, § 19-2; Code 1994, § 62-2)  
Sec. 24-24. - Destruction of books and other personal property. 
Any person who shall willfully injure or destroy any article of furniture, book, map, plat, chart, magazine, periodical, picture, statuary or other personal property belonging to or in care of the library shall be guilty of a misdemeanor. 
(Code 1978, § 19-3; Code 1994, § 62-3)  
Sec. 24-25. - Taking without permission. 
It is unlawful for any person to take from the library any book, map, plat, chart, magazine, periodical, picture, statuary or other personal property belonging to or in charge of the library, except with the permission of the person legally in charge thereof, and under the rules adopted by the board of directors of the library, or to retain such book, map, plat, chart, magazine, periodical, picture, statuary or any other personal property belonging to or in charge of the library for a longer period of time than specified in the rules adopted by the board of directors of the library, and any person who shall fail or refuse to return such book, map, plat, chart, magazine, periodical, picture, statuary or other personal property belonging to or in the care of the library shall be guilty of a misdemeanor. 
(Code 1978, § 19-4; Code 1994, § 62-4)  
Chapter 26 - MANUFACTURED HOMES AND PARKS[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
State Law reference— Manufactured Home and Recreational Vehicle Code, K.S.A. 75-1211 et seq.; Kansas Manufactured Housing Act, K.S.A. 58-4201 et seq. 
 
ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 
 
Secs. 26-1—26-18. - Reserved.  
ARTICLE II. - TRAVEL TRAILER PARKS  
DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 
 
Sec. 26-19. - Definitions. 
The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
Natural or artificial barrier means any river, pond, canal, railroad, levee, embankment, fence, hedge, street or alley. 
Park means travel trailer park. 
Travel trailer means and includes any vehicle or similar portable structure constructed so as to permit its being used as a conveyance on a public street and so as to permit the occupancy thereof for dwelling or sleeping purposes by one or more persons, provided that this definition shall refer to and include any portable contrivance used or intended to be used generally for temporary living or sleeping quarters and which is capable of being moved by its own power, towed, transported by or mounted upon another vehicle, not exceeding eight feet in width and 30 feet in length. 
Travel trailer park means any plot of ground upon which one or more travel trailers occupied for dwelling or sleeping purposes are located, regardless of whether or not a charge is made for such accommodation. 
Travel trailer space means a plot of ground within a camper park designed for the accommodation of one travel trailer. 
(Code 1978, § 22-16; Code 1994, § 66-36)  
Sec. 26-20. - Parking travel trailers. 
It is unlawful for any person to park or leave any travel trailer in any place except a licensed travel trailer park, provided that nothing in this article shall be construed to prohibit the storage of any travel trailer for any length of time when the travel trailer is not being used for living or sleeping purposes. 
(Code 1978, § 22-17; Code 1994, § 66-37)  
Sec. 26-21. - Park plan. 
All travel trailer parks shall conform to the following requirements: 
(1)  The park shall be located on a well-drained site, properly graded to ensure rapid drainage and freedom from stagnant pools of water. 
(2)  Travel trailer spaces shall be provided consisting of a minimum of 2,000 square feet for each space, which shall be at least 25 feet wide and clearly defined. Travel trailers shall be so harbored on each space that there shall be at least a 15-foot clearance between travel trailers. No travel trailers shall be located closer than five feet from any property line bounding the park. 
(3)  All travel trailer spaces shall abut upon a driveway of not less than 12 feet in width which shall have unobstructed access to a public street, alley or highway. All driveways shall be of all-weather construction, well-marked in the day-time and lighted at night with 25-watt lamps at intervals of 100 feet located approximately 15 feet from the ground. 
(4)  Walkways not less than two feet wide shall be provided from the travel trailer spaces to the service buildings. The walkways shall be of all-weather construction, well-marked in the day-time and lighted at night with 25-watt lamps at intervals of 100 feet located approximately 15 feet from the ground. 
(5)  Each park shall provide service buildings to house toilet facilities, bathing facilities, laundry facilities and other sanitary facilities as prescribed in this article. 
(6)  An electrical outlet supply at least 110 volts shall be provided for each travel trailer space. 
(Code 1978, § 22-18; Code 1994, § 66-38)  
Sec. 26-22. - Location. 
Travel trailer parks may be located as provided in the zoning ordinance of the city. Each boundary of the park must be at least 200 feet from any permanent residence building located outside the park, unless separated therefrom by a natural or artificial barrier, or unless a majority of the property owners residing in the area within 200 feet therefrom consent in writing to the establishment of the park. 
(Code 1978, § 22-19; Code 1994, § 66-39)  
Sec. 26-23. - Water supply. 
An adequate supply of pure water for drinking and domestic purposes shall be supplied to meet the requirements of the park. The water supply shall be obtained from faucets only. No common drinking cups shall be permitted. Cold water supply faucets shall be located on each travel trailer space. An adequate supply of hot water shall be provided at all times in the service building for bathing, washing and laundry facilities. 
(Code 1978, § 22-20; Code 1994, § 66-40)  
Sec. 26-24. - Fire protection. 
Every park shall be equipped at all times with one fire extinguisher in good working order for every ten travel trailer spaces, located not farther than 200 feet from each travel trailer space. No open fires shall be permitted at any place which would endanger life or property. No fires shall be left unattended at any time. 
(Code 1978, § 22-25; Code 1994, § 66-41)  
Sec. 26-25. - Sanitary facilities. 
Each park shall be provided with toilets, baths or showers, and other sanitary facilities which shall conform to the following requirements: 
(1)  Toilet facilities for men and women shall be either in separate buildings at least 20 feet apart or shall be separated, if in the same building. 
(2)  Toilet facilities for women shall consist of not less than one flush toilet for every 15 travel trailer spaces; one shower or bathtub for every 15 travel trailer spaces; and one lavatory for every 20 travel trailer spaces. Each toilet, shower or bathtub shall be in a private compartment. 
(3)  Toilet facilities for men shall consist of not less than one flush toilet for every 15 travel trailer spaces; one shower or bathtub for every 15 travel trailer spaces; one lavatory for every 15 travel trailer spaces; and one single urinal for every 15 travel trailer spaces. Each toilet, shower and bathtub shall be in a private compartment. 
(4)  Service buildings housing the toilet facilities shall be permanent structures complying with all applicable ordinances and statutes regulating buildings, electrical installations and plumbing and sanitation systems, and shall be located not closer than ten feet nor farther than 200 feet from any travel trailer space. 
(5)  The service buildings shall be well lighted at all times of the day or night; shall be well ventilated with screened openings; shall be constructed of such moisture-proof material, including painted woodwork, as shall permit repeated cleaning and washing; and shall be maintained at a temperature of at least 68 degrees Fahrenheit during the period from October 1 to May 1. The floors of the service buildings shall be of water-impervious material and shall slope to a floor drain connected with the sewage system. 
(6)  All service buildings and the grounds of the park shall be maintained in a clean, sightly condition and kept free of any condition that will menace the health of any occupant or the public or constitute a nuisance. 
(Code 1978, § 22-21; Code 1994, § 66-42)  
Sec. 26-26. - Laundry facilities. 
The laundry facilities in all parks shall be provided in the ratio of one double laundry tub and ironing board for every 30 travel trailer spaces. An electrical outlet supplying current sufficient to operate an iron shall be located conveniently near the ironing board. Drying spaces shall be provided sufficiently to accommodate the laundry of the travel trailer occupants. The service building housing the laundry facilities shall be a permanent structure complying with all applicable ordinances and statutes regulating buildings, electrical installations and plumbing and sanitation systems. 
(Code 1978, § 22-22; Code 1994, § 66-43)  
Sec. 26-27. - Sewage disposal. 
Waste from showers, bathtubs, toilets and laundries shall be discharged into a public sewer system in compliance with applicable ordinances or into a private sewer and disposal plant or septic tank system of such construction and in such manner as will present no health hazard. All kitchen sinks, washbasins, bath or shower tubs in any travel trailer harbored in any park may empty into a sanitary sink drain located on the travel trailer space. 
(Code 1978, § 22-23; Code 1994, § 66-44)  
Sec. 26-28. - Garbage, rubbish receptacles. 
Tightly covered garbage cans shall be provided in quantities adequate to permit disposal of all garbage and rubbish in parks. Garbage cans shall be located not farther than 200 feet from any travel trailer space. The cans shall be kept in sanitary condition at all times. Garbage and rubbish shall be collected and disposed of as frequently as may be necessary to ensure that the garbage cans shall not overflow. 
(Code 1978, § 22-24; Code 1994, § 66-45)  
Sec. 26-29. - Animals and pets. 
No owner or person in charge of any dog, cat or other pet animal shall permit it to commit any nuisance within the limits of any travel trailer park. 
(Code 1978, § 22-26; Code 1994, § 66-46)  
Sec. 26-30. - Register of occupants. 
(a)  It shall be the duty of the licensee under this article to keep a register containing a record of all travel trailer owners and occupants located within the park. The register shall contain the following information: 
(1)  Name and address of each occupant. 
(2)  The make, model and year of all automobiles and travel trailers. 
(3)  License number and owner of each travel trailer and automobile by which it is towed. 
(4)  The state issuing such license. 
(5)  The dates of arrival and departure of each travel trailer. 
(b)  The park shall keep the register required by this section available for inspection at all times by law enforcement officers, public health officials and other officials whose duties necessitate acquisition of the information contained in the register. The licensee shall be required at the end of each calendar month to deliver a copy of the month's register to the city license collector. The register records shall not be destroyed for a period of three years following the date of registration. 
(Code 1978, § 22-27; Code 1994, § 66-47)  
Secs. 26-31—26-48. - Reserved.  
DIVISION 2. - LICENSE 
 
Sec. 26-49. - Required. 
It is unlawful for any person to maintain or operate within the limits of the city any travel trailer park unless such person shall first obtain a license therefor. 
(Code 1978, § 22-35; Code 1994, § 66-76)  
Sec. 26-50. - Application. 
(a)  Applications for a travel trailer park license shall be filed with and issued by the city clerk. Applications shall be in writing signed by the applicant and shall contain the following: 
(1)  The name and address of the applicant. 
(2)  The location and legal description of the travel trailer park. 
(3)  A complete plan of the park showing compliance with section 26-21. 
(4)  Plans and specifications of all buildings and other improvements constructed or to be constructed within the travel trailer park. 
(5)  Such further information as may be required to enable a determination to be made if the proposed park will comply with legal requirements. 
(b)  The application and all accompanying plans and specifications required by this section shall be filed in triplicate. 
(Code 1978, § 22-36; Code 1994, § 66-77)  
Sec. 26-51. - Investigation of applicant; issuance. 
The city engineer and the police chief shall investigate the applicant under this division and inspect the proposed plans and specifications. If the applicant is found to be of good moral character, and the proposed travel trailer park will be in compliance with all provisions of this article and all applicable ordinances or statutes, the city clerk shall issue the license upon completion of the park according to the plans. 
(Code 1978, § 22-37; Code 1994, § 66-78)  
Sec. 26-52. - Fee. 
The license fee required under this division shall be as provided in the city fee schedule. 
(Code 1978, § 22-38; Code 1994, § 66-79)  
Sec. 26-53. - Posting. 
The license certificate issued under this division shall be conspicuously posted in the office of or on the premises of the travel trailer park at all times. 
(Code 1978, § 22-39; Code 1994, § 66-80)  
Sec. 26-54. - Revocation; reissuance. 
The city commission may revoke any license to maintain and operate a park when the licensee has been found guilty by a court of competent jurisdiction of violating any provision of this article. After such conviction, the license may be reissued if the circumstances leading to conviction have been remedied and the park is being maintained and operated in full compliance with law. 
(Code 1978, § 22-40; Code 1994, § 66-81)  
Secs. 26-55—26-81. - Reserved.  
ARTICLE III. - MANUFACTURED HOME PARKS  
DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 
 
Sec. 26-82. - Definitions. 
The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
Driveway means a minor private way used by vehicles and pedestrians on a manufactured home lot or used for common access to a small group of lots or facilities. 
License means a written license issued by the license inspector allowing a person to operate and maintain a manufactured home park under the provisions of this article and regulations issued under this article. 
License inspector means the agent or agents of the city responsible for approving the issuance of a license. 
Manufactured home means a structure which is subject to the federal act [National Manufactured Home Construction and Safety Standards Act of 1974, 42 USC 5401-5426] and which is transportable in one or more sections which, in the traveling mode, is eight body feet or more in width or 40 body feet or more in length, or, when erected on-site, is 320 or more square feet and which is built on a permanent chassis and designed to be used as a dwelling, with or without permanent foundation, when connected to the required utilities, and includes the plumbing, heating, air conditioning and electrical systems contained therein, and such term shall include any structure which meets all the requirements of this subsection except the size requirements and with respect to which the manufacturer voluntarily files with the federal department of housing and urban development a certification required by the secretary of housing and urban development and complies with the standards established under the federal act, except that such term shall not include any self-propelled recreational vehicle. 
Manufactured home lot means a parcel of land for the placement of a single manufactured home and the exclusive use of its occupants. 
Manufactured home park means a contiguous parcel of land which has been developed for the placement of manufactured homes and is owned by an individual, a firm, trust, partnership, public or private association or corporation. 
Manufactured home stand means that part of an individual lot which has been reserved for the placement of one manufactured home unit. 
Park management means the person who owns or has charge, care or control of the manufactured home park. 
Park street means a private way which affords principal means of access to individual manufactured home lots or auxiliary buildings. 
Permit means a written license issued by the license inspector permitting the construction, alteration and extension of a manufactured home park under the provisions of this article and all other city ordinances. 
Service building means a structure housing toilet, lavatory and such other facilities as may be required by this article. 
Sewer connection means the connection consisting of all pipes, fittings and appurtenances from the drain outlet of the manufactured home to the inlet of the corresponding sewer riser pipe of the sewerage system serving the manufactured home park. 
Sewer riser pipe means that portion of the sewer lateral which extends vertically to the ground elevation and terminates at each manufactured home lot. 
Water connection means the connection consisting of all pipes, fittings and appurtenances from the water riser pipe to the water inlet pipe of the distribution system within the manufactured home. 
Water riser pipe means that portion of the water supply system serving the manufactured home park which extends vertically to the ground elevation and terminates at a designated point at each manufactured home lot. 
(Code 1978, § 22-52; Code 1994, § 66-106)  
Sec. 26-83. - Exemptions from article provisions. 
(a)  Where the city commission finds that compliance with provisions of this article would result in undue hardship, an exemption may be granted by the city commission without impairing the intent and purpose of this article. Deviations from design, construction and installation provisions shall be brought into compliance with this article within a reasonable period of time based on economic feasibility of improvement, nature, significance and extent of deviation, depreciation of material, improvement and layout in use and other similar factors, within a minimum period not exceeding five years and a maximum period not exceeding 25 years. Such period shall begin after the license inspector has given notice of a certain and specific deviation from this article to the person to whom the permit or certification was issued. 
(b)  Gradual improvements to a higher degree of conformity shall be permissive, provided that there shall be complete conformity at the end of a period prescribed by the city commission. 
(Code 1978, § 22-53; Code 1994, § 66-107)  
Sec. 26-84. - Permanent improvements to be installed prior to occupancy. 
All permanent improvements shall be installed in manufactured home parks before occupancy is permitted. 
(Code 1978, § 22-54; Code 1994, § 66-108)  
Sec. 26-85. - Compliance with building code required. 
All construction in manufactured home parks shall be in compliance with the building code of the city. 
(Code 1978, § 22-55; Code 1994, § 66-109)  
Secs. 26-86—26-113. - Reserved.  
DIVISION 2. - CONSTRUCTION PERMIT 
 
Sec. 26-114. - Required. 
It is unlawful for any person to construct, alter or extend any manufactured home park within the limits of the city unless such person holds a valid permit issued by the city commission in the name of such person for the specific construction, alteration or extension proposed. 
(Code 1978, § 22-63; Code 1994, § 66-141)  
Sec. 26-115. - Applications requiring rezoning; fees; approval. 
(a)  Applications under this division requiring rezoning shall have attached to the request a preliminary site plan prepared by a licensed professional engineer of the state. The preliminary site plan shall contain the following: 
(1)  Name, address and telephone number of the applicant. 
(2)  The acreage and dimensions of the tract of land. 
(3)  Contour intervals of not more than two feet. 
(4)  North point, scale and date of drawing. 
(5)  The number, location and size of all manufactured home lots. 
(6)  The location and width of roadways and walkways. 
(7)  Location and size of designated recreation areas and other open space. 
(8)  One typical manufactured home lot showing proposed development, to include, but not be limited to, roadway, off-street parking, manufactured home stand, patio, storage and walkways. 
(9)  The location of water and sewer lines, both existing and proposed. 
(10)  Proposed location and size of all buildings to be constructed. 
(11)  Approximate location of all areas subject to flooding and the location, width and direction of flow of all water. 
(12)  Location and method of enclosing rubbish and garbage disposal areas. 
(13)  Location of all existing public streets within 200 feet of the proposed park. 
(14)  Location of all dwellings within 200 feet of the proposed park. 
(15)  Preliminary drainage plan of park showing proposed method of carrying surface water to an adequate point of disposition. 
(16)  Proposed development schedule. 
(b)  All applications requesting rezoning shall be accompanied by a deposit fee as set out in the city fee schedule, to be filed with the city clerk. A public hearing will be held in accordance with the zoning ordinance. 
(c)  The city commission, after receiving the recommendation from the city planning commission, shall either approve or disapprove the use of the land for a manufactured home park. If approved, no permit shall be issued until complete final engineering plans and specifications are approved and a performance bond is filed with the city clerk. 
(Code 1978, § 22-64; Code 1994, § 66-142)  
Sec. 26-116. - Permit applications; review; approval. 
(a)  All applications for manufactured home park permits shall be submitted to the city commission with preliminary plans as set out in section 26-115 and complete final engineering plans and specifications, prepared by a licensed professional engineer of the state showing, but not limited to, the following: 
(1)  Name, address and telephone number of the applicant. 
(2)  North point, scale and date of drawing. 
(3)  The number, location and size of all manufactured home lots. 
(4)  The acreage and dimensions of the tract of land. 
(5)  The locations and dimensions of: 
a.  Roadways, walkways, driveways; 
b.  Patios, storage areas, manufactured home stands. 
(6)  The location, size and dimensions of off-street parking. 
(7)  The number, location and dimensions of designated recreation areas. 
(8)  The location and details of lighting and electrical systems. 
(9)  The plans and specifications of: 
a.  Water and sewer lines; 
b.  Refuse disposal; 
c.  All buildings constructed or to be constructed; 
d.  Storm drainage. 
(10)  Landscaping plan. 
(11)  Any other site improvements. 
(b)  The preliminary site plan and complete final engineering plans and specifications shall be referred to a review committee made up of representatives of the following departments or agencies, including, but not limited to, city engineering, planning, building inspection, utilities, health and fire, who shall review and make recommendations to the city planning commission or the city commission. 
(c)  The city commission shall approve the issuance of a permit based on the approval of complete final engineering plans and specifications by the review committee and a performance bond filed with the city clerk. Permit approval is subject to beginning construction within two years of approval or permit shall be voided. 
(Code 1978, § 22-65; Code 1994, § 66-143)  
Sec. 26-117. - Performance bond; return. 
(a)  The performance bond for a manufactured home park permit, consisting of a cashier's check or surety bond, shall be made payable to the city in the amount equal to the full cost of improvements, including, but not limited to, roadways, walkways, water and sewer lines, patios, manufactured home stands, curb and gutter, community buildings, landscaping, and recreational facilities, as established by the city engineer. 
(b)  A copy of as-built plans shall be filed with the city engineer. The performance bond shall be returned by the city clerk when construction is completed. 
(Code 1978, § 22-66; Code 1994, § 66-144)  
Sec. 26-118. - Fee. 
The fee for the construction of a manufactured home park shall be as provided in the city fee schedule. 
(Code 1978, § 22-67; Code 1994, § 66-145)  
Secs. 26-119—26-149. - Reserved.  
DIVISION 3. - BUSINESS LICENSE 
 
Sec. 26-150. - Required. 
It shall be unlawful for any person to operate any mobile home park within the limits of the city unless such person holds a valid license issued annually by the city clerk in the name of such person for the specific mobile home park. 
(Code 1978, § 22-75; Code 1994, § 66-171)  
Sec. 26-151. - Application; renewal. 
Application for an original and renewal license under this division shall be made to and on a form provided by the city clerk, and shall be accompanied by the amount provided in the city fee schedule. 
(Code 1978, § 22-76; Code 1994, § 66-172)  
Sec. 26-152. - Issuance. 
Issuance of an original and renewal license by the city clerk shall determine whether there is compliance with this chapter and the city development regulations. Licenses are for a period of January 1 to December 31 of each year and are not prorated, transferable or refundable. 
(Code 1978, § 22-77; Code 1994, § 66-173)  
Sec. 26-153. - Monthly inhabited lot fee. 
In addition to the annual license fee, each park shall pay a fee for each manufactured home occupying a lot for a period more than 20 days each month. The monthly fee shall be paid in the amount provided in the city fee schedule. Fees may be paid each calendar quarter. 
(Code 1978, § 22-78; Code 1994, § 66-174)  
Sec. 26-154. - Hearing on denials. 
Any person whose application for a license under this division has been denied may request and shall be granted a hearing on the matter before the governing body under the procedure provided by division 5 of this article. 
(Code 1978, § 22-79; Code 1994, § 66-175)  
Sec. 26-155. - Transfer, sale or disposal of interest. 
Every person holding a license under this division shall give notice in writing to the city clerk within 24 hours after having sold, transferred, given away or otherwise disposed of interest in or control of any manufactured home park. Such notice shall include the name and address of the person succeeding to the ownership or control of such mobile home park. 
(Code 1978, § 22-80; Code 1994, § 66-176)  
Sec. 26-156. - Suspension. 
Whenever, upon inspection of any manufactured home park, the city inspector finds that conditions or practices exist which are in violation of any provision of this article, the city inspector shall give notice in writing in accordance with section 26-205 to the person to whom the license was issued that unless such conditions or practices are corrected within a reasonable period of time specified in the notice by the city inspector, the license shall be suspended. At the end of such period, the city inspector shall reinspect such conditions or practices in the manufactured home park, and if they have not been corrected the city clerk shall suspend the license and give notice in writing of such suspension to the person to whom the license is issued. Upon receipt of notice of such suspension, such person shall cease operation of such manufactured home park except as provided in section 26-206. 
(Code 1978, § 22-81; Code 1994, § 66-177)  
Secs. 26-157—26-178. - Reserved.  
DIVISION 4. - INSPECTIONS 
 
Sec. 26-179. - Authority of license inspector generally. 
The license inspector is authorized and directed to make such inspections as are necessary to determine satisfactory compliance with this article. 
(Code 1978, § 22-89; Code 1994, § 66-201)  
Sec. 26-180. - Right of entry. 
Subject to constitutional limitations, the license inspector shall have the power to enter at reasonable times upon any private or public property for the purpose of inspecting and investigating conditions relating to the enforcement of this article. 
(Code 1978, § 22-90; Code 1994, § 66-202)  
Sec. 26-181. - Inspections of register. 
It shall be the license inspector's power to inspect the register containing a record of all residents of the manufactured home park. 
(Code 1978, § 22-91; Code 1994, § 66-203)  
Sec. 26-182. - Duty of park management. 
It shall be the duty of every park management to give the license inspector free access to all lots at reasonable times for the purpose of inspection. 
(Code 1978, § 22-92; Code 1994, § 66-204)  
Sec. 26-183. - Duty of occupants. 
It shall be the duty of every occupant of a manufactured home park to give the owner thereof or any agent or employee access to any part of such manufactured home park at reasonable times for the purpose of making such repairs or alterations as are necessary to effect compliance with this article. 
(Code 1978, § 22-93; Code 1994, § 66-205)  
Secs. 26-184—26-204. - Reserved.  
DIVISION 5. - NOTICES OF VIOLATION, HEARINGS AND ORDERS 
 
Sec. 26-205. - Notice of violations. 
When the license inspector determines that there are reasonable grounds to believe that there has been a violation of any provision of this article, the license inspector shall give notice of such alleged violation to the person to whom the permit or license was issued, as provided in this section. Such notice shall: 
(1)  Be in writing; 
(2)  Include a statement of the reasons for its issuance; 
(3)  Allow a reasonable time for the performance of any act it requires; 
(4)  Be served upon the owner or his agent, as the case may require, provided that such notice or order shall be deemed to have been properly served upon such owner or agent when a copy thereof has been sent by registered mail to the owner's last-known address, or when the owner has been served with such notice by any method authorized or required by the laws of this state; 
(5)  Contain an outline of remedial action which, if taken, will affect compliance with the provisions of this article. 
(Code 1978, § 22-101; Code 1994, § 66-231)  
Sec. 26-206. - Hearing. 
Any person affected by any notice which has been issued in connection with the enforcement of any provisions of this article may request and shall be granted a hearing on the matter before the city commission, provided that such person shall file in the office of the license inspector a written petition requesting such hearing and setting forth a brief statement of the grounds therefor within ten days after the day the notice was served. The filing of the request for a hearing shall operate as a stay of the notice and of the suspension except in the case of an order issued under section 26-209. Upon receipt of such petition, the license inspector shall set a time and place for such hearing and shall give the petitioner written notice thereof. At such hearing the petitioner shall be given an opportunity to be heard and to show why such notice should be modified or withdrawn. The hearing shall be commenced not later than ten days after the day on which the petition was filed, provided that upon application of the petitioner the license inspector may postpone the date of the hearing for a reasonable time beyond such ten-day period when, in the license inspector's judgment, the petitioner has submitted good and sufficient reasons for such postponement. 
(Code 1978, § 22-102; Code 1994, § 66-232)  
Sec. 26-207. - Orders. 
After the hearing, the city commission shall make findings as to compliance with the provisions of this article and shall issue an order in writing sustaining, modifying or withdrawing the notice which shall be served as provided in section 26-205(4). Upon failure to comply with any order sustaining or modifying a notice, the license of the manufactured home park affected by the order shall be revoked. 
(Code 1978, § 22-103; Code 1994, § 66-233)
