(d)  Pending the issuance of revenue bonds authorized by this section, the city commission may issue revenue anticipation bonds of the city for the purpose of providing interim financing for a project, such revenue anticipation bonds being payable from revenue bonds issued to provide permanent financing for activities authorized by this article and the income, proceeds, revenues, and funds of the city derived from or held in connection with its sewer system. 
(Code 1994, § 103-9; Ord. No. 8077, § 1, 6-12-2018)  
Chapter 42 - STREETS, SIDEWALKS AND OTHER PUBLIC PLACES  
ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 
 
Sec. 42-1. - Use permit. 
(a)  Required. It is unlawful for any person to use the streets, alleys and other public places, including sidewalks and parking areas, for display, storage and sale of merchandise of any kind, or for exhibitions or advertising or other purposes other than customary traffic and common use of such public places, without first procuring a permit therefor. 
(b)  Procedure for issuance; fee. Application shall be made to the city clerk, on a form provided by the clerk, accompanied by a permit fee in the amount provided in the fee schedule. Permit issuance must be approved by the city manager, who may, in his discretion, waive the permit fee for religious, charitable or civic events. 
(c)  Insurance certificate prerequisite to issuance. Before a license shall be issued under this article, the applicant for such license shall file with the city clerk a certificate of liability insurance issued by a company authorized to do business in the state providing $1,000,000.00 per occurrence for bodily injury or property and $2,000,000.00 aggregate coverage. In the description of operations section shall include the following: "Sidewalk/Public Way Use" and "City of Leavenworth, its assigned, officers and affiliates are additional insured on a primary and non-contributory basis." The policy shall further include a provision that notice of change or cancellation shall be given to the city. In addition the applicant shall hold the city harmless for any and all claims that may arise against the city by any person for damages to persons or property caused by the licensee. 
(d)  Appeal. The decision of the city manager as to a permit under this article may be appealed to the city commission by filing a written request with the city clerk. The city commission shall consider the appeal at its next regular or special meeting. 
(Code 1978, §§ 32-19—32-21; Code 1994, §§ 102-36—102-40; Ord. No. 7280, § 1, 8-20-1996)  
Sec. 42-2. - Encumbering streets for property improvements. 
Nothing in this chapter shall prevent any person who may be improving his property from encumbering the streets, avenues or alleys under a permit issued by the clerk with the consent of the city engineer and payment of a fee as provided in the city fee schedule; but in the event of such encumbering of the streets with building material or earth necessary for the improvement being made, the contractor shall clean up the premises thoroughly within ten days from the completion of the work. 
(Code 1978, § 32-6; Code 1994, § 102-3)  
Sec. 42-3. - Use of metal tires and tracks on streets. 
It is unlawful for any person to operate any vehicle on any paved or hard-surfaced street or alley in the city with any metal tire tread, track, skid or outrigger pad in contact with the street or alley. 
(Code 1978, § 32-7; Code 1994, § 102-4)  
Sec. 42-4. - Minimum street width. 
No improvement or maintenance of any kind shall be done on any street originally dedicated which is not of the minimum width as recommended by the planning commission under this chapter, provided that no such improvement or maintenance will be done until the necessary minimum width of the street has been dedicated or deeded to the city. 
(Code 1978, § 32-86; Code 1994, § 102-101)  
Sec. 42-5. - Open cellar doors and gratings on sidewalks prohibited. 
It is unlawful for any person to keep open or leave open any cellar door or grating of any kind, in or upon any sidewalk in the city, or suffer or permit any cellar door or grating to be left open, except while necessarily open during the use thereof, and during such time such cellar door or grating shall be properly guarded and protected. 
(Code 1978, § 32-3; Code 1994, § 102-136)  
Sec. 42-6. - Sidewalk debris, ice and snow removal. 
(a)  Duty of owner to remove snow. It is the duty of every person in the possession and occupancy of any premises adjacent to any sidewalk or sidewalk ramp to remove from such areas on all sides of the premises that abut public sidewalks all snow within 24 hours after the snow has fallen, and all persons failing to do so shall be deemed guilty of a misdemeanor. 
(b)  Owner to keep abutting gutters clean. Every owner or occupant of any lot or piece of ground in the city shall keep the guttering adjacent to or in front of the premises owned or occupied or under control of such person clean and free from all dirt, filth, snow, ice, standing water, garbage or other matter of every kind and description. Every person who shall fail to comply with the provisions of this section shall, for each failure, after a reasonable time for such compliance, be guilty of a misdemeanor. 
(c)  Designation by city manager. The city manager shall designate an appropriate staff member to see that sidewalks are kept clean of dirt, snow and ice. 
(d)  Notice to property owner. When the staff member designated by the city manager finds any sidewalk covered with earth, snow or ice, the staff member shall notify the owner of the abutting lots to clean the sidewalk. If the owner shall fail to do so, or if the necessity is urgent, the staff member shall have such sidewalk cleaned and the cost of doing so shall be billed to the owner. 
(e)  Failure to pay; assessment of costs. If the property owner fails to pay the costs, the city clerk shall certify the assessment to the county clerk at the time other special assessments are certified for assessing to the tax rolls of the county. 
(Code 1978, §§ 32-143—32-146; Code 1994, §§ 102-196—102-199; Ord. No. 7855, § 1, 10-26-2010)  
Secs. 42-7—42-30. - Reserved.  
ARTICLE II. - SIDEWALK CONSTRUCTION AND REPAIR[1] 

Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
State Law reference— Authority for cities to provide for construction, repair, condemnation and reconstruction of sidewalks, K.S.A. 12-1801. 
 
Sec. 42-31. - Specifications. 
All sidewalks constructed, reconstructed or repaired in the city shall be constructed, reconstructed or repaired in accordance with the plans and specifications for the construction, repair and reconstruction of sidewalks, a copy of which is on file in the office of the city clerk and in the office of the city engineer, which plans and specifications are adopted and incorporated in this article by reference. 
(Code 1978, § 32-34; Code 1994, § 102-161) 
State Law reference— Similar provision, K.S.A. 12-1802.  
Sec. 42-32. - Petition. 
When a petition signed by not less than 25 citizens owning real estate in a precinct or ward of the city paying for the construction of a sidewalk in such precinct or ward is filed with the city clerk, the city commission may, in its discretion, by resolution, order such sidewalk constructed. 
(Code 1978, § 32-35; Code 1994, § 102-162) 
State Law reference— Similar provisions, K.S.A. 12-1803.  
Sec. 42-33. - Condemnation, reconstruction. 
When any sidewalk, in the opinion of the city commission, becomes inadequate or unsafe for the travel thereon, the city commission may adopt a resolution condemning such walk and providing for the construction of a new walk in place of the walk condemned. 
(Code 1978, § 32-36; Code 1994, § 102-163) 
State Law reference— Similar provisions, K.S.A. 12-1804.  
Sec. 42-34. - Notice to abutting owner. 
The resolution providing for the construction or reconstruction of a sidewalk shall give the owner of the abutting property not less than 30 days nor more than 60 days after its publication in which to construct or cause to be constructed or reconstructed the sidewalk at the owner's own expense. Such resolution shall be published once in the official city newspaper. If the sidewalk is not constructed by the property owner within the time specified, the city commission shall cause the work to be done by contract. 
(Code 1978, § 32-37; Code 1994, § 102-164) 
State Law reference— Similar provisions, K.S.A. 12-1805.  
Sec. 42-35. - Construction by abutting property owner. 
Nothing in this article shall prohibit the owner of property abutting on a street, who desires to construct or reconstruct a sidewalk, from doing so without any petition or condemning resolution if the owner does so at his own expense and in accordance with official plans and specifications and meets such other requirements as would have to be met if the sidewalk were constructed or reconstructed by the city, provided that if such property owner desires the walk to be constructed or reconstructed by the city and an assessment levied as provided in other cases, the owner shall file a request with the city commission and it may, in its discretion, provide for the construction or reconstruction of the sidewalk in the same manner as in cases where citizens or taxpayers file petitions. 
(Code 1978, § 32-38; Code 1994, § 102-165) 
State Law reference— Similar provisions, K.S.A. 12-1806.  
Sec. 42-36. - Grade. 
Where a grade has been established for a street, the grade for the sidewalk shall be established either in the same manner as the grade for the street was established or by reference to a stated distance above or below the street grade. Where no street grade has been established, the natural grade may be used. 
(Code 1978, § 32-39; Code 1994, § 102-166) 
State Law reference— Similar provisions, K.S.A. 12-1807.  
Sec. 42-37. - Repairs by owner or city. 
It is the duty of the owner of the abutting property to keep the sidewalk in repair, but the city may, after giving five days' notice to the owner or agent, if known, of the necessity for making repairs, and without notice if the lot or piece of land is unoccupied, make all necessary repairs at any time. Such repairs shall be done and the cost thereof assessed against the lot or piece of land abutting on the sidewalk so repaired as may be provided by law. 
(Code 1978, § 32-40; Code 1994, § 102-167) 
State Law reference— Similar provisions, K.S.A. 12-1808.  
Sec. 42-38. - Assessment of cost; old sidewalk materials. 
The cost of all sidewalks shall be assessed against the property abutting on the sidewalk, provided that where a sidewalk is condemned and a new sidewalk constructed, the materials of the old sidewalk shall be the property of the city, except in those cases where the property owner builds the new sidewalk and pays for such sidewalk without any assessment having to be made, and in such cases the owner shall remove the old material from the street. 
(Code 1978, § 32-41; Code 1994, § 102-168) 
State Law reference— Similar provisions, K.S.A. 12-1809.  
Sec. 42-39. - Levy, notice; limitation of actions. 
When a sidewalk has been constructed or reconstructed and where special assessments must be levied for the expense thereof, the city commission shall, as soon as the cost is ascertained, levy an assessment against the lot or piece of land chargeable therefor, by ordinance, and the property owner shall have 30 days after the publication of the ordinance within which to make full payment of the assessment. The city clerk shall mail a notice not less than 15 days prior to the end of such 30-day period to the owner of the property as shown on the records of the office of the register of deeds, but failure of the owner to receive the notice shall not affect the validity of the assessment. Any suit challenging the validity of the proceedings or the amount of the assessment must be filed within 30 days after publication of the assessment ordinance. 
(Code 1978, § 32-42; Code 1994, § 102-169) 
State Law reference— Similar provisions, K.S.A. 12-1810.  
Sec. 42-40. - Installment payments; interest; costs. 
The assessment levied under this article may be paid in one installment or in not more than five installments, at the discretion of the city commission, and when installments are certified to the county clerk, interest at the rate specified on the scrip or bonds authorized in this article to be issued shall be added, provided that when scrip or bonds are not issued, the interest on the one installment shall be four percent. The assessment shall include the cost of materials, labor, engineering and supervision, publication expense, cost of printing bonds, removing old sidewalk, and all other expenses properly chargeable against the project; provided further, that certain costs not ascertained at the time of figuring the expense, such as publication of the assessment ordinance, printing of bonds, etc., may be estimated; provided, further, that the costs relating to scrip or bonds shall be deducted if the assessment is paid within the 30-day period provided for in this article. 
(Code 1978, § 32-43; Code 1994, § 102-170) 
State Law reference— Similar provisions, K.S.A. 12-1811.  
Sec. 42-41. - Financing of cost; one installment. 
If the assessment under this article is levied in one installment, the cost of construction or reconstruction of sidewalks may be financed, until the assessment is paid, out of the fund provided for the maintenance of streets or the general improvement fund if such cost has been budgeted as an expense of such fund, and when the assessment and the interest thereon are paid they shall be credited to such fund; otherwise, the financing shall be by the issuance of sidewalk scrip or sidewalk bonds, as provided by law. 
(Code 1978, § 32-44; Code 1994, § 102-171) 
State Law reference— Similar provisions, K.S.A. 12-1812.  
Sec. 42-42. - Payment of cost by city. 
The cost of constructing, reconstructing and repairing all sidewalks abutting on lots or pieces of land belonging to the city or to the state or to the United States, and that portion of the sidewalk extending from the projected property line to the curb and which does not abut on and which is not in front of or alongside of any lot or piece of land, shall be paid for by the city unless the state or the United States shall pay the cost of the sidewalk abutting on property owned by the state or the United States, and may be paid for out of the fund provided for the maintenance of streets or the general improvement fund or by the issuance of scrip or bonds as provided by law, and the levying of taxes to pay such scrip or bonds. 
(Code 1978, § 32-45; Code 1994, § 102-172) 
State Law reference— Similar provisions, K.S.A. 12-1813.  
Sec. 42-43. - Approval of city engineer. 
The placement of all sidewalks to be constructed within the public right-of-way within the city shall be subject to the approval of the city engineer. 
(Code 1978, § 32-46; Code 1994, § 102-173)  
Sec. 42-44. - Altering location. 
The city manager may, in its discretion, alter or vary the location of sidewalks to be constructed on the front or side of any block upon the petition of a majority of the owners of a majority of the front feet of the property abutting upon the front or side of any block, or it may regulate the location independent of such petition. 
(Code 1978, § 32-47; Code 1994, § 102-174)  
Secs. 42-45—42-61. - Reserved.  
ARTICLE III. - CURB CUTS AND DRIVEWAY CONSTRUCTION 
 
Sec. 42-62. - Driveway construction permit. 
(a)  Required; exception. Any owner or occupant of premises desiring to construct and use a driveway from the curbline across any sidewalk adjacent to the owner's or occupant's premises shall obtain a permit from the city therefor; provided, however, that the city engineer may, in the paving or repaving of streets, or in the construction or reconstruction of curbing or guttering along any street, make provision for such driveways to the adjacent property without the issuing of a permit therefor as required by this article. 
(b)  Application. Any person desiring a permit under this article shall file with the city engineer an application, on the form provided by the city engineer, accompanied by a permit fee in the amount provided in the city fee schedule. 
(c)  Investigation of location; issuance. The city engineer shall inspect the location designated in the application and, if the driveway can be constructed so as not to interfere with the use of the sidewalk for pedestrians, and with safety to travel, the engineer shall issue a permit, designating the area, grade and specifications for the same. 
(Code 1978, §§ 32-70—32-74, 32-100(1), 32-101(1); Code 1994, §§ 102-251—102-255; Ord. No. 7086, § 1, 2-25-1992)  
Sec. 42-63. - Construction standards and restrictions. 
(a)  Location restrictions generally. No driveway entrance shall be located closer than 20 feet from the corner of the curbing at the intersection of any street and alley or closer than two feet from the side lot lines of any residential or commercial property or tract. 
(b)  Method of making curb cuts. When any curb is cut for the purpose of constructing a driveway entrance, It is entirely cut and removed, and the curb and gutter, if any, shall be replaced by sectional paving with expansion joints to prevent the breaking of the adjacent curb and gutter. The curb at each side of the entrance shall be replaced by a sectional curb rounded off on a radius of at least two feet. 
(c)  Interference with grade prohibited. Driveway entrances shall be constructed so as not to interfere with or change the grade of any existing street or sidewalk. 
(d)  Residential driveway curb cuts. Curb cuts for constructing residential driveways in the city shall not exceed 20 feet in width. 
(e)  Commercial driveway curb cuts. No curb cut for a commercial driveway entrance shall exceed 40 feet. The construction of multiple driveway entrances from the same street to the same commercial property or tract is prohibited unless there is no more than one commercial driveway entrance for each 50 linear feet of frontage on the same street and multiple commercial driveway entrances are separated by intervening curbing or space affording a parking area in the street of not less than 18 linear feet parallel to the curbing. 
(f)  Curb cutbacks for parking prohibited. No person shall remove or cut back the curbing along any street for the purpose of widening the area for parking vehicles in the street. 
(g)  Conformity to permit and approval of city engineer required. All work under the permit is done in conformity to the specifications in such permit and to the approval and satisfaction of the city engineer. 
(Code 1978, §§ 32-60, 32-99—32-102; Code 1994, §§ 102-226—102-230)  
Sec. 42-64. - Crossings over curbs, gutters prohibited. 
(a)  The construction or placing of crossing aprons across the gutter on any of the paved and curbed, or curbed and guttered streets in the city is prohibited. All such obstructions to the flow of water in the gutters and to the use of the full width of the streets by vehicles is declared a nuisance and a dangerous obstruction, and it is made the duty of all persons having heretofore constructed or placed such obstructions across any of the gutters on any of such streets to abate and remove such obstructions. 
(b)  It is the duty of the city engineer to notify and require the owners or occupants of the property adjacent to the location of any such aprons or constructions of wood or other material now placed, maintained or used, to remove the same within ten days after the service of such notice. Upon the failure, neglect or refusal to comply with such notice, it is made the duty of the city engineer to have such obstruction removed. 
(Code 1978, § 32-61; Code 1994, § 102-231)  
Sec. 42-65. - Display of address or house numbers on curbs prohibited. 
It is unlawful to paint, stamp or otherwise display an address or house number on curbs.  
Secs. 42-66—42-88. - Reserved.  
ARTICLE IV. - EXCAVATIONS, FILL AND OTHER EARTH MOVING  
DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 
 
Sec. 42-89. - Definitions. 
The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
Excavation means and includes any function of earth moving, digging, scooping or cutting in which heavy power-driven equipment is used. 
(Code 1978, § 11-16; Code 1994, § 46-181)  
Sec. 42-90. - Applicability. 
The restrictions contained in this article shall apply to all real property, both public and private, within the city. 
(Code 1978, § 11-17; Code 1994, § 46-182)  
Sec. 42-91. - Stripping topsoil prohibited; exception. 
It is unlawful for any person to excavate or strip topsoil from any property within the corporate limits of the city, provided that this restriction shall not apply when the property is being graded or otherwise prepared for the construction thereon of a building or other improvement. 
(Code 1978, § 11-19; Code 1994, § 46-184)  
Sec. 42-92. - Tunneling under streets unlawful. 
Tunneling under the streets, alleys or public properties of the city is unlawful. 
(Code 1978, § 32-115; Code 1994, § 102-287)  
Sec. 42-93. - Gas, waterline connections. 
Any connection of gas or water lines shall be pushed or bored. No opening should be larger than three feet by four feet, provided larger openings may be made when approved by the director of public works or his designated representative by endorsement of the permit issued by the city inspector. 
(Code 1978, § 32-116; Code 1994, § 102-288)  
Secs. 42-94—42-114. - Reserved.  
DIVISION 2. - PERMIT 
 
Sec. 42-115. - Permit required. 
It is unlawful for any person to engage in the performance of excavation, fill or earth moving or within the city without first having obtained a permit from the city inspector for each such purpose and paying the permit fee as provided in the city fee schedule. 
(Code 1978, § 11-18; Code 1994, § 46-183; Ord. No. 7086, § 1, 2-25-1992) 
Editor's note— See also land disturbance permit requirements in section 18-91.  
Sec. 42-116. - Insurance certificate prerequisite to issuance. 
Before a license shall be issued under this article, the applicant for such license shall file with the city clerk a certificate of liability insurance issued by a company authorized to do business in the state providing $1,000,000.00 per occurrence for bodily injury or $2,000,000.00 aggregate coverage. The description of operations section shall include the following: "Excavations, Fill and Earth Moving" and "City of Leavenworth, its assigned officers and affiliates are additional insured on a primary and non-contributory basis." The policy shall further include a provision that notice of change or cancellation shall be given to the city. In addition the applicant shall hold the city harmless for any and all claims that may arise against the city by any person for damages to persons or property caused by the licensee. 
(Code 1978, § 32-130; Code 1994, § 102-314)  
Sec. 42-117. - Issuance. 
The city inspector, being satisfied that the proposed excavation or opening is authorized under an ordinance of the city, that the excavation or opening is necessary, and that the applicant has complied with the ordinances of the city governing the making of such proposed excavation or opening, shall issue to the applicant a permit in writing, signed by the inspector, designating the location, number of openings, the purpose for which the excavation or opening is to be made, and the time within which the undertaking is to be completed. 
(Code 1978, § 32-131; Code 1994, § 102-315)  
Secs. 42-118—42-147. - Reserved.  
DIVISION 3. - STANDARDS AND SPECIFICATIONS 
 
Sec. 42-148. - Backfilling, topping and paving; work to be performed by contractor; notice required. 
All backfilling, topping or paving in any street, alley, sidewalk or public ground shall be done by the company making the excavation. The inspection office shall be notified of the location of all cuts prior to their being made and shall be informed when backfilling operations are ready to begin. 
(Code 1978, § 32-118; Code 1994, § 102-290)  
Sec. 42-149. - Materials and procedure. 
The following specifications shall apply to excavations made under this article: 
(1)  AB-3 is to be used for backfill up to the lower surface of the existing surface materials. The AB-3 shall be placed in successive lifts of not more than 12 inches and each lift is to be compacted by mechanical means. The AB-3 is to contain moisture sufficient to result in a finished base equal to or greater than the density of the adjacent material. 
(2)  Surfacing is to be placed 12 inches minimum on each side of a trench, including the beginning and ending of trenches. 
(3)  On all curbed and guttered streets, regardless of existing surface, the street cut shall be filled with 3,000 psi concrete to a minimum depth of six inches or from the base of the original pavement, whichever is the greater. The concrete shall be flat-finished and neatly edged. Seal coat surfacings shall be replaced with a minimum of six inches of asphalt. Hot mix asphalt shall be used when available. If seasonal or availability conditions warrant, cold mix asphalt may be used, provided the cold mix equals the hot mix density. Rock or gravel roads and alleys are to be backfilled with AB-3 compacted to a density equal to or greater than the adjacent undisturbed area, then covered with road rock that equals the original surface in size. 
(4)  Asphalt, asphalt-brick combination and concrete are to be saw cut to neat lines. The saw cut may be made when the cut is filled and is not required to be done at the time the cut is opened. 
(5)  All finished surfaces are to be checked with a straight edge or string line at the time of finishing or tamping of the asphalt. 
(6)  Excavations under sidewalks are to be backfilled with AB-3 and thoroughly tamped to achieve a density to prevent settlement. 
(7)  Excavations extending back of the curbline or beyond the ditch line of gravel or seal coated streets shall be backfilled with the material from the excavation and, further, the initial four feet shall be backfilled in six-inch lifts and tamped to 95 percent of optimum density using the standard proctor test as performed by a commercial testing laboratory. Wet material that will not meet optimum moisture density shall be modified by the addition of four percent of hydrated or quick lime by volume. Existing ground cover is to be replaced by either stockpiled sod or freshly cut sod or seeding and fertilizer as may be approved by the director of public works or his designated representative when the backfill is completed. Sodding or seeding is expected to be completed during the same day or the next working day. Backfill with frozen dirt may be done with the explicit understanding that the trench fill material is to be re-excavated and tamped when the ground thaws. If the inspection office declares that an excavation appears not to be meeting this standard, the contractor may elect the following: 
a.  To have a minimum of two Shelby tube samples taken in the finished excavation to determine the in-place density to be compared to an adjacent undisturbed sample. If the compacted materials fail to equal or exceed the level of adjacent soil density values, in the opinion of the commercial testing laboratory, then the contractor will remove and replace all the trench fill materials. The building inspector or designated representative shall be sole judge of the quality of the fill. 
b.  Replace the fill in its entirety to the heretofore enumerated standards. 
(8)  All service cut trenches are to have a minimum width of 18 inches. 
(Code 1978, § 32-119; Code 1994, § 102-291)  
Sec. 42-150. - Notice and warnings. 
The person making a street cut is responsible for giving notice and providing warning to the pedestrian and vehicular traffic. This includes notification to police dispatch when traffic is prevented. They shall at all times during the progress of the work maintain barricades and shall display flashing lights or reflective surfaces during the hours of darkness. 
(Code 1978, § 32-117; Code 1994, § 102-289)  
Sec. 42-151. - Barriers and guards required for excavation or construction on or near sidewalks. 
It is the duty of every person who constructs any sidewalk or excavate under any sidewalk of the city to securely guard the area by fence or barricade. 
(Code 1978, § 32-4; Code 1994, § 102-1)  
Sec. 42-152. - Removal of barricades, lights. 
It is unlawful for any person to remove, destroy or otherwise damage any barricade, warning lights or other warning devices as required by this Code except for the removal by such person who shall be in charge of such work. 
(Code 1978, § 32-5; Code 1994, § 102-2) 
State Law reference— Similar provisions, K.S.A. 68-2106.  
Sec. 42-153. - Defective workmanship and materials. 
During a period of two years from and after the date that any backfilling operation is completed, the contractor shall make all needed repairs arising out of defective workmanship or materials, or both, which, in the judgment of the city, shall become necessary during such period. 
(Code 1978, § 32-120; Code 1994, § 102-292)  
Sec. 42-154. - Standard instructions available. 
Standard instructions will be available at the city inspector's office to be used as a reference and guide to workmanship required of any person authorized to make or fill street cuts. 
(Code 1978, § 32-114; Code 1994, § 102-286)  
Secs. 42-155—42-176. - Reserved.  
ARTICLE V. - STREET TREES[2] 

Footnotes: 
--- (2) --- 
State Law reference— Trees and shrubbery, K.S.A. 12-3201 et seq. 
 
Sec. 42-177. - Definitions. 
The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
Park means and includes all public parks having individual names, and all areas owned by the city or to which the public has free access as a park. 
Tree means trees, shrubs, bushes and all other woody vegetation. 
(Code 1978, § 37-39; Code 1994, § 118-62)  
Sec. 42-178. - Authority of city to plant, maintain and remove. 
The park department shall have the right to plant, trim, spray, preserve and remove trees, plants and shrubs within the line of all streets, alleys, avenues, lanes, squares and public grounds, as may be necessary to ensure safety or to preserve the symmetry and beauty of such public grounds. The parks and recreation director may remove or cause or order to be removed any tree or part thereof which is in an unsafe condition or which by reason of its nature is injurious to sewers or other public improvements, or is affected with any injurious fungus, insect or other pest. 
(Code 1978, § 37-43; Code 1994, § 118-66)  
Sec. 42-179. - Rules and regulations by parks and recreation director. 
The parks and recreation director may make additional rules and regulations pertaining to the planting, removal and care of trees, bushes and shrubs not inconsistent with the provisions of this article, and no person shall fail to obey any such rules or regulations. 
(Code 1978, § 37-51; Code 1994, § 118-74)  
Sec. 42-180. - Interference with parks and recreation director. 
It is unlawful for any person to prevent, delay or interfere with the parks and recreation director, or any of his agents, while engaging in and about the planting, cultivating, mulching, pruning, spraying or removing of any trees, plants or shrubs in or upon any public right-of-way, public park or upon any private grounds as authorized in this article. 
(Code 1978, § 37-50; Code 1994, § 118-73)  
Sec. 42-181. - Planting procedure. 
Tree planting on any right-of-way shall be performed in strict accordance with the terms of this article. The parks and recreation director shall have the authority to require a detailed declaration of intentions prior to planting of street trees by property owners. Planting of street trees shall conform to the following standards: 
(1)  Trees must not be less than one inch in diameter of trunk one foot above the ground. 
(2)  All trees from one inch to three inches in diameter of trunk one foot above the ground must be protected and supported by tree guards. 
(3)  No tree shall be placed so as to cause a traffic hazard. 
(4)  Trees shall be planted at least 30 feet to 50 feet apart except where a special permit is obtained from the parks and recreation director. 
(5)  No tree shall be planted where the clear space between the curb and sidewalk is less than three feet. 
(6)  No tree shall be planted nearer than one foot from the curbline or outer line of the sidewalk. 
(7)  No tree shall be planted nearer than 35 feet from the right-of-way lines of two intersecting streets. 
(Code 1978, § 37-41; Code 1994, § 118-64)  
Sec. 42-182. - Visibility at intersections. 
All trees, shrubs and bushes located on the triangle formed by two right-of-way lines at the intersection of two streets and the line connecting the points a distance of 35 feet each way from the intersection of the right-of-way lines on any corner lot within the city shall not be permitted to grow to a height of more than 24 inches above the road level of any street, avenue or alley, in order that the view of the driver of a vehicle approaching a street intersection shall not be obstructed. No trees may be planted in this area. 
(Code 1978, § 37-44; Code 1994, § 118-67)  
Sec. 42-183. - Damage to trees prohibited. 
No person shall, without authority, break, injure, mutilate, kill or destroy any tree or shrub, or set any fire, or the heat thereof, to injure any portion of any tree. No person owning, using or having control or charge of gas or any other substance deleterious to tree life shall allow such gas or other deleterious substance to come in contact with the soil surrounding the roots of any tree, shrub or plant. 
(Code 1978, § 37-42; Code 1994, § 118-65)  
Sec. 42-184. - Duties of property owners and others. 
(a)  Restriction on trees owner may plant, maintain and remove. The owner of land abutting on any street may, when acting within the provisions of this article, prune, spray, plant or remove trees in that part of the street abutting such owner's land not used for public travel. 
(b)  Owner to remove dead trees and limbs. It is the duty of the owner, occupant or person in charge of any lot or piece of ground in the city to provide for the removal of all dead trees and dead tree limbs from such lot or piece of ground, including the parking areas adjacent thereto. Any such condition shall be deemed to be a nuisance and in case of the failure, neglect or refusal of the owner, occupant or person in charge of the lot or piece of ground to provide for such removal, the city shall cause such removal to be done and charge the entire cost of such removal against the lot or piece of ground in the manner provided in section 28-5. 
(c)  Permit required for deviation from city regulations. A street tree permit is required only when the owner of property intends to deviate from the rules and regulations contained within this article; except that when a property owner requests the city to plant a tree on the right-of-way in front of the owner's property, the owner shall be required to sign a street tree permit agreeing to care for such tree. 
(d)  Trimming by owner required. Every owner of any tree overhanging any street or right-of-way within the city shall trim the branches so that such branches shall not obstruct the light from any street lamp or obstruct the view of any street intersection and so that there shall be a clear space of ten feet above the surface of the street or right-of-way. The owner shall remove all dead, diseased or dangerous trees, or broken or decayed limbs which constitute a menace to the safety of the public. The city shall have the right to trim any tree or shrub on private property when it interferes with the proper spread of light along the street from a street light or interferes with the visibility of any traffic control device or sign, such trimming to be confined to the area immediately above the right-of-way. 
(e)  Trimming by persons maintaining poles and wires required. To prevent the destruction of shade and ornamental trees along the streets and highways of the city, all persons maintaining wires or poles in the city, their agents, servants and employees are prohibited from cutting or trimming trees except under the direction of the city manager or some other person duly authorized by the city manager to do so. 
(Code 1978, §§ 37-1, 37-40, 37-45, 37-48, 37-49; Code 1994, §§ 118-1, 118-63, 118-68, 118-71, 118-72)  
Sec. 42-185. - Violations and enforcement. 
(a)  Notice of violation. If a violation of this article occurs, the city shall serve notice on the owner or other occupant of the affected property identifying the violation and stating that the owner or occupant has ten days to correct the violation. If the violation is not corrected within ten days after service of the notice, the owner or occupant shall be guilty of a misdemeanor. 
(b)  Service of notice. The notice under this section may be served by delivering the notice or a copy thereof to the owner or occupant, or by leaving the notice at the owner's or occupant's usual place of business or abode; or if the owner is a nonresident of the city, by posting the notice in a conspicuous place upon the lot in front of which the trees are located. 
(c)  Abatement by city; costs. If an owner or occupant fails to correct the violation within the time permitted, the violation may be corrected by the city at the expense of the owner or occupant and the costs thereof shall be collected as provided in section 28-5. 
(Code 1978, §§ 37-46, 37-47; Code 1994, §§ 118-69, 118-70)  
Secs. 42-186—42-209. - Reserved.  
ARTICLE VI. - STREET ADDRESSES 
 
Sec. 42-210. - Duty of owners and occupants to ensure building numbering. 
It is the duty of all persons owning or occupying buildings fronting on any public street, avenue or public grounds of the city to cause such buildings to be numbered in conformity with the provisions of this article. 
(Code 1978, § 32-158; Code 1994, § 102-371; Ord. No. 6941, § 1(32-158), 9-13-1988)  
Sec. 42-211. - Numbering system generally. 
All the streets of the city shall be so named and numbered as will best suit public safety and achieve an efficient manner of locating addresses for public travel and commerce. 
(Code 1978, § 32-159; Code 1994, § 102-372; Ord. No. 6941, § 1(32-159), 9-13-1988)  
Sec. 42-212. - North and south streets numbering. 
(a)  Shawnee Street shall constitute the base for a grid of all streets running north and south. All north and south streets shall be numbered according to a north-south grid map on file in the city clerk's office and made part of this article as though set forth herein. All parts of streets running north or northerly from Shawnee Street shall be designated respectively by the prefix "North" to the names of such streets, and all parts of streets running south or southerly from Shawnee Street shall be designated respectively by the prefix "South" to the names of such streets. All streets running north and south which do not intersect Shawnee Street shall be numbered according to the grid map and contain a prefix only when needed. 
(b)  Streets that run north and south shall be numbered, commencing on the north side of Shawnee Street with number 100, with alternating even numbers on the right side from the point of starting and with alternating odd numbers on the left side, e.g.: the number 101 on the southeast corner of Shawnee Street and all streets running south, and the northwest corner of all streets running north; 201 on the southeast or northwest corner of the second street from Shawnee Street, as the case may be, going north or south; 300 in the third block, and 400 in the fourth block, and so on. 
(Code 1978, §§ 32-160, 32-162; Code 1994, §§ 102-373, 102-374; Ord. No. 6941, §§ 1(32-160), (32-161), 9-13-1988)  
Sec. 42-213. - East and west street numbering. 
All the streets of the city which run east and west shall be numbered according to an east-west grid map on file in the office of the city clerk and adopted as though set forth in this article. The grid starts with the number one at the Missouri River and increases to the west with the numbers alternating from side to side so that even numbers shall be on the north side and odd numbers on the south side. 
(Code 1978, § 32-163; Code 1994, § 102-375; Ord. No. 6941, § 1(32-162), 9-13-1988)  
Sec. 42-214. - Size and placement of numbers. 
All buildings shall display a number which is visible from the street. If the number is placed on the building itself, the size of the number shall not be less than four inches in length, and shall be legible and conspicuously placed on, above or by the side of the door of each building fronting on or adjacent to any street, avenue or public ground. 
(Code 1978, § 32-164; Code 1994, § 102-376; Ord. No. 6941, § 1(32-163), 9-13-1988)  
Sec. 42-215. - Application to new buildings. 
All numbering of streets, avenues or public grounds in this city shall be in accordance with the provisions of this article, and when the lots or parts of lots adjacent to or abutting upon any street, avenue or public grounds are vacant, or have no building upon them, no number will be required; but if at any time a building shall be erected upon such lots or parts of lots, the owner or occupant of the building shall, within 30 days after its completion, be subject to all the provisions of this article with reference to numbering such building. 
(Code 1978, § 32-165; Code 1994, § 102-377; Ord. No. 6941, § 1(32-164), 9-13-1988)  
Sec. 42-216. - Posting house numbers on curbs, sidewalks and other city property prohibited. 
It is unlawful for any person or business entity to stamp, paint or otherwise place house numbers on city curbs, sidewalks or other public property.  
Sec. 42-217. - Location of street signs. 
Street signs shall be located at all street intersections and placed so as to maximize visibility to traffic from all directions. The sign location shall be determined by the operations superintendent. 
(Code 1994, § 102-378; Ord. No. 6941, § 1(32-165), 9-13-1988)  
Secs. 42-218—42-242. - Reserved.  
ARTICLE VII. - SPECIAL EVENTS 
 
Sec. 42-243. - Permit required; exceptions. 
No person shall engage in, participate in, aid, form or start any parade, run, walk or other organized activity on the public streets referred to in this article as a special event, unless a special event permit shall have been obtained from the office of the city clerk; provided, however, that this article shall not apply to funeral processions, students going to and from school classes or participating in educational activities under the immediate direction and supervision of the proper school authorities or a governmental agency acting within the scope of its functions. 
(Code 1978, § 32-185; Code 1994, § 102-421; Ord. No. 7088, § 1(32-185), 2-25-1992)  
Sec. 42-244. - Application for permit. 
Application for a special event permit is made in writing to the city clerk, on forms provided by the city clerk, at least eight weeks in advance of the date of the proposed special event. The city manager may, in his discretion, consider any application for a permit to conduct a special event which is filed less than eight weeks prior to the date such special event is to be conducted. The application shall contain the following information so that adequate arrangements may be made for the proper policing: 
(1)  The name, address and telephone number of the person seeking to conduct such a special event. If he is not a resident of the city, then there shall be listed the name, address and telephone number of a local representative which should be included along with the name, address and telephone number of the sponsoring organization and its chief officer. 
(2)  If the special event is proposed to be conducted for, on behalf of, or by an organization, the name, address and telephone number of the headquarters of the organization, and of the authorized and responsible heads of such organization. 
(3)  The date and hours when the special event is to be conducted. 
(4)  The proposed special event route and location of any reviewing stands. 
(5)  The estimated number of people, vehicles and animals, and the types of animals, that will take part in the special event. 
(6)  Any additional information which the city staff shall find reasonably necessary to make a fair determination as to whether a permit should be issued. 
(Code 1978, § 32-186; Code 1994, § 102-422; Ord. No. 7088, § 1(32-186), 2-25-1992)  
Sec. 42-245. - Standards for issuance. 
The city clerk, with the approval of the city manager, shall issue a permit under this article when, from a consideration of the application and other available information, he finds that: 
(1)  The conduct of the special event will not substantially interrupt the safe and orderly movement of other traffic contiguous to its route. 
(2)  The conduct of the special event will not require the diversion of so great a number of police officers of the city to properly police the line of movement and the areas contiguous thereto as to prevent normal police protection to the city. 
(3)  The concentration of persons, animals and vehicles at assembly points of the special event will not unduly interfere with proper fire and police protection of, or ambulance service to, areas contiguous to such assembly area. 
(4)  The conduct of such special event will not adversely affect or interfere with the movement of firefighting equipment in route to a fire. 
(5)  The conduct of the special event is not reasonably likely to cause injury to persons or property, to provoke disorderly conduct or to create a disturbance. 
(6)  The special event is scheduled to move from its point of origin to its point of termination expeditiously and without unreasonable delays in route. 
(7)  The special event is not to held for the sole purpose of advertising any product, goods or event and is not designed to be held purely for private profit. 
(8)  The special event will not substantially interfere with any other special event for which a permit has already been granted. 
(9)  The applicant has provided for services of that number and type of special event monitors which the police chief considers reasonably necessary to ensure that the special event will be conducted in conformity with the special event permit. 
(10)  The applicant has not materially misrepresented any facts or information set forth in his application for a special event permit. 
(Code 1978, § 32-187; Code 1994, § 102-423; Ord. No. 7088, § 1(32-187), 2-25-1992)  
Sec. 42-246. - Liability insurance required. 
Before a license shall be issued under this article, the applicant for such license shall file with the city clerk a certificate of liability insurance issued by a company authorized to do business in the state providing $1,000,000.00 per occurrence for bodily injury or property and $2,000,000.00 aggregate coverage. In the description of operations section shall include the name of the activity and "City of Leavenworth, its assigned, officers and affiliates are additional insured on a primary and non-contributory basis." The policy shall further include a provision that notice of change or cancellation shall be given to the city. In addition the applicant shall hold the city harmless for any and all claims that may arise against the city by any person for damages to persons or property caused by the licensee. 
(Code 1978, § 32-187; Code 1994, § 102-423; Ord. No. 7088, § 1(32-187), 2-25-1992)  
Sec. 42-247. - Appeal procedure upon denial of application. 
Upon a denial by the city manager of an application made pursuant to this article, the applicant may appeal from the determination of the city manager by filing a written notice of appeal to the city clerk for hearing by the city commissioners. The city commission shall hear the appeal at its next regular meeting. Upon such appeal, the city commission may reverse, affirm or modify in any regard the determination of the city manager. 
(Code 1978, § 32-188; Code 1994, § 102-424; Ord. No. 7088, § 1(32-188), 2-25-1992)  
Sec. 42-248. - Notice of issuance. 
Upon the approval of a special event permit, the city clerk shall send a copy of the approved application to the applicant, the police chief and the fire chief. 
(Code 1978, § 32-189; Code 1994, § 102-25; Ord. No. 7088, § 1(32-189), 2-25-1992)  
Sec. 42-249. - Revocation. 
The city manager or his designated representative shall have the authority to revoke a special event permit issued under this article upon application of the standards for issuance as set forth in this article. 
(Code 1978, § 32-193; Code 1994, § 102-427; Ord. No. 7088, § 1(32-192), 2-25-1992)  
Sec. 42-250. - Special event route, reviewing stands and assembly points to be determined by police chief. 
The special event will follow the designated special event route as determined by the police chief, and state the location of any reviewing stands, if any. The proposed special event will assemble and disband in the staging area as determined by the police chief. 
(Code 1978, § 32-186; Code 1994, § 102-422; Ord. No. 7088, § 1(32-186), 2-25-1992)  
Sec. 42-251. - Interference with private property or restricted areas prohibited. 
No assembling or disbanding will encroach upon, occupy or traverse any private property or restricted area. 
(Code 1978, § 32-186; Code 1994, § 102-422; Ord. No. 7088, § 1(32-186), 2-25-1992)  
Sec. 42-252. - Compliance with applicable law required; throwing items from special event vehicles prohibited. 
A permittee under this article shall comply with all permit directions and conditions and with all applicable laws and ordinances and shall prohibit any candy, gum or other items from being thrown, tossed or otherwise distributed from vehicles in the special event. 
(Code 1978, § 32-191; Code 1994, § 102-426; Ord. No. 7088, § 1(32-190), 2-25-1992)  
Sec. 42-253. - Public conduct during special event. 
(a)  Interference. No person shall unreasonably hamper, obstruct, impede or interfere with any special event assembly or with any person, vehicle or animal participating or used in a special event. 
(b)  Driving through special events. No driver of a vehicle shall drive between the vehicles or persons comprising a special event when such vehicles or persons are in motion and are conspicuously designated as a special event. 
(c)  Parking on special event route. The police chief shall have the authority, when reasonably necessary, to prohibit or restrict the parking of vehicles along a highway or part thereof constituting a part of the route of a special event. The police chief shall post signs to such effect, and it is unlawful for any person to park or leave unattended any vehicle in violation thereof. No person shall be liable for parking on a street unposted in violation of this section. 
(Code 1978, § 32-192; Code 1994, § 102-402; Ord. No. 7088, § 1(32-191), 2-25-1992)  
Sec. 42-254. - Violations. 
It is deemed unlawful to intentionally give false information in obtaining a permit or for any person to violate or fail to comply with the provisions of this article. 
(Code 1978, § 32-194; Code 1994, § 102-428; Ord. No. 7088, § 1(32-193), 2-25-1992)  
Chapter 44 - TRAFFIC AND VEHICLES[1]

State Law reference— Traffic and vehicles, K.S.A. 8-113 et seq.; powers of local authorities, K.S.A. 8-2002. 
 
ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 
 
Sec. 44-1. - Standard traffic ordinance adopted; amendments. 
(a)  Adoption. There is hereby incorporated by reference for the purpose of regulating traffic within the corporate limits of the city that certain standard traffic ordinance known as the Standard Traffic Ordinance for Kansas Cities, Edition of 2019, prepared and published in book form by the League of Kansas Municipalities, Topeka, Kansas, save and except such articles, sections, parts or portions as are hereafter omitted, deleted, modified, or changed. 
(b)  Marked copies on file. One copy of said Standard Traffic Ordinance shall be marked or stamped "Official Copy as Adopted by Ordinance No. 8109 " with all sections and portions thereof intended to be omitted or changed clearly marked to show any such omission or change and to which shall be attached a copy of Ordinance No. 8109 , and filed with the city clerk, to be open to inspection and available to the public at all reasonable business hours. The police department, municipal judge, and all administrative departments of the city charged with enforcement of the ordinance shall be supplied, at the cost of the city, such number of official copies of such Standard Traffic Ordinance similarly marked, as may be deemed expedient. 
(c)  Amendments. The standard traffic ordinance adopted in this section is adopted subject to the following local amendments: 
(1)  Article 14. Miscellaneous Rules, section 114.5, is amended, adding, as follows: 
(e) As provided by subsection (a) (2), it shall be unlawful to operate a worksite utility vehicle except for public safety and city maintenance staff within the corporate limits of the city. 
(2)  Article 15. Operation of Bicycles, Motorized Bicycles, and Play Vehicles, section 135.1 is amended, adding the following: 
(e) As provided in subsection (c), "it is unlawful to operate or for the owner to permit the operation of an electric-assisted scooter upon a street, highway, public parking lot, or public parks area." 
(d)  Omitting. Section 69(d): Article II, Pedestrians, of said Standard Traffic Ordinance relating to city permits for soliciting of contributions is hereby declared to be omitted and deleted. 
(Code 1978, §§ 35-1, 35-2; Code 1994, §§ 110-1, 110-2, 110-2.1, 110-2.2; Ord. No. 8048, § 1, 7-11-2017; Ord. No. 8085, § 1, 8-28-2018; Ord. No. 8109 , § 1, 8-27-2019)  
Sec. 44-2. - Manual on school crossing controls adopted by reference. 
The Kansas Guidelines for School Crossing Guards, published by the state department of transportation, is adopted and incorporated by reference as if set out in full in this chapter. There shall be a copy of the publication kept on file in the office of the city clerk and available for inspection by the public at all reasonable business hours. The filed copies of the publication shall be marked "Official Copy as Incorporated by the Code of Ordinances of Leavenworth, Kansas." All deleted sections or portions of the filed copies of such publication shall be clearly marked to show local amendments to the publication. 
(Code 1978, §§ 35-16, 35-17; Code 1994, §§ 110-36, 110-37) 
State Law reference— Adoption by reference authorized, K.S.A. 12-3009 et seq., 12-3301 et seq.  
Sec. 44-3. - Intersection traffic control device master index adopted by reference. 
The 2019 Intersection Traffic Control Device Master Index, prepared and published by the city in book form for the purpose of regulating intersection traffic control devices within the city, is adopted as though fully set forth herein. One copy of the adopted index, marked "Official Copy as Adopted by Ordinance No. 8110 " and to which shall be attached a copy of Ordinance No. 8110 , shall be filed with the city clerk and available to the public for inspection at all reasonable business hours. 
(Code 1994, § 110-44; Ord. No. 7864, § 1, 2-8-2011; Ord. No. 7884, § 1, 9-13-2011; Ord. No. 7905, § 1, 9-11-2012; Ord. No. 7932, § 1, 9-10-2013; Ord. No. 7956, § 1, 9-9-2014; Ord. No. 7981, § 1, 9-8-2015; Ord. No. 8006, § 1, 9-13-2016; Ord. No. 8055, § 1, 9-12-2017; Ord. No. 8086, § 1, 8-28-2018; Ord. No. 8110 , § 1, 8-27-2019)  
Sec. 44-4. - Mandatory license suspensions, conviction records, and final appeal disposition records. 
(a)  Court to forward surrendered licenses to state. When any person is convicted of any offense in the municipal court for which K.S.A. 8-255 makes mandatory the suspension of the driver license of such person by the state motor vehicle division, the municipal court shall require the surrender to it of all licenses then held by the person so convicted, and the court shall thereupon forward such licenses, or if such court has a clerk shall direct the clerk of such court to so forward such licenses, together with a record of such conviction to the state motor vehicle division, within ten days from the date the conviction becomes final. 
(b)  Clerk to provide record of convictions to state. The municipal court shall also forward to the state motor vehicle division a record of the conviction of any person in the court for a violation of any ordinance of the city relating to the operation of motor vehicles, other than regulations governing standing and parking. Such record of conviction shall be made upon any form approved by the state motor vehicle division and shall include the name and address of the party charged, his driver license number, the registration number of the vehicle involved, the nature of the offense, the date of hearing, the plea, the judge, whether bail or bond was forfeited, and the amount of fine or forfeiture as the case may be. 
(c)  Clerk to forward final disposition of appeals to state. The clerk of the court shall within ten days of the final disposition of any appeal forward a notification of such final disposition to the motor vehicle division. 
(d)  Conviction defined. For the purpose of this section, the term "conviction" means a final conviction, without regard to whether sentence was suspended or probation granted after such conviction. Also, for the purposes of this section, a forfeiture of bail, bond or collateral deposited to secure a defendant's appearance in court, which forfeiture has not been vacated, shall be equivalent to a conviction. 
(Code 1978, § 35-23; Code 1994, § 110-4)  
Sec. 44-5. - Breath and blood alcohol tests for driver under 21 years of age. 
(a)  It is unlawful for any person less than 21 years of age to operate or attempt to operate a vehicle in this state with a breath or blood alcohol content of 0.02 or greater. 
(b)  When a law enforcement officer determines that a breath or blood alcohol test is to be required of a person less than 21 years of age pursuant to K.S.A. 8-1001 or K.S.A. 8-2,142 in addition to any other notices required by law, the law enforcement officer shall provide written and oral notice that: 
(1)  It is unlawful for any person less than 21 years of age to operate or attempt to operate a vehicle in this state with a breath or blood alcohol content of 0.02 or greater; and 
(2)  If the person is less than 21 years of age at the time of the test request and submits to and completes the test or tests and the test results show an alcohol concentration of 0.02 or greater, the person's driving privileges will be suspended for at least 30 days upon the first occurrence and for one year upon a second or subsequent occurrence. 
(c)  Any suspension and restriction of driving privileges pursuant to this section shall be in addition to any disqualification from driving a commercial motor vehicle pursuant to K.S.A. 8-2,142. 
(d)  When a breath or blood alcohol test is requested pursuant to K.S.A. 8-1001 from a person less than 21 years of age, and results in a test result of 0.02 or greater, but less than 0.08, a law enforcement officer's certification under this section shall be prepared. The certification required by this section shall be signed by one or more officers to certify that: 
(1)  Certification requirements. 
a.  There existed reasonable grounds to believe the person was operating a vehicle while under the influence of alcohol or drugs, or both, or to believe that the person had been driving a commercial motor vehicle, as defined in K.S.A. 8-2,128 while having alcohol or other drugs in such person's system; 
b.  The person had been placed under arrest, was in custody or had been involved in a vehicle accident or collision; 
c.  A law enforcement officer had presented the person with the oral and written notice required by this section; 
d.  That the person was less than 21 years of age at the time of the test request; and 
e.  The result of the test showed that the person had an alcohol concentration of 0.02 or greater in such person's blood or breath. 
(2)  With regard to a breath test, in addition to those matters required to be certified under subsection (d)(1) of this section, that: 
a.  The testing equipment used was certified by the state department of health and environment; 
b.  The testing procedures used were in accordance with the requirements set out by the state department of health and environment; and 
c.  The person who operated the testing equipment was certified by the state department of health and environment to operate such equipment. 
(e)  If a hearing is requested as a result of a law enforcement officer's certification under this section, the scope of the hearing shall be limited to whether: 
(1)  A law enforcement officer had reasonable grounds to believe the person was operating a vehicle while under the influence of alcohol or drugs, or both, or to believe that the person had been driving a commercial motor vehicle, as defined in K.S.A. 8-2,128 while having alcohol or other drugs in such person's system; 
(2)  The person was in custody or arrested for an alcohol or drug related offense or was involved in a motor vehicle accident or collision resulting in property damage, personal injury or death; 
(3)  A law enforcement officer had presented the person with the oral and written notice required by K.S.A. 8-1001 and the oral and written notice required by this section; 
(4)  The testing equipment used was reliable; 
(5)  The person who operated the testing equipment was qualified; 
(6)  The testing procedures used were reliable; 
(7)  The test result determined that the person had an alcohol concentration of 0.02 or greater in such person's blood or breath; 
(8)  The person was operating a vehicle; and 
(9)  The person was less than 21 years of age at the time a test was requested. 
(f)  If a person less than 21 years of age submits to a breath or blood alcohol test requested pursuant to K.S.A. 8-1001 or K.S.A. 8-2,142 and produces a test result of 0.02 or greater, but less than 0.08, the person's driving privileges upon the first occurrence shall be suspended for 30 days and then restricted as provided by K.S.A. 8-1015 for an additional 330 days and upon a second or subsequent occurrence shall be suspended for one year. 
(g)  Except where there is a conflict between this section and K.S.A. 8-1001 and 8-1002 the provisions of K.S.A. 8-1001 and 8-1002 shall be applicable to proceedings under this section. 
(h)  Any determination under this section that a person less than 21 years of age had a test result of 0.02 or greater, but less than 0.08, and any resulting administrative action upon the person's driving privileges, upon the first occurrence of such test result and administrative action, shall not be considered by any insurance company in determining the rate charged for any automobile liability insurance policy or whether to cancel any such policy under the provisions of K.S.A. 40-277(4)(a). 
(i)  A traffic infraction is a violation of any provision of this section that prescribes or requires the same behavior as that prescribed or required by a statutory provision that is classified as a traffic infraction in K.S.A. 8-2118. All violations of this section that are not traffic infractions are traffic offenses. 
(Code 1994, §§ 110-5, 110-6; Ord. No. 7283, §§ 3, 4, 9-10-1996; Ord. No. 7320, §§ 3, 4, 8-12-1997; Ord. No. 7371, § 3, 8-11-1998) 
State Law reference— Similar provisions, K.S.A. 8-1567a.

(12)  Osage Street, from the west side of 5th Street to the east side of Broadway, vehicular traffic shall proceed east.

Sec. 44-33. - Bus, truck traffic. 
(a)  Definitions. The following words and phrases, when used in this section, shall have the meanings respectively ascribed to them in this subsection: 
Bus means every motor vehicle designed for carrying more than 12 passengers and used for the transportation of persons, and every motor vehicle other than a taxicab designed and used for the transportation of persons for compensation. 
Truck means every motor vehicle designed and used primarily for the transportation of property and rated with a carrying capacity greater than three-fourths ton. 
Truck-tractor means every motor vehicle designed and used primarily for drawing other vehicles and not so constructed as to carry a load other than a part of the weight of the vehicle and load so drawn. 
(a)  Prohibited streets. It is unlawful for any person to drive or to cause to be driven any bus or truck over and along the following streets: 
(1)  Broadway between Metropolitan Avenue and Pennsylvania Avenue; 
(2)  LeCompton Road from Ohio Street to the west city limits; 
(3)  Muncie Road from U.S. 73 to Shrine Park Road; 
(4)  South Third Street from Spruce to Elm Street; 
(5)  Tenth Street/Tenth Avenue from Eisenhower Road to Metropolitan Avenue; 
(6)  20th Street/20th Street Trafficway from Metropolitan Avenue to Eisenhower Road; 
provided that the provisions of this section shall not apply to any person driving or causing to be driven a bus or truck across street intersections; provided, further, that the provisions of this section shall not apply to any person driving or causing to be driven a bus or truck along a portion of a block on the streets where it becomes necessary to pick up from or deliver to property which is not accessible from any other street or alley or on a portion of the streets where it becomes necessary going to property which is not accessible from any other street or alley. 
(b)  Penalty. Any person convicted of a violation of the provisions of this section shall be subject to the penalties provided in this Code for unclassified misdemeanors. 
(Code 1978, § 35-22; Code 1994, § 110-47; Ord. No. 7253, § 2, 2-13-1996; Ord. No. 7334, § 2, 10-14-1997; Ord. No. 8007, § 1, 9-13-2016; Ord. No. 8030, § 1, 2-14-2017) 
State Law reference— Authority to prohibit certain classes of vehicles for specific streets, K.S.A. 8-2002(a)(14).  
Sec. 44-34. - Turning movements controlled on specific streets. 
The driver of a vehicle shall not make a turn from the streets named in this section at the indicated intersection: 
(1)  Limit Street, no left turn traveling eastbound and no right turn traveling westbound to enter Henry Leavenworth Elementary School. 
(2)  Sherman Ave, eastbound and westbound traffic at Tenth Street. 
(3)  Metropolitan Street, no right turn traveling westbound to enter Fort Leavenworth. 
(Code 1994, § 110-45; Ord. No. 7102, § 1(4), 8-11-1992; Ord. No. 7218, § 2, 6-27-1995; Ord. No. 7889, § 1, 11-22-2011; Ord. No. 8010, § 1, 9-13-2016; Ord. No. 8041, § 1, 6-13-2017) 
State Law reference— Authority to regulate or prohibit turning movements, K.S.A. 8-2002(a)(9); turning movements generally, K.S.A. 8-1545 et seq.  
Sec. 44-35. - Bicycles in downtown district. 
(a)  Definitions. Bicycle is defined as set forth in the Standard Traffic Ordinance for Kansas Cities. 
(b)  Prohibited area. No person shall ride a bicycle on the sidewalks in the downtown district defined as follows: from the east boundary of the city to the east side of Broadway, and from the south side of Seneca to the north side of Oak Street. 
(c)  Penalty. Any person violating any provision of this section shall be fined not less than $5.00 and no more than $500.00 for each offense. A separate offense shall be deemed committed on each day during or on which a violation occurs or continues. 
(Code 1994, § 110-48; Ord. No. 6986, §§ 1—3, 9-26-1989) 
State Law reference— Authority to regulate bicycles, K.S.A. 8-2002(a)(8); bicycles generally, K.S.A. 8-1586 et seq.  
Sec. 44-36. - Roller skates, roller blades and skateboards in downtown district. 
(a)  Definitions. As used in this section, the terms "roller skates," "roller blades," and "skateboards" mean and include riding in or on or by means of any coaster, toy vehicle or similar device. 
(b)  Prohibited area. No person shall roller skate, roller blade or ride a skateboard in the downtown district defined as follows: from the east boundary of the city to the east side of Broadway, and from the south side of Seneca to the north side of Oak Street, provided that for special events permits may be obtained as follows: 
(1)  Application in writing submitted to the city clerk designating the site of the proposed activity. 
(2)  The police chief shall make a recommendation to approve, disapprove or attach conditions to the permit to the city manager. 
(3)  The city manager may approve, disapprove or approve with conditions. 
(4)  The applicant may appeal the city manager's decision to the city commission by submitting a written notice of appeal through the city clerk. 
(5)  The city commission may grant or deny the permit or modify the conditions. 
(6)  The permit shall designate the site and the period of time the permit shall be valid. 
(c)  Penalty. Any person violating any provision of this section shall be fined not less than $5.00 and no more than $500.00 for each offense. A separate offense shall be deemed committed on each day during or on which a violation occurs or continues. 
(Code 1994, § 110-49; Ord. No. 6984, §§ 1—3, 9-26-1989; Ord. No. 7223, § 1, 8-1-1995)  
Secs. 44-37—44-60. - Reserved.  
ARTICLE III. - SPEED LIMITS

Sec. 44-62. - Speed limit on U.S. 73 city connecting link. 
Traffic on U.S. 73 connection link shall not exceed the speed limits as follows for the respective distances set out in this section, traveling north:

Traffic on U.S. 73 connection link shall not exceed the speed limits as follows for the respective distances set out in this section, traveling south:

(2)  Speed limit of 45 miles per hour starting 550 feet south of the south side of the Idaho Street intersection. 
(3)  Speed limit of 40 miles per hour starting 330 feet north of the Eisenhower and U.S. 73 intersection (south city limits).

ARTICLE IV. - PARKING, STOPPING AND STANDING[2] 
Footnotes: 
--- (2) --- 
State Law reference— Authority to regulate stopping, standing, K.S.A. 8-2002(a)(1); stopping, standing and parking generally, K.S.A. 8-1569 et seq.; citation procedure for illegal parking, standing or stopping, K.S.A. 8-2112 et seq. 
 
DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 
 
Sec. 44-85. - Penalty for violation of article; prima facie evidence of violation. 
Any operator of a vehicle permitting such vehicle to be parked or standing in violation of this article, upon conviction, shall be fined a sum of not less than $5.00 nor more than $25.00. If any vehicle is found to be in violation of the provisions of this article and the identity of the operator cannot be determined, the owner or person in whose name such vehicle is registered shall be held prima facie responsible for such violation. 
(Code 1978, § 35-47; Code 1994, § 110-76) 
State Law reference— Presumption of owner responsibility, K.S.A. 8-2114.  
Sec. 44-86. - Parking restricted to 24-hour period. 
It is unlawful for any person to park or to permit the parking, storing or standing of any vehicle, as defined in the standard traffic ordinance incorporated by section 44-1, upon any street or alley or in any public park or public off-street parking facility in the city, for a continuous period of more than 24 hours, without special permission of the police chief. If any police officer of the city shall discover a vehicle parked, standing or stored in violation of this section, such police officer shall make a reasonable effort to discover the owner or person having charge of such vehicle and notify such owner or person to remove the vehicle. If the owner or person in charge of such vehicle shall refuse to remove the vehicle after receiving such notice, such owner or person shall be guilty of a misdemeanor. If the owner or person in charge of such vehicle cannot be located, or if such owner or person is located and refuses to remove such vehicle, the vehicle shall be removed by the police department and towed to a suitable storage place in the city. Before such vehicle may be reclaimed or redeemed, the owner thereof shall pay all costs incurred by the city in removing and storing such vehicle. 
(Code 1978, § 35-45; Code 1994, § 110-77)  
Sec. 44-87. - No parking any time. 
The parking of automobiles, motor trucks, carriages, wagons and any and all other vehicles is prohibited on the following streets at any time: 
(1)  Second Avenue, west side, lying east of block E, Fackler's Addition to the city, from the north side of Linn Street to the south side of Elm Street. 
(2)  Second Avenue (originally platted as Sixth Street), west side, from the intersection with Linn to the intersection with Elm. 
(3)  Fourth Street, both sides, from the north side of Eisenhower Road to the south side of Metropolitan, with the exception that parking is allowed on the east side of Fourth Street from the north side of Walnut Street to the south side of Custer Street. 
(4)  Fifth Avenue, east side, from a point 70 feet south of the south curbline of Marshall Street to a point 70 feet north of the north curbline of Marshall Street.

(7)  Fifth Street, approximately eight feet adjacent to the entrance area at the dog and cat clinic located at 1101 North Fifth Street.
