Sec. 44-88. - Parking spaces for the disabled. 
Parking spaces for the disabled shall be incompliance with K.S.A. 8-1,129. 
(Code 1994, § 110-79; Ord. No. 6928, § 1, 3-8-1988; Ord. No. 6985, § 2, 9-26-1989) 
State Law reference— Parking in spaces reserved for disabled persons, K.S.A. 8-1,129.  
Sec. 44-89. - No parking within 25 feet of corners. 
The parking of automobiles, motor trucks, carriages, wagons and all other vehicles within 25 feet in each direction from the curbline corners at the intersections of the following streets in this city is prohibited: 
(1)  Third Street and Cherokee Street, Delaware Street and Shawnee Street. 
(2)  Fourth Street and Cherokee Street, Delaware Street and Shawnee Street. 
(3)  Fifth Street and Choctaw Street, Cherokee Street, Delaware Street, Shawnee Street and Seneca Street. 
(4)  Fifth Street, west side, between Shawnee Street and the alley north of Shawnee Street. 
(5)  Sixth Street and Delaware Street. 
(Code 1978, § 35-35; Code 1994, § 110-80)  
Sec. 44-90. - No parking, stopping or standing during school hours. 
The parking, stopping or standing of automobiles, motor trucks, campers, wagons and all other vehicles are prohibited during the days of regular school sessions from one-half hour before until one-half hour after regular school hours on the following streets: 
(1)  19th Street Terrace, north of Vilas Street, during school hours and on school days. 
(2)  Grand Avenue, east side, between Marion Street and Sherman Street during school hours and on school days. 
(3)  Kingman Street, between Marion Street and Sherman Street, during school hours and on school days. 
(Code 1978, § 35-36; Code 1994, § 110-81; Ord. No. 7102, § 1(1), 8-11-1992; Ord. No. 7218, § 3, 6-27-1995; Ord. No. 7290, § 2, 11-12-1996; Ord. No. 7589, § 2, 2-24-2004; Ord. No. 7630, § 1, 11-23-2004; Ord. No. 7870, § 1, 3-22-2011; Ord. No. 7889, § 2, 11-22-2011; Ord. No. 7983, § 1, 10-13-2015; Ord. No. 7986, § 1, 12-8-2015; Ord. No. 8009, § 1, 9-13-2016)  
Sec. 44-91. - No parking 7:00 a.m. to 5:00 p.m. on school days. 
The parking of vehicles, including automobiles, motor trucks and all other vehicles, is prohibited on school days from 7:00 a.m. to 5:00 p.m. at the following locations: 
(1)  Hughes Road, east side, from 150 feet north of Muncie Road to a point 150 feet south of Muncie Road. 
(2)  Muncie Road, north and south side, from the east side of Hughes Road a distance of 150 feet to the east. 
(Code 1978, § 35-36.1; Code 1994, § 110-82; Ord. No. 7123, §§ 2, 3, 3-9-1993; Ord. No. 7889, § 2, 11-22-2011)  
Sec. 44-92. - Reserved spaces for funeral homes. 
Funeral homes may reserve the necessary parking adjacent to their establishments for a period of one hour before a funeral until one hour after such funeral by placing a notice to the public in a form approved by the police chief on the spaces to be reserved, stating thereon the hours to be reserved, and any person violating this notice shall be subject to having such person's vehicle towed at such person's expense. 
(Code 1978, § 35-76; Code 1994, § 110-86; Ord. No. 6997, § 4, 11-14-1989)  
Sec. 44-93. - Parking of certain vehicles in residential areas prohibited; exceptions. 
No bus, vehicle, or panel truck of a greater capacity than three-quarter ton that is used for business purposes may be parked on the streets in any residential area at any time longer than the time necessary to deliver, load or unload, or to complete any repair that is being made for which the vehicle is necessary for the transportation of a repairman, such repairman's material and tools. 
(Code 1978, § 35-40; Code 1994, § 110-88)  
Sec. 44-94. - Parking truck more than 18 feet in length. 
It is unlawful to park any truck or other cargo-carrying vehicle longer than 18 feet, including any projections of the load thereof, at any time on Delaware Street from Main to Esplanade Street. 
(Code 1978, § 35-42; Code 1994, § 110-89)  
Sec. 44-95. - Parking, stopping, or standing prohibited at all times. 
The parking, stopping and standing of any automobiles, motor trucks, carriers, wagons, and any and all other vehicles is prohibited: 
(1)  On the north side of Seneca Street beginning 100 feet east of the curbline of Fifth Street and extending east a distance of 100 feet. 
(2)  On the east side of Commercial Place from Muncie Road to Commercial Street. 
(Code 1994, § 110-96; Ord. No. 7388, § 1, 11-24-1998; Ord. No. 8075, § 1, 5-22-2018)  
Sec. 44-96. - Displaying advertising. 
It is unlawful for any person to operate or park any vehicle on any street for the primary purpose of displaying advertising. 
(Code 1978, § 35-43; Code 1994, § 110-90)  
Sec. 44-97. - Selling from parked vehicle. 
It is unlawful for any person to park or keep a vehicle longer than ten minutes in one block for the purpose of selling merchandise contained in such vehicle without a valid permit. 
(Code 1978, § 35-44; Code 1994, § 110-93)  
Sec. 44-98. - Removal of vehicles after posting notice. 
The police shall have the power to remove or have removed any vehicle on any street in the city after posting or giving notice two hours in advance of such removal that the carriage or vehicle must be removed as ordered for removal of snow, painting of traffic signs or cleaning of the streets, which authority shall apply to any hour, day or night. 
(Code 1978, § 35-39; Code 1994, § 110-91)  
Sec. 44-99. - Removal of parked vehicles during emergencies. 
If, by reason of fire, flood, windstorm, snowstorm or other catastrophe, any emergency arises which, in the opinion of the fire chief, police chief, city engineer or other officer of the city, requires the removal of any vehicles parked or standing in the streets, alleys, public parks, public off-street parking facilities, or in any other public place in the city, such vehicles may be removed and towed by the city officers or employees to some other safe place in the city. The city official ordering such removal shall cause a record to be kept listing the description of any and all vehicles so removed, and the places from which and to which such vehicles are removed. Before removing any such vehicle, the official ordering the removal shall make a reasonable effort to locate the owner or person in charge of such vehicle, having due regard for the nature of the emergency, and to notify such owner or person to remove the vehicle. If the owner or person in charge of such vehicle so notified shall refuse to remove the vehicle, such owner or person shall be guilty of a misdemeanor. 
(Code 1978, § 35-46; Code 1994, § 110-92)  
Secs. 44-100—44-126. - Reserved.  
DIVISION 2. - MUNICIPAL PARKING LOTS 
 
Sec. 44-127. - Violation notices; towing of vehicles. 
(a)  When a police officer or other officer designated by the police chief finds a vehicle parked in violation of this division, he shall attach a violation notice to the vehicle. The notice shall be in the form of an envelope and shall state that, within seven days after the date shown on the notice, if the owner or operator of the vehicle places $25.00 in the notice envelope and deposits the envelope in one of the fee deposit boxes at the police department or delivers the notice and $25.00 to the police department, the parking violation shall be fully satisfied without the imposition of any other penalty. If the fine required in this section is not paid within seven days, the violator, upon conviction, shall be fined an amount not to exceed $50.00. 
(b)  Alternatively, the police chief or designated officer may order the vehicle removed and towed by a towing service in the city. The city official ordering such removal shall cause a record to be kept listing the description of any and all vehicles so removed and the place from which and to which such vehicles are removed. Before such vehicle may be reclaimed or redeemed, the owner thereof shall pay all costs for the towing and storing of such vehicle. 
(Code 1978, §§ 35-58, 35-59; Code 1994, §§ 110-131, 110-132; Ord. No. 6997, §§ 2, 3, 11-14-1989; Ord. No. 7398, § 2, 2-23-1999)  
Sec. 44-128. - City manager to establish parking restrictions; posting of signs. 
The city manager shall establish restricted parking spaces in the municipal parking lots in locations numbered for use by motor vehicles as defined by the standard traffic ordinance. The municipal parking lots or portions thereof as defined in this division shall be posted with signs giving notice to the public of the restrictions and prohibitions as may be established from time to time by the city manager. 
(Code 1978, § 35-57; Code 1994, § 110-136; Ord. No. 6997, § 2, 11-14-1989)  
Sec. 44-129. - Parking time limited. 
It is unlawful to park or permit the parking, storing or standing of any vehicle for any continuous period on any municipally owned or municipally operated off-street parking lot for a period of time longer than shown on the official signs erected on the parking facilities designating the maximum period for parking, provided that it shall not be unlawful for vehicles to park beyond the maximum time in such facilities on Sundays and holidays, as set out in the ordinances of the city. The term "official signs" means signs erected by city employees as directed by the city manager. 
(Code 1978, § 35-55; Code 1994, § 110-135)  
Sec. 44-130. - Prohibited truck parking. 
It shall be unlawful for any person to park, cause to be parked, or permit to remain parked or stored any truck in any of the municipal parking lots located in the downtown central business district. The term "truck" as used in this section shall have the meaning provided in the adopted standard traffic ordinance with a rated carrying capacity of more than three-quarter ton, or of any truck-tractor with or without trailer or semitrailer. 
(Code 1978, § 35-56; Code 1994, § 110-133; Ord. No. 6997, § 2, 11-14-1989)  
Sec. 44-131. - Parking permits for special events. 
(a)  Any organization sponsoring a class, convention, seminar or other group meeting within the downtown business area may make application to the police chief for a permit authorizing attendees to park a motor vehicle in the off-street parking lots without being subject to the time restrictions therein. The permit shall be displayed in the lower left corner of the windshield inside the vehicle and shall show on its face the date that the permit is effective. Failure to post the permit granted under this section shall render the user subject to the time restrictions in the parking area. 
(b)  Permits for parking in the municipal parking lots shall be issued for one-month periods, effective the first of each month, for a monthly fee as provided in the city fee schedule. 
(Code 1978, § 35-61; Code 1994, § 110-134)  
Sec. 44-132. - Commercial parking permits required. 
Upon application to the police department, a permit may issue to contractors, tradesmen, craftsmen, maintenance, repair and servicemen having a need to park at or near where they are performing their services in any time limit parking area. A permit may be issued to reserve parking or to have access to available parking in the normal conduct of their business, but in no case shall such permit be used as a substitute for a loading zone or parking in a restricted permit parking space. 
(Code 1978, §§ 35-78—35-80; Code 1994, § 110-137; Ord. No. 6997, § 5, 11-14-1989)  
Secs. 44-133—44-162. - Reserved.  
DIVISION 3. - LOADING ZONE PERMIT 
 
Sec. 44-163. - Application by businesses. 
Persons operating business establishments within the designated downtown business district streets shall make application for permission to establish loading zones in the area directly in front of their places of business. Such applications may only be made by persons who do not have an alley or rear entrance loading zone space at their place of business. All applications shall be approved by the chief of police and shall be valid for a period of one year from date of issuance and are subject to renewal annually. Fees for such permits are as provided in the city fee schedule. Fees are nonrefundable. 
(Code 1978, § 35-89; Code 1994, § 110-161; Ord. No. 6997, § 6, 11-14-1989)  
Sec. 44-164. - Review of denial by city manager. 
All applications denied by the police chief may be appealed to the city manager by submitting a written request for appeal to the office of the city manager within 30 days from the date of denial. 
(Code 1978, § 35-90; Code 1994, § 110-162; Ord. No. 6997, § 6, 11-14-1990)  
Sec. 44-165. - Designation of zone; violation. 
Upon approval a loading zone sign shall be installed by the city. It is unlawful for noncommercial vehicles to park in such loading zones. Any unauthorized vehicles parked in such loading zones will be ticketed for illegal parking. 
(Code 1978, § 35-94; Code 1994, § 110-166; Ord. No. 6997, § 6, 11-14-1989)  
Secs. 44-166—44-185. - Reserved.  
ARTICLE V. - EMERGENCY SNOW ROUTES 
 
Sec. 44-186. - Declaration of traffic emergency; use of designated snow routes required. 
(a)  When snow has accumulated or there is a possibility that snow will accumulate to such a depth that snow removal operations will be required, the city manager or, in the absence of the city manager, the police chief may declare a traffic emergency, and, until such traffic emergency is terminated, it is unlawful to park a vehicle on any street designated an emergency snow route in this article or to operate a motor vehicle on any emergency snow route in such manner or condition that such motor vehicle stalls and is unable to proceed by reason of the fact that the driving wheels are not equipped with tire chains or snow tires. 
(b)  The police chief, during a traffic emergency, is empowered to waive or suspend enforcement of parking regulations not specifically designated within this article. 
(Code 1978, § 35-106; Code 1994, § 110-186)  
Sec. 44-187. - Notice. 
After declaration of a traffic emergency, the city manager shall cause appropriate notice thereof to be given through the local press, radio and other media. The traffic emergency shall be terminated by notice given substantially in the same manner as the traffic emergency was declared. 
(Code 1978, § 35-107; Code 1994, § 110-187)  
Sec. 44-188. - Removal of vehicles. 
All vehicles parked on emergency snow routes must be removed within two hours after notice of a traffic emergency has been given. Any vehicle parked on an emergency snow route after such period of time may be removed or caused to be removed by a police officer to the nearest garage or other place of safety and the vehicle may not be recovered until the towing and storage charges are paid. 
(Code 1978, § 35-108; Code 1994, § 110-188)  
Sec. 44-189. - Establishment of routes; posting of signs. 
(a)  The following streets are established as emergency snow routes within the city: 
(1)  East-west streets: 
a.  Cherokee Street, Third Street to 20th Street. 
b.  County Road 5, 15th Street to Michals Road. 
c.  Eisenhower Road, Fourth Street to 20th Street Trafficway. 
d.  Kiowa Street, Third Street to Fourth Street. 
e.  Marshall Street, Fifth Avenue to Broadway (Hospital). 
f.  McDonald Road, Hughes Road to Shrine Park Road. 
g.  Metropolitan Avenue, from Centennial Bridge to 20th Street. 
h.  Muncie Road, Fourth Street to 10th Avenue. 
i.  Ohio and LeCompton Road, Tenth Avenue to city limits. 
j.  Ottawa Street, Third Street to 20th Street. 
k.  Pennsylvania, Fourth Street to Tenth Avenue. 
l.  Shawnee Street, Third Street to 20th Street. 
m.  Spruce Street, Third Street to 15th Street. 
n.  Thornton Street, Fourth Street to Tenth Avenue. 
o.  Thornton Street, 17th Street to 19th Street. 
p.  Vilas Street, Tenth Avenue to 20th Street Trafficway. 
q.  Vilas Street to be extended from 22nd Street to 25th Street. 
(2)  North-south streets: 
a.  Second Avenue, Congress Street to Limit Street. 
b.  Third Street, Kiowa Street to Spruce Street. 
c.  Fourth Street, Metropolitan Avenue to Eisenhower Road. 
d.  Fifth Avenue, Olive Street to Thornton Street. 
e.  Fifth Street, Metropolitan Avenue to Congress Street. 
f.  Seventh Street, Metropolitan Avenue to Spruce Street. 
g.  Tenth Avenue, Spruce Street to Eisenhower Road. 
h.  Tenth Street, Metropolitan Avenue to Spruce Street. 
i.  13th Street, Metropolitan Avenue to Cherokee Street. 
j.  15th Street, Vilas Street to Limit Street. 
k.  17th Street, Vilas Street to Thornton Street. 
l.  18th Street, U.S. 73 to Metropolitan Avenue. 
m.  18th Street, Dakota Street to Spruce Street. 
n.  18th Street, LeCompton Road to Thornton Street. 
o.  19th Street Terrace, 20th Street Trafficway to Thornton Street. 
p.  20th Street, Metropolitan Avenue to Spruce Street.

r.  Broadway, Metropolitan Street to Thornton Street.

ARTICLE VI. - ABANDONED VEHICLES[3] 

Footnotes: 
--- (3) --- 
State Law reference— Abandoned and disabled vehicles, K.S.A. 8-1101 et seq. 
 
Sec. 44-217. - Definitions. 
The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
Abandoned vehicle means any motor vehicle left or abandoned on a highway or other property open to use by the public for a period of time in excess of 48 hours. 
Highway means the entire width between the boundary lines of every way publicly maintained when any part thereof is open to the use of the public for the purposes of vehicular traffic. 
Motor vehicle means every vehicle, or tractor-trailer combination, which is self-propelled and by which any person or property is or may be transported or drawn upon a highway, except vehicles used exclusively upon stationary rails or tracks. 
(Code 1978, § 18-35; Code 1994, § 110-211) 
State Law reference— Similar provisions, K.S.A. 8-1101.  
Sec. 44-218. - Police chief designated as enforcing officer. 
The police chief is designated as the enforcing officer charged with the administration of this article. 
(Code 1978, § 18-36; Code 1994, § 110-212)  
Sec. 44-219. - Removal by city. 
When a person leaves a motor vehicle on a public street or other property open to use by the public, the city may, after 48 hours, when the motor vehicle interferes with public highway operations, immediately remove the vehicle. 
(Code 1978, § 18-37; Code 1994, § 110-213)  
Chapter 46 - UTILITIES[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
State Law reference— Municipal utilities, K.S.A. 12-801 et seq. 
 
ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 
 
Sec. 46-1. - Tampering. 
Any person who shall tamper with any sewer or water line constituting a part of the city's sewer or water system or shall make any connection therewith without written permission from the city, or who shall reconnect service after it has been disconnected for the nonpayment of a sewage charge without first paying the delinquency and the charges provided for in section 46-115, shall be guilty of a misdemeanor. 
(Code 1978, § 36-2; Code 1994, § 114-2)  
Secs. 46-2—46-20. - Reserved.  
ARTICLE II. - WATER  
DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 
 
Secs. 46-21—46-43. - Reserved.  
DIVISION 2. - WATER LINES 
 
Sec. 46-44. - Permit—Required for installation and construction. 
No water lines or appurtenances shall be placed on any street or public grounds in the city unless a special permit therefor is obtained as provided in this division. 
(Code 1978, § 36-23; Code 1994, § 114-76)  
Sec. 46-45. - Permit—Application; issuance. 
When any person having authority in the city to construct, install or change the location of water lines, such person shall apply to the city engineer for a permit to do so. Such application shall be accompanied with the schedule and plat showing the lines to be constructed or changes to be made and the facts required by this division. The city engineer, if such application is in conformity with the ordinances of the city and the ordinance granting such person the right to construct, install or change location of lines, shall issue a permit for the construction, installation or change applied for, and, thereupon, such individual, company or corporation shall proceed to construct, install or make the proposed changes. 
(Code 1978, § 36-24; Code 1994, § 114-77)  
Sec. 46-46. - Plats filed with city engineer. 
Every person having water lines upon the streets or public grounds of the city shall file in the office of the city engineer a schedule and plat showing the exact location of all existing water lines. 
(Code 1978, § 36-25; Code 1994, § 114-78)  
Secs. 46-47—46-65. - Reserved.  
ARTICLE III. - SEWERS  
DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 
 
Secs. 46-66—46-89. - Reserved.  
DIVISION 2. - CONNECTIONS 
 
Sec. 46-90. - Outside benefit district, sewer district or development. 
(a)  The city manager may allow a property owner outside a benefit district, sewer district or development to connect to the city's sanitary sewer system if the following conditions exist: 
(1)  The property has not been in a previous special benefit district; 
(2)  There exists a public sanitary sewer so located that the property can be connected to the public system; and 
(3)  It is not practical to create a benefit district to serve the private property. 
(b)  The property owner shall make a payment to the city in the amount provided in the city fee schedule applied against the square footage of the lot or tract of land that the property owner wishes to have connected to the city's sewer system. 
(c)  If the area is not a platted lot, then the city manager may designate a portion of not less than 10,000 square feet upon which to apply the average square footage cost. The area to be developed must be inclusive of an area having minimum frontage as required by city code on an open dedicated public street. 
(d)  Multifamily, industrial, and commercial connections will be based upon the total lot size. The city manager may reduce the lot size if there is sufficient indication that the square footage outside the building tract will be developed in the future. The lot size assessed will then be determined by a minimum of 10,000 square feet but being inclusive of all improvements to include outbuildings and parking facilities. 
(e)  A survey description at the cost of the property owner of the property to be excluded from future benefit district assessments as provided in subsection (f) of this section. 
(f)  There shall be a written agreement by and between the property owner and the city with the stipulation contained therein that the property shall not be included in any future sanitary sewer district of the city. The agreement shall be properly notarized and filed on record in the office of the register of deeds in the county. 
(Code 1978, § 36-45; Code 1994, § 114-112; Ord. No. 7441, § 1, 2-8-2000)  
Sec. 46-91. - Duty of property owners; connection by city. 
(a)  It is the duty of every person owning any dwelling, house or any other building within the city, when such dwelling, house or building is or shall be located within 300 feet of a sewer, or in any block within any sewer district in the city in which a sewer extends, to make connections with such sewer for the purpose of disposing of all substances from any such building affecting the public health which may be lawfully and properly disposed of by means of such sewer. 
(b)  If any person or agent shall fail, neglect or refuse to connect any such building with the sewer system as provided for in this section for more than ten days after being notified in writing to do so, the city commission may advertise for bids for the construction and making of such sewer connections. The contract shall be awarded to the lowest responsible bidder and shall cause such building or premises to be connected to the sewer system. 
(c)  All costs and expenses shall be assessed against the property connected. Such assessment is to be made in the same manner as other special assessments are made. 
(Code 1978, § 36-47; Code 1994, § 114-114)  
Sec. 46-92. - Unlawful connections. 
It is unlawful to connect an open gutter, cesspool, privy vault or any drain of any kind whatsoever of the surface water from the roof or yard to a sanitary sewer, or to connect any sanitary sewer or sanitary sewage to any drainage or stormwater sewer. 
(Code 1978, § 36-48; Code 1994, § 114-115)  
Secs. 46-93—46-112. - Reserved.  
DIVISION 3. - SEWER SERVICE CHARGES 
 
Sec. 46-113. - Levy. 
(a)  Definitions. The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this division, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
BOD (denoting biochemical oxygen demand) means the quantity of oxygen utilized in the biochemical oxidation of organic matter under standard laboratory procedure in five days at 20 degrees Celsius, expressed in milligrams per liter (mg/L). 
Capital charge means that portion of the total wastewater service charge, which is levied for local capital costs, local investment in plant facilities, and other local costs excluding operation, maintenance and replacement costs. 
CCF means 100 cubic feet. 
Nonresidential customer means each customer whose premises are served by the city's wastewater treatment works and who is not either a residential customer or a customer who is provided wastewater service under a written contract with the city. 
Normal domestic wastewater means wastewater that has a BOD of not more than 350 mg/L and a suspended solids concentration of not more than 350 mg/L. 
Operation and maintenance mean expenditures for materials, labor, utilities and other items, which are necessary for operating, managing and maintaining the wastewater treatment works to achieve the capacity and performance for which such works were designed and constructed. 
Replacement means expenditures for obtaining and installing equipment, accessories or appurtenances which are necessary during the useful life of the treatment works to maintain the capacity and performance for which such works were designed and constructed. The term "operation and maintenance" includes replacement. 
Residential customer means any customer served by the city's wastewater treatment works whose lot, parcel of real estate or building is used only for domestic dwelling purposes. 
SS (suspended solids) means solids that either float on the surface of or are in suspension in wastewater, and which are removable by a standard specific laboratory filtration device. 
Treatment works means any devices and systems for the collection, storage, treatment, recycling and reclamation of wastewater or necessary to recycle or reuse water at the most economical cost over the useful life of the works. These include intercepting sewers, outfall sewers, wastewater collection systems, pumping, treatment and other facilities, which are an integral part of the wastewater collection and treatment processes or are used for ultimate disposal of residues resulting from such treatment. 
Useful life means the estimated period during which a treatment works will be operated. 
User charge means that portion of the total wastewater service charge, which is levied in a proportional and equitable manner for the cost of operation, maintenance and replacement of wastewater treatment works. 
_____
(b)  Wastewater service charges. The following monthly service charges shall be paid to the city by all residential and nonresidential customers receiving service from the city's wastewater treatment works: 
(1)  City service charge. 
a.  Inside city customers. Monthly wastewater service charges shall be calculated for all customers located within the city's corporate limits. The service charges shall be based on each customer's water consumption as defined in this subsection. The service charges for these customers shall be as follows:

The service charges shall be based on each customer's water consumption as defined in this subsection. The service charges for these customers shall be as follows:

c.  Residential customers. At the end of the three-month period consisting of the consecutive months of January, February and March of each year, the average monthly consumption of water by each residential customer located within the corporate limits of the city during such three-month period shall be ascertained and the monthly wastewater service charges paid by such residential customer for each of the following months of the 12-month period commencing with July 1 shall be based upon the average monthly consumption of water by such residential customer during this three-month period. The minimum wastewater service charge for those residential customers for premises located within the corporate limits of the city who do not have a record of average monthly gross consumption of water as set forth in this section shall be $29.88 per month, which consists of a user charge of $17.66 and a capital charge of $12.22. 
d.  Nonresidential customers. At the end of the 12-month period consisting of a fiscal year of July through June, the average monthly consumption of water by each nonresidential customer during such 12-month period shall be ascertained and the monthly service charges paid by such nonresidential customer for each of the following 12 months shall be based upon the average monthly consumption of water by such customer during such 12-month period. The minimum wastewater service charge for those nonresidential customers who do not have a record of average monthly gross consumption of water as set forth in this section shall be calculated monthly and shall be based on the consumption of water by such nonresidential customer for each month until the customer has established a 12-month fiscal year as provided in this subsection, at which time the charges shall be computed on the average monthly use for such 12-month period as provided in this subsection. Nonresidential customers, upon written request submitted to the city clerk by such customer, may be billed for wastewater service charges based on actual water usage for each monthly billing period. 
e.  Unusual burden on treatment works. The city shall establish fair and equitable charges for any industrial or other customer served by the city who discharges waste into the city's wastewater treatment works of such volume, type or character that places an unusual burden on the city's treatment works. 
f.  Users receiving water from other sources. For any customer who receives water from a source other than the city's water supply system and who discharges wastes into the city's wastewater treatment works, the volume of such wastes discharged shall either be estimated by the city or, at the discretion of the city, the customer shall, at his sole cost and expense, install and maintain in good operating condition suitable meters or measuring devices of standard type and design at an appropriate point or points as necessary to properly measure the customers sewage discharge and shall permit the city to perform the reading of such metering device. The sewer charges for such customer's shall be established in accordance with such estimates or metering records. 
(2)  Extra strength surcharge. Any customer discharging a liquid into the city's wastewater treatment works with a BOD or suspended solids (SS) concentration greater than normal domestic wastewater shall pay an additional monthly charge based on the billable volume of water, as follows:

(3)  Contract customers. Any agreement or contract entered into by the city with any customer relating to the provisions of wastewater service shall be in compliance with the user charge regulations as contained in 40 CFR 35, subpart E. 
(Code 1978, § 36-57; Code 1994, § 114-126; Ord. No. 8087, §§ 1, 2, 10-9-2018)

Sec. 46-114. - Billing; objections; hearing; disconnection. 
(a)  The waterworks board is authorized to render bills monthly to all persons whose premises are connected, or are required to be connected, or may be connected, to the sanitary sewer system of the city. Such bills shall be mailed or delivered by the waterworks board with the water bill of such persons at a time not later than ten days following the reading of the water meter of such persons, and such bills shall be computed on a monthly basis. 
(b)  The waterworks board shall not assume responsibility for speedy and safe delivery, or for the failure to receive the monthly bill, but a duplicate thereof may be obtained from the office of the city waterworks board either in person or by telephone request. 
(c)  If the bill remains unpaid for a period of 30 days after such bill has been mailed or delivered, water service may be discontinued and shut off at the discretion of the waterworks board and sewer service may be discontinued by the city, provided that before any such water service or sewer service shall be discontinued for failure to pay the sewage disposal service charge, the person so defaulting in the payment of his service charge shall be given ten days' notice of the intention to shut off the water service or sewer service. 
(d)  If within a ten-day period the person receiving such notice of intention to discontinue his water service or sewer service shall file with the city commission a written notice stating that the person believes that he has a just and reasonable complaint against the assessment of the sewage disposal service charge, then the mayor shall, within ten days from the receipt of the written notice, call a meeting of the city commission, and the city clerk shall notify the aggrieved party, in writing, at least three days before the date on which the meeting is to be held, and the aggrieved party may appear at the meeting and present his grievance. If, at the meeting, the city commission feels that the complaint of the aggrieved party is just, the city commission may make such adjustment of the sewage disposal service charge as it deems equitable and just in the premises. If the city commission at the meeting deems the complaint of the aggrieved party is without merit, it may affirm the sewage disposal service charge of which the aggrieved party complains, and the finding of the city commission shall be final and binding upon all parties concerned. 
(e)  Any person who has not received a notice of the intent to disconnect their sewer service but believes that he has a just and reasonable complaint against the assessment of the sewage disposal service charge may file a written request with the city public works director for a review of the levy of the sewage disposal charge. The city public works director or his designee shall make a written response within ten days of the receipt of the request. Within ten days of the receipt of the response, any person who still believes they have a just and reasonable complaint may make a written request for a review by the city commission, then the mayor shall, within ten days from the receipt of the written notice, call a meeting of the city commission, and the city clerk shall notify the aggrieved party, in writing, at least three days before the date on which the meeting is to be held, and the aggrieved party may appear at the meeting and present his grievance. If at the meeting the city commission feels that the complaint of the aggrieved party is just, the city commission may make such adjustment of the sewage disposal service charge as it deems equitable and just in the premises. If the city commission at the meeting deems the complaint of the aggrieved party is without merit, it may affirm the sewage disposal service charge of which the aggrieved party complains, and the finding of the city commission shall be final and binding upon all parties concerned. 
(Code 1978, § 36-58; Code 1994, § 114-127; Ord. No. 7547, § 1, 10-22-2002; Ord. No. 7676, § 1, 11-8-2005; Ord. No. 7716, § 1, 11-28-2006; Ord. No. 7723, § 1, 1-23-2007)  
Sec. 46-115. - Disconnection, reconnection charges. 
If water service or sewer service shall be discontinued under authority of this division, the water service or sewer service shall not be restored until the delinquent account plus a penalty of five percent and a cost charge covering the actual expense on an hourly basis of turning off the service and a cost charge covering the actual expense on an hourly basis of restoring the service has been paid by the person whose water service has been turned off. Such disconnection and reconnection charges for water service shall be retained by the waterworks board to defray its costs in the premises and the charges for disconnection from and reconnection to sewers shall be retained by the city. 
(Code 1978, § 36-59; Code 1994, § 114-128; Ord. No. 7547, § 1, 10-22-2002; Ord. No. 7676, § 1, 11-8-2005; Ord. No. 7716, § 1, 11-28-2006; Ord. No. 7723, § 1, 1-23-2007)  
Sec. 46-116. - Payment required; no discrimination. 
No person shall be allowed the use of the sanitary sewers of the city without the payment of the sewage disposal service charge, nor shall there be any discrimination among users of like classes as to rates. 
(Code 1978, § 36-60; Code 1994, § 114-129; Ord. No. 7547, § 1, 10-22-2002; Ord. No. 7676, § 1, 11-8-2005; Ord. No. 7716, § 1, 11-28-2006; Ord. No. 7723, § 1, 1-23-2007)  
Sec. 46-117. - Dumping vehicle loads into treatment facility. 
All carts, receptacles, containers and implements used for removing the contents of any vault, septic tank or cesspool shall not be dumped into the public sewage treatment facility of the city without prior written permission from the public works director or his designee. 
(Code 1978, § 36-61; Code 1994, § 114-130; Ord. No. 7547, § 1, 10-22-2002; Ord. No. 7676, § 1, 11-8-2005; Ord. No. 7716, § 1, 11-28-2006; Ord. No. 7723, § 1, 1-23-2007)  
Secs. 46-118—46-147. - Reserved.  
DIVISION 4. - INDUSTRIAL WASTES 
 
Sec. 46-148. - Abbreviations. 
The following abbreviations, when used in this division, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
BOD means five-day, 20 degrees Celsius biochemical oxygen demand. 
mg/L means milligrams per liter. 
SS means suspended solids. 
(Code 1978, § 36-69; Code 1994, § 114-141)  
Sec. 46-149. - Review, acceptance by city engineer. 
Review and acceptance by the city engineer with the advice and consent of the city commission shall be obtained prior to the discharge into the city sewers of any wastewater having a five-day, 20 degrees Celsius BOD greater than 300 mg/L based on analysis of a 24-hour composite sample or an SS greater than 400 mg/L. 
(Code 1978, § 36-70; Code 1994, § 114-142)  
Sec. 46-150. - Prohibited wastes. 
The following wastes shall not be discharged into the city sewers: 
(1)  Any liquid or vapor having a temperature higher than 150 degrees Fahrenheit, except where the volume of discharge represents a significant portion of the flow through a particular sewer, a lower limit may be prescribed to prevent odor nuisance. 
(2)  Stormwater and surface drain water. 
(3)  Wastes having a pH less than 5.5 or more than 10.0 or otherwise having chemical properties which are hazardous or are capable of causing damage to the sewage works or personnel. 
(4)  Garbage or waste that has not been properly shredded. 
(5)  Insoluble oils, fats and greases. So-called soluble oils may be permitted to the extent of 100 mg/L, provided that subsequent dilution in the sewers or treatment plant does not result in separation. 
(6)  Gasoline, naphtha, benzene, oil and other flammable or explosive liquids, solids or gases. 
(7)  Any waste which contains more than 100 mg/L of fat, oil and grease (exclusive of soap). 
(8)  Any corrosive, noxious or malodorous material or substance which either singly or by reaction with other wastes is capable of causing damage to the sewage works or creating a public nuisance or hazard or preventing entry into the sewers for maintenance and repair. 
(9)  Any material or substance not specifically mentioned in this section which is in itself corrosive, irritating to human beings and animals, toxic or noxious or which by interaction with other wastes could produce undesirable effects including deleterious action on the sewage works, adversely affect any treatment process, constitute a hazard to human beings or animals or have an adverse effect upon the receiving stream. 
(Code 1978, § 36-71; Code 1994, § 114-143)  
Sec. 46-151. - Investigations. 
It shall be the duty of the city engineer to cause investigation to be made of all properties reasonably believed to be depositing sewage in violation of the provisions of this division. 
(Code 1978, § 36-72; Code 1994, § 114-144)  
Sec. 46-152. - Right of entry, information. 
The city engineer shall have the right to enter at any reasonable time any property served by a connection to the city sewer system for the purpose of inspecting the system. On demand, the owner or occupants of any property so served shall furnish to the city engineer such information as the engineer may require regarding the sewage system on such property. The refusal of the owner or occupant of such property to supply such information or to allow the survey or investigation shall be prima facie evidence of the presence of improper usage and which is subject to this division. 
(Code 1978, § 36-73; Code 1994, § 114-145)  
Sec. 46-153. - Termination of service for violations. 
The city engineer may, upon reasonable belief that any person is depositing sewage in violation of the provisions of this division, recommend to the city commission the suspension or revocation of the right of any person to discharge sewage into the sanitary sewers or the sewage disposal plant of the city until proof satisfactory to the city commission shall be supplied establishing that effective means have been taken to prevent the discharge of sewage in violation of this division. Service shall not be restored until such corrections have been completed in compliance with the requirements of the city engineer. 
(Code 1978, § 36-74; Code 1994, § 114-146)  
Sec. 46-154. - Disconnections of service; notice. 
When the danger to the city sewage system appears imminent, no notice shall be required prior to the disconnection of service. In all other cases, service shall be disconnected following five days' notice in writing. 
(Code 1978, § 36-75; Code 1994, § 114-147)  
Secs. 46-155—46-254. - Reserved.  
ARTICLE IV. - UNDERGROUND CONDUITS 
 
Sec. 46-255. - Requirement. 
Every person having any poles erected on or any wires or cables strung in, along, over or across any streets and alleys in the city, used for telephone, telegraph or electric light or power purposes, may be ordered and directed to begin within 90 days from the date of the order to place all or any portion of their wires and cables underground in subsurface conduits and to have all such wires, poles and cables removed from all such streets and alleys within nine months from the date of the order. 
(Code 1978, § 36-163; Code 1994, § 114-256)  
Sec. 46-256. - Designation by resolution. 
The city commission, by resolution, or the city engineer, may designate the portions of the streets, alleys or highways in which pipes or conduits shall be laid as provided in this article. 
(Code 1978, § 36-164; Code 1994, § 114-257)  
Sec. 46-257. - Approval, supervision of city engineer. 
The system and the kind of pipe to be used for underground conduit shall, before any work is done, be approved by the city engineer. The pipe or conduits shall be laid in the streets or in the alleys as the city engineer may deem advisable. All work done or performed under this article shall be done under the supervision of the city engineer. 
(Code 1978, § 36-165; Code 1994, § 114-258)  
Sec. 46-258. - Placement of manholes and appliances permitted. 
Any person placing telegraph, telephone, electric light and power wires and cables underground in subsurface conduits shall have the right to place such necessary manholes and appliances for affording access to such conduits, wires and cables for making connections therefrom to subscribers and stations. Such conduits, manholes and appliances shall be constructed and the wires and cables placed therein in such manner as not to injure or destroy any vault, sewer, water or gas pipe. 
(Code 1978, § 36-166; Code 1994, § 114-259)  
Sec. 46-259. - Conformance to new grades of streets. 
When the city shall grade or regrade any street, alley or highway along or across which any person has laid any pipe or conduit, the person owning or using such pipe or conduit shall, at such person's own expense, change such pipe or conduit to conform to the street, alley or highway so graded or regraded, on an order therefor from the city engineer. 
(Code 1978, § 36-167; Code 1994, § 114-260)  
Sec. 46-260. - Owner to hold city harmless. 
Every person placing telegraph, telephone, electric light or power wires or cables, electric wires or cables underground in subsurface conduits shall save and hold the city harmless from all damages for personal or other injuries either to private individuals or corporations or to property for which the city may in any way become liable resulting from or growing out of any negligence or want of care on the part of any such persons in the construction of any pipe, conduit or other appliance, or any defective construction, unsound material or want of repair of any conduits, wires, cables, manholes or other appliances used, maintained or constructed by such person under this article or any other ordinance or franchise granted to any such person. 
(Code 1978, § 36-168; Code 1994, § 114-261)  
Appendix A - DEVELOPMENT REGULATIONS  
ARTICLE 1. - GENERAL PROVISIONS 
 
Sec. 1.01. - Overview. 
A.  Title. These regulations, shall be known, as the "Development Regulations of the City of Leavenworth, Kansas" or "developmental regulations" these regulations are adopted pursuant to K.S.A. 12-747 et seq. and 12-757 et seq. 
B.  Purpose. These regulations serve the following purposes: 
1.  To promote the health, safety, comfort and economic development of the city; 
2.  To preserve and protect property values throughout the city; 
3.  To regulate the height, number of stories and size of buildings; the percentage of lot coverage; the size of yards, courts, and other open spaces; and density of population; 
4.  To divide the jurisdictional area into zones and districts; 
5.  To regulate the location and use of buildings and land within each district or zone. 
C.  Jurisdiction. These regulations apply to all land and structures within the incorporated area of the city. Fort Leavenworth, the U.S. Penitentiary, and the Veterans Administration Reservations are excluded from the jurisdiction of these regulations. 
D.  Exemptions. The following structures and uses shall be exempt from the provisions of these regulations: 
1.  Utilities. Poles, wires, cables, conduits, vaults, laterals, pipes, street lighting, mains, valves, or other similar equipment or improvements for the distribution to consumers of telephone or other communications, electricity, gas, or water, or the collection of sewage or surface water operated or maintained by a public utility; and 
2.  Railroads. Railroad track, signals, bridges, and similar facilities and equipment located on a railroad right-of-way, and maintenance and repair work on such facilities and equipment. 
E.  Annexation. 
1.  All territory annexed into the city, voluntarily or involuntarily, shall be zoned after annexation in accordance with the zoning district most closely matching the comprehensive land use plan for that area, determined by table 1-01 below. 
2.  The landowner may propose a different zoning classification through an application for rezoning, as provided elsewhere in this Code. The rezoning must be completed at or before the time the annexation petition is presented to the city commission for consideration.
